{{Other people||David Friedman (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = David M. Friedman |image = David Friedman.jpg |office = [[United States Ambassador to Israel]] |president = [[Donald Trump]] |term_start = May 15, 2017 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Daniel B. Shapiro|Dan Shapiro]] |successor = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |birth_name = David Melech Friedman |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|8|8}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |spouse = {{marriage|Tammy Sand|July 1981}} |children = 5 | religion = [[Orthodox Judaism]] | alma_mater = [[Columbia University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[New York University]] {{small|([[Juris Doctor|JD]])}} |footnotes = }} '''David Melech Friedman''' (born August 8, 1958) is an American bankruptcy lawyer and the [[United States Ambassador to Israel]]. He joined the law firm [[Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman]] (then known as Kasowitz, Hoff, Benson & Torres) in 1994, where he met and represented [[Donald Trump]], then chairman and president of [[The Trump Organization]]. He served as an advisor to Trump during his successful [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]]. In December 2016, President-elect Trump's [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump|transition team]] announced that Friedman was Trump's nominee for ambassador. His nomination was met with support from conservative Israeli and Jewish American activist groups, and opposition from liberal advocacy organizations, particularly [[J Street]]. He was confirmed by the full [[United States Senate|Senate]] on March 23, 2017, with a 52–46 vote, officially sworn in by Vice President [[Mike Pence]] on March 29 and presented his credentials on May 15. ==Early life and education== Friedman was one of four children born to Morris S. Friedman (d. 2005),{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/16/world/middleeast/david-friedman-us-ambassador-israel.html |title=David Friedman, Choice for Envoy to Israel, Is Hostile to Two-State Efforts |last1=Kershner |first1=Isabel |last2=Stolberg |first2=Sheryl Gay |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 16, 2016 |accessdate=December 24, 2016}} a Temple Hillel rabbi{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/25/classified/paid-notice-deaths-friedman-rabbi-morris-s.html|title=Paid Notice: FRIEDMAN, RABBI MORRIS S.|date=25 February 2005|publisher=New York Times Archives}} and Addi Friedman, a high school English teacher.{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/world-news/u-s-election-2016/.premium-1.752378|title=What Do We Know About David Friedman, Trump's Pick for Ambassador to Israel?|date=November 11, 2016|work=[[Haaretz]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes|last1=Maltz|first1=Judy|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-03-20/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-david-friedman|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About David Friedman|author=Galvin, Gaby|date=20 March 2017|publisher=U.S. News and World Report}} He grew up in [[North Woodmere, New York]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/04/style/tammy-d-sand-is-engaged-to-david-melech-friedman.html|title=Tammy D. Sand Is Engaged To David Melech Friedman|date=January 4, 1981|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=December 24, 2016}} His father was a [[rabbi]] at Temple Hillel, a [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative]] synagogue in North Woodmere, and served as the head of the [[New York Board of Rabbis]].{{cite news |url=http://forward.com/news/357320/meet-david-friedman-bankruptcy-lawyer-turned-possible-israel-ambassador/ |title=Meet David Friedman, Bankruptcy Lawyer Turned Possible Israel Ambassador |last=Solomon |first=Daniel J. |work=[[The Forward]] |date=December 16, 2016 |accessdate=December 24, 2016}} His mother was a high school English teacher. He graduated from Hebrew Academy of Nassau County (HANC) high school in 1974, and earned his [[Bachelor of Arts|bachelor's degree]] in anthropology from [[Columbia University]], graduating in 1978,{{Cite web|url=http://jstreet.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/JSt-Ambassadors-v1.pdf|title=US Ambassadors to Israel, 1988–2017|last=|first=|date=|website=[[J Street]]|format=PDF|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 20, 2017}} and his [[Juris Doctor|law degree]] from [[New York University School of Law]], graduating in 1981.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kasowitz.com/david-m-friedman/|title=David M. Friedman|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 21, 2017}} He has been a member of the [[New York State Bar Association]] since 1982. ==Legal and philanthropic career== In 1994, he left the now-defunct law firm [[Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon]] to form the bankruptcy practice at [[Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman|Kasowitz, Hoff, Benson & Torres]].{{cite web |title=President-Elect Donald J. Trump Nominates David Friedman as U.S. Ambassador to Israel|url=https://greatagain.gov/president-elect-donald-j-trump-nominates-david-friedman-as-u-s-ambassador-to-israel-d563ae2e0034#.mexqcoqzq |website=GreatAgain.gov|accessdate=December 16, 2016 |date=December 15, 2016}}{{Cite magazine|last=Amon|first=Elizabeth|date=August 2004|title=Fast Rise to the Top|url=http://www.kasowitz.com/files/FastRise-NoWhitePage.pdf|format=PDF|magazine=[[The American Lawyer]]|access-date=March 18, 2017|location=New York City}} Friedman was promoted to name partner in 1995, and the firm was renamed Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman.{{Cite news|url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/19950501/SUB/505010712/profiles-executive-moves|title=Profiles/Executive Moves|last=Feliciano|first=Carmen|date=May 1, 1995|work=[[Crain Communications|Crain's New York Business]]|access-date=March 18, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} As the head of the creditors' rights and bankruptcy practice group, Friedman advised and represented [[Donald Trump]] and [[The Trump Organization]] in bankruptcies involving his [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]] casinos.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trump-picks-a-supporter-of-west-bank-settlements-for-ambassador-to-israel/2016/12/15/1a50c03c-c32e-11e6-9a51-cd56ea1c2bb7_story.html|title=Trump picks a supporter of West Bank settlements for ambassador to Israel|last=DeYoung|first=Karen|date=December 15, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=December 26, 2016}} Friedman volunteered to head American Friends of Bet El Institutions,{{Cite news|url=http://forward.com/news/israel/359902/inside-the-west-bank-settlement-that-trumps-envoy-david-friedman-loves-best/|title=Inside the West Bank Settlement That Trump's Envoy David Friedman Loves Best|last=Zeveloff|first=Naomi|date=January 15, 2017|work=[[The Forward]]|access-date=May 6, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} an organization that advocates against a [[two-state solution]] to the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]] and provides around $2 million per year to the Israeli settlement [[Beit El|Bet El]].{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.759434|title=Trump Taps David Friedman as U.S. Ambassador to Israel|date=December 16, 2016|work=[[Haaretz]]|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-1.759484|title=Fund Headed by Trump's Israel Ambassador Pumped Tens of Millions Into West Bank Settlement|last=Maltz|first=Judy|date=December 16, 2016|work=[[Haaretz]]|access-date=March 17, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes}} The organization also received donations from the family foundation of [[Jared Kushner]], Trump's son-in-law. In 1999, Friedman dedicated the Friedman Faculty House.{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-1.771981|title=Building Dedicated by Trump's Israel Envoy Was Constructed Illegally on Palestinian Land|last=Maltz|first=Judy|date=February 15, 2017|work=[[Haaretz]]|access-date=May 6, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes}} The settlement runs the Israeli newspaper ''Arutz Sheva'', where Friedman is a columnist.{{Cite news|url=http://forward.com/news/357523/david-friedman-does-more-than-write-for-far-right-news-site/|title=David Friedman Does More Than Write for Far-Right News Site|last=Nathan-Kazis|first=Josh|date=December 19, 2016|work=[[The Forward]]|access-date=March 20, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} In his writings and statements, Friedman repeatedly argued in support of Israeli settlements, declaring them legal.{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/12/david-friedman-trump-embassy-israel/510905/|title=Trump's Pick for Israel Ambassador Is No Diplomat|last=Graham|first=David A.|date=December 16, 2016|work=[[The Atlantic]]|accessdate=December 26, 2016}} He has also contributed to [[United Hatzalah]] ("united rescue"), an Israeli organization that provides emergency medical services, and [[Aleh Negev]], a village for disabled [[Negev Bedouin|Bedouin]] and Jewish people in southern Israel. ==Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign== Friedman advised Trump on Israel-related and Jewish issues during his [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]], co-chairing Trump's Israel Advisory Committee along with [[Jason D. Greenblatt]], an executive vice president for The Trump Organization.{{cite web |url=https://medium.com/@jgreenblatt/joint-statement-from-jason-dov-greenblatt-and-david-friedman-co-chairmen-of-the-israel-advisory-edc1ec50b7a8#.zbv6r8wyd |title=Joint Statement from Jason Dov Greenblatt and David Friedman, Co-Chairmen of the Israel Advisory Committee to Donald J. Trump |last1=Greenblatt |first1=Jason D. |last2=Friedman |first2=David |work=[[Medium (website)|Medium]] |date=November 2, 2016 |accessdate=December 24, 2016}} During the [[United States presidential election, 2016|presidential election]], he donated a total of $50,000 to the Trump campaign and the [[Republican National Committee]]. Four days prior to the election, Friedman and Greenblatt released a joint statement promising to move the [[Embassy of the United States, Tel Aviv|U.S. embassy]] in [[Tel Aviv]] to [[Jerusalem]], one of Trump's campaign promises.{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/videos/1.698482|title=WATCH: Trump Promises to Move U.S. Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem|last=|first=|date=January 20, 2016|work=[[Haaretz]]|access-date=March 17, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Other presidential candidates, including [[Bill Clinton]], [[George W. Bush]], and [[Hillary Clinton]],{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/us-news/1.763000|title=Republican Senators Introduce Bill to Move U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem|date=January 4, 2017|work=[[Haaretz]]|accessdate=January 24, 2017}} had also promised to move the embassy to Jerusalem during their campaigns.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/19/world/middleeast/jerusalem-us-embassy-trump.html|title=An Embassy in Jerusalem? Trump Promises, but So Did Predecessors|last=Baker|first=Peter|date=November 18, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=March 17, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Moving the embassy would be a significant departure from U.S. policy. Since the end of the [[Six-Day War]] in 1967, the U.S. officially maintained that Jerusalem's final status should be decided by direct negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians;{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2016/12/29/trumps-plan-to-move-the-u-s-embassy-to-jerusalem-could-help-the-peace-process/|title=Trump's plan to move the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem could help the peace process|date=December 29, 2016|last1=Elman|first1=Miriam F.|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=January 24, 2017}} it did not recognize Jerusalem as Israeli territory. Relocation would be in accordance with the [[Jerusalem Embassy Act]], passed by Congress in 1995, which required moving the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem by May 31, 1999. The executive branch has consistently waived implementation of the act, arguing it would have a negative impact on [[national security]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-us-embassy-jerusalem-232724|title=Will Trump move the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem?|last=Hanna|first=Andrew|date=December 15, 2016|work=[[Politico]]|access-date=March 17, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last2=Saba|first2=Yousef}} On June 1, 2017, in accordance with his predecessors, President Trump signed an executive order keeping the embassy in Tel Aviv instead of relocating it to Jerusalem.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/01/world/middleeast/israel-embassy-jerusalem-trump.html|title=Donald Trump Won't Move Embassy to Jerusalem, at Least for Now|last=Baker|first=Peter|date=June 1, 2017|access-date=July 24, 2017}} However, on December 6, 2017, President Trump reversed course and issued a "[https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/presidential-proclamation-recognizing-jerusalem-capital-state-israel-relocating-united-states-embassy-israel-jerusalem/ Presidential Proclamation] Recognizing Jerusalem as the Capital of the State of Israel and Relocating the United States Embassy to Israel to Jerusalem."https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/presidential-proclamation-recognizing-jerusalem-capital-state-israel-relocating-united-states-embassy-israel-jerusalem/ ==Nomination for U.S. Ambassador to Israel== === Reactions === On December 15, 2016, the [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump|transition team]] of President-elect Donald Trump announced that Friedman had been selected to be the nominee as the [[United States Ambassador to Israel]].{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4604739/david-friedman-jerusalem-jewish-israel/|title=Why Jerusalem Isn't Recognized as Israel's Capital|last=Samuelson|first=Kate|date=December 16, 2016|website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 17, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/trump-taps-adviser-david-friedman-to-be-us-ambassador-to-israel/|title=Trump taps adviser Friedman to be US ambassador to Israel|date=December 16, 2016|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last1=Cortellessa|first1=Eric|access-date=December 16, 2016}} Friedman's nomination was controversial; some [[American Jews|American Jewish]], [[Israel lobby in the United States|Israeli]], and [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] individuals and advocacy groups argued against his nomination. [[Saeb Erekat]], chief negotiator for the [[Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian Authority]], said that moving the U.S. embassy to Jerusalem and annexing West Bank settlements would lead to the "destruction of the peace process" and send the region down a path of "chaos, lawlessness, and extremism".{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/erekat-moving-us-embassy-to-jerusalem-will-destroy-peace-process/|title=Erekat: Moving US Embassy to Jerusalem will 'destroy peace process'|date=December 16, 2016|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|access-date=December 26, 2016}} Friedman had said in an interview for ''[[Haaretz]]'' during the campaign that Trump would be open to [[Israel]] annexing parts of the [[West Bank]].{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-1.726779|title=David Friedman: Trump Would Support Israeli Annexation of Parts of West Bank|last=Ravid|first=Barak|date=June 23, 2016|work=[[Haaretz]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=y|accessdate=December 26, 2016}} The U.S. has opposed [[Israeli settlement]]s in the West Bank since 1967.{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2016/12/undiplomatic-choice|title=An undiplomatic choice: Donald Trump picks a hardliner as ambassador to Israel|date=December 17, 2016|work=[[The Economist]]|author1=V.V.B.|accessdate=December 18, 2016}} The liberal advocacy organization [[J Street]] "vehemently opposed" Friedman's nomination.{{cite web |url=http://jstreet.org/press-releases/j-street-vehemently-opposes-nomination-david-friedman-us-ambassador-israel/ |title=J Street Vehemently Opposes Nomination of David Friedman as US Ambassador to Israel |work=[[J Street]] |date=December 16, 2016 |accessdate=December 26, 2016}} During the presidential campaign, Friedman had attacked J Street supporters, writing in ''Arutz Sheva'' in May 2016:
Are J Street supporters really as bad as [[Kapo (concentration camp)|kapos]]? The answer, actually, is no. They are far worse than kapos—Jews who turned in their fellow Jews in the Nazi death camps. The kapos faced extraordinary cruelty and who knows what any of us would have done under those circumstances to save a loved one? But J Street? They are just smug advocates of Israel's destruction delivered from the comfort of their secure American sofas—it's hard to imagine anyone worse.{{cite news|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/Articles/Article.aspx/18828|title=Read Peter Beinart and you'll vote Donald Trump|last=Friedman|first=David|date=May 6, 2016|work=[[Arutz Sheva]]|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}
When asked about his comments on J Street at the [[Center for Middle East Policy|Saban Forum]] in early December, Friedman had stood by his statements, saying that J Street supporters were "not Jewish, and they're not pro-Israel".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/15/us/politics/donald-trump-david-friedman-israel-ambassador.html|title=Trump Chooses Hard-Liner as Ambassador to Israel|last=Rosenberg|first=Matthew|date=December 15, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/liberal-jewish-orgs-rage-against-trumps-israel-ambassador-pick/|title=Liberal Jewish groups rage against Trump's Israel ambassador pick|date=December 16, 2016|last1=Cortellessa|first1=Eric|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|accessdate=December 17, 2016}} The advocacy organizations [[Americans for Peace Now]], [[Ameinu]], the [[Israel Policy Forum]], and the [[New Israel Fund]] also opposed the nomination.{{cite news |url=http://www.jta.org/2016/12/16/news-opinion/united-states/trumps-pick-for-israel-envoy-elates-hawks-worries-doves |title=Hawks hail Trump's nominee for ambassador to Israel, doves vow a fight |work=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]] |date=December 16, 2016 |accessdate=December 26, 2016}} Six [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] members of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], including Jewish representatives [[Jan Schakowsky]], [[Jerrold Nadler]], [[John Yarmuth]], and [[Steve Cohen]], urged their colleagues in the [[United States Senate|Senate]] to vote against Friedman.{{cite news |url=http://forward.com/news/national/357547/chuck-schumer-not-taking-sides-on-david-friedman-as-ambassador-to-israel/ |title=Chuck Schumer Not Taking Sides on David Friedman as Ambassador to Israel |last=Guttman |first=Nathan |work=[[The Forward]] |date=December 19, 2016 |access-date=December 26, 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://forward.com/fast-forward/357688/rep-steve-cohen-rejects-david-friedman-says-hes-no-fiddler/ |title=Rep. Steve Cohen Rejects David Friedman — Says He's No 'Fiddler' |last=Guttman |first=Nathan |work=[[The Forward]] |date=December 20, 2016 |access-date=December 26, 2016}} Five former United States Ambassadors to Israel – [[Thomas R. Pickering|Thomas Pickering]], [[William Caldwell Harrop|William Harrop]], [[Edward S. Walker Jr.|Edward Walker Jr.]], [[Daniel Kurtzer]], and [[James B. Cunningham|James Cunningham]] – signed a letter declaring Friedman unqualified.{{Cite news|url=https://apnews.com/c03016227ab7429b81ed3fb3b0a1ff67/trumps-pick-israel-ambassador-faces-rocky-confirmation|title=Trump's pick for Israel envoy goes on damage control|last=Lardner|first=Richard|date=February 16, 2017|work=[[Associated Press]]|access-date=May 8, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} Other Jewish and Israeli groups and individuals supported Friedman's nomination. Nathan Diament, executive director for public policy at the [[Orthodox Union]], commended Trump for the nomination as a change in the [[Israel–United States relations|relationship between Israel and the United States]] from the relationship under the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]].{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-israel-ambassador-david-friedman-232717 |title= Trump picks hard-line attorney as Israel envoy, angering Jewish left |last=Toosi |first= Nahal |work= [[Politico]] |date=December 15, 2016 |access-date= December 29, 2016}} [[Morton Klein]], president of the [[Zionist Organization of America]], said Friedman "has the potential to be the greatest US Ambassador to Israel ever". The [[Republican Jewish Coalition]] and Rabbi [[Yechiel Eckstein]], founder and president of the [[International Fellowship of Christians and Jews]], both supported the nomination. Israeli politicians [[Tzipi Hotovely]], the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Israel)|Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs]], [[Dani Dayan]], the [[Consul (representative)|Consul General]] of Israel in New York, and [[Ministry of Education (Israel)|Minister of Education]] [[Naftali Bennett]] all praised Friedman and welcomed his nomination.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/in-trumps-pick-for-ambassador-to-israel-right-wing-israelis-see-a-friend/2016/12/16/3cbe690b-04db-4587-bea5-1f75fffb0e67_story.html|title=Israel says there's never been a more right-wing U.S. ambassador than Trump's pick|last=Booth|first=William|date=December 16, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=March 21, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last2=Eglash|first2=Ruth}} The [[Yesha Council]], the umbrella organization governing West Bank settlements, also supported the nomination, saying Friedman had a "deep love for all of the land and people of Israel, including those in [[Judea and Samaria Area|Judea and Samaria]]," the Biblical names of the area of land which is referred to internationally as the West Bank. === Senate confirmation === [[File:David Friedman sworn in.jpg|thumb|275x275px|David Friedman is sworn in by Vice President [[Mike Pence]].]] Friedman's confirmation hearing was held on February 16, 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/16/politics/david-friedman-trump-israel-ambassador-confirmation-hearing/|title=Senate grills US envoy to Israel pick after Trump scraps two-state policy|last=Gaouette|first=Nicole|date=February 16, 2017|work=[[CNN]]|access-date=March 17, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last2=Labott|first2=Elise}} The hearing was contentious; protesters from [[American Muslims for Palestine|Americans Muslims for Palestine]] and the Jewish group [[IfNotNow (organization)|IfNotNow]] were arrested after interrupting the proceedings several times.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/16/us/politics/david-friedman-trump-nominee-israel-envoy-apologizes.html|title=Trump's Nominee for Israel Envoy Apologizes for 'Hurtful Words'|last=Huetteman|first=Emmarie|date=February 16, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=March 22, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/protest-friedman-unequal-punishment_us_58f8f6a3e4b00fa7de123264|title=6 Protesters Were Arrested. Only The 2 Arab Muslims Face Misdemeanor Charges.|last=Schulberg|first=Jessica|date=April 20, 2017|work=[[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]|access-date=June 22, 2017|language=en-US}} Friedman said he believed a two-state solution is the best way to resolve the conflict. He had previously questioned the need for it, stating as a representative for the Trump campaign, "a two-state solution is not a priority ... A two-state solution is a way, but it's not the only way."{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/what-a-donald-trump-presidency-would-mean-for-israel/|title=What a Trump presidency would mean for Israel|last=Cortellessa|first=Eric|date=November 6, 2016|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|accessdate=December 26, 2016}} He had also called it a "scam" and a "damaging anachronism" in a February 2016 column for ''Arutz Sheva''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/Articles/Article.aspx/18368|title=End the two-state narrative|last=Friedman|first=David|date=October 2, 2016|work=[[Arutz Sheva]]|access-date=March 22, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/16/trumps-middle-east-policy-chaos-un-ambassador-says-us-absolutely/|title=Trump's Middle East policy in chaos as UN ambassador says US 'absolutely' supports two-state solution|last=Sanchez|first=Raf|date=February 16, 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|access-date=March 22, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} He also agreed to sell off his business interests in the region and end his support for the expansion of Israeli settlements. He apologized for his past language towards J Street, maintaining his differences of opinion with the organization.{{Cite news|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/c03016227ab7429b81ed3fb3b0a1ff67/trumps-pick-israel-ambassador-faces-rocky-confirmation|title=Trump's pick for Israel envoy goes on damage control|last=Lardner|first=Richard|date=February 16, 2017|work=[[Associated Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Yael Patir, the Israel director of J Street, did not accept the apology.{{Cite news|url=http://www.jta.org/2017/02/17/news-opinion/israel-middle-east/j-street-israel-boss-rejects-david-friedmans-remorse-for-kapos-remark|title=J Street Israel boss rejects David Friedman's remorse for 'kapos' remark|last=|first=|date=February 17, 2017|work=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]|access-date=March 22, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Several Democratic members of the [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] criticized Friedman's fitness for the position, while the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] members generally expressed their support. On March 9, 2017, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved his nomination in a 12–9 vote. All Republicans voted in favor, along with Democrat [[Bob Menendez]] from [[New Jersey]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2017/03/09/democrats-not-expected-to-support-trump-pick-for-ambassador-to-israel/|title=Trump's pick for Israeli ambassador clears key Senate panel|last=Demirjian|first=Karoun|date=March 9, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=March 22, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Friedman was officially confirmed on March 23.{{Cite web|author=David Rosenberg|date=March 23, 2017|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/227204|title=It's final: David Friedman confirmed as Ambassador to Israel|website=Israel National News|access-date=August 27, 2017}} All Democratic and independent senators except Bob Menendez and [[Joe Manchin]], from [[West Virginia]], voted against him. 50 out of 52 Republican senators voted for him; two Republicans did not vote.{{Cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=115&session=1&vote=00096|title=On the Nomination (Confirmation David Friedman, of New York, to be Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the United States of America to Israel)|last=|first=|date=March 23, 2017|website=[[United States Senate]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 23, 2017}} On March 29, Vice President [[Mike Pence]] officially administered the [[oath of office]], swearing in Friedman.{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/us-news/.premium-1.780361|title=David Friedman, Staunch Supporter of the Settlements, Sworn in as U.S. Ambassador to Israel|last=Tibon|first=Amir|date=March 30, 2017|work=[[Haaretz]]|access-date=March 29, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} He succeeded Leslie Tsou, who served as the interim [[chargé d'affaires]] after [[Daniel B. Shapiro|Daniel Shapiro]] left the position on January 20.{{Cite web|url=https://il.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/our-ambassador/|title=Charge d'Affaires Leslie M. Tsou|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Embassy of the United States, Tel Aviv|U.S. Embassy in Israel]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 24, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-1.763440|title=Outgoing U.S. Envoy Dan Shapiro to Stay in Israel After Trump Takes Office|last=Sommer|first=Allison Kaplan|date=January 7, 2017|work=[[Haaretz]]|access-date=March 24, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} ==Ambassadorship== [[File:Donald Trump with Reuven Rivlin in Israel 2017 (7).jpg|300px|thumb|David Friedman, fourth from right in the front row of in Beit HaNassi (the President's Residence of Israel), during Donald Trump's visit to Israel, May 2017]] Friedman became the U.S. ambassador to Israel on May 15, 2017 when he presented his credentials to Israeli President [[Reuven Rivlin]].{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/david-friedman-officially-takes-up-post-as-trumps-israel-envoy/ |title=David Friedman officially takes up post as Trump's Israel envoy |last=Ahren |first=Raphael |date=May 16, 2017 |work=[[The Times of Israel]] |accessdate=July 27, 2017}} ==Personal life== Friedman is an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jew]] and is fluent in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]. He has been married to his wife, Tammy Deborah Sand, since 1981. They have five children and seven grandchildren.{{cite news |url=http://www.foreign.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/021617_Friedman_Testimony.pdf |title=Statement of David M. Friedman, of New York, Nominee to be Ambassador to Israel |last=Friedman |first=David M. |date=February 16, 2017 |accessdate=February 17, 2017 |work=[[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations]] |format=PDF}} Friedman's daughter, Talia Friedman, immigrated to Israel and officially became an Israeli citizen on August 15, 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.jta.org/2017/08/15/news-opinion/israel-middle-east/daughter-of-us-ambassador-david-friedman-immigrates-to-israel|title=Daughter of US Ambassador David Friedman immigrates to Israel|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en-us}} In 1984, Friedman met President [[Ronald Reagan]] when Reagan visited Temple Hillel. Reagan was the first sitting president since [[George Washington]] to visit a synagogue.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1984/10/27/reagan-courts-jews-environmentalists/9d7784c0-38ec-43e6-a785-353bef07e2f2/|title=Reagan Courts Jews, Environmentalists|last=Cannon|first=Lou|date=October 27, 1984|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=March 21, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/27/nyregion/reagan-woos-jewish-voters-on-li-visit.html|title=Reagan Woos Jewish Voters on L.I. Visit|last=Gruson|first=Lindsey|date=October 27, 1984|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=March 21, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Friedman became friends with [[Donald Trump]] in 2005, after Trump paid him a condolence call during his sitting [[Shiva (Judaism)|shiva]] for his father. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|David M. Friedman}} * [https://www.c-span.org/person/?davidfriedman06 Appearances] on [[C-SPAN]] {{s-start}} {{s-dip}} {{s-bef|before=[[Daniel B. Shapiro|Dan Shapiro]]}} {{s-ttl|title = [[United States Ambassador to Israel]]|years=2017–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{US Ambassadors to Israel}} {{Portal bar|Government of the United States|Biography}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Friedman, David M.}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:20th-century American lawyers]] [[Category:21st-century American lawyers]] [[Category:21st-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the United States to Israel]] [[Category:American columnists]] [[Category:American foreign policy writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American Orthodox Jews]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016]] [[Category:Jewish American attorneys]] [[Category:Jewish American writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:New York (state) lawyers]] [[Category:New York (state) Republicans]] [[Category:New York University School of Law alumni]] [[Category:People associated with the United States presidential election, 2016]] [[Category:People from North Woodmere, New York]] [[Category:Trump administration personnel]] [[Category:The Trump Organization employees]] [[Category:Writers from New York (state)]] [[Category:Kasowitz Benson Torres people]]

{{Infobox person | name = Tina Fontaine | image = Tina Fontaine Sep 2013 school photograph.png | alt = see caption | caption = September 2013 school photograph of Fontaine | birth_name = Tina Michelle Fontaine | birth_date = {{Birth date|1999|01|01}} | birth_place = [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]], Canada | disappeared_date = {{disappeared date and age|2014|08|08|1999|01|01}} | disappeared_place = [[Downtown Winnipeg|Downtown Winnipeg, Manitoba]], Canada | death_date = {{Circa}} {{Death date and age|2014|08|10|1999|01|01}} | death_place = | body_discovered = [[Red River of the North|Red River]], Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada | resting_place = [[Sagkeeng First Nation]], Manitoba, Canada | resting_place_coordinates = }} '''Tina Michelle Fontaine''' (January 1, 1999 – {{Circa|August 10, 2014}})<ref>{{cite news |last1= Blaze Baum |first1= Kathryn |title= How many more women will it take, asks family of slain teen Tina Fontaine |url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/how-many-more-women-will-it-take-asks-aunt-of-slain-teen-tina-fontaine/article20184699/ |accessdate= August 7, 2016 |work= The Globe and Mail |date= August 22, 2014}}</ref> was a First Nations (Indigenous) girl who died in August 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.winnipegsun.com/2015/12/11/arrest-in-tina-fontaine-homicide |work= Winnipeg Sun |date= 11 December 2015 |title= Party-house acquaintance, 53, arrested in murder of Tina Fontaine |author= Dawkins, Glen}}</ref> Her case is considered among the high number of [[missing and murdered Indigenous women]] of Canada. Her death renewed calls by activists for the government to conduct a national inquiry into the issue.
Identified early as a suspect, Raymond Joseph Cormier was charged in December 2015 with her murder.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/alleged-murderer-was-a-prime-suspect-not-long-after-tina-fontaines-death/article27738326/ |title= Alleged murderer was a prime suspect not long after Tina Fontaine's death |author= Renata D'Aliesio, Joe Friesen and Stephanie Chambers |work= The Globe and Mail |date=11 December 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://globalnews.ca/news/2396052/what-we-know-about-tina-fontaines-accused-killer-raymond-cormier/ |title= What we know about Tina Fontaine's accused killer, Raymond Cormier |author= Steele, Heather |date=11 December 2015 |work= Global News}}</ref> Cormier was [[Acquittal|acquitted]] by a jury in February 2018.<ref name=":1" /> Under new Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] in 2015, the government committed to creating an independent national inquiry into the issue of murders and violence against Indigenous women, which was started in 2017.
==Background==
Fontaine was raised by her great-aunt for most of her life; they lived on the [[Sagkeeng First Nation]], 121 km northeast [[Winnipeg]], Manitoba.
Her father, Eugene, had been beaten to death in 2011. His two assailants received manslaughter convictions. Fontaine's aunt recalled that her father's violent death deeply affected the girl. "She was very hurt, very lost. That's when she drifted away."<ref name="Nationalpost">{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/after-her-father-was-beaten-to-death-tina-fontaine-went-astray-she-only-lasted-two-months-in-winnipeg |title= After her father was beaten to death, Tina Fontaine went astray: 'She only lasted two months in Winnipeg' |author=Lambert, Stephen |work= National Post |date= 16 October 2014}}</ref> She went to Winnipeg.
==Disappearances and body discovery==
Fontaine was in the care of Manitoba [[Child and Family Services|Child and Family Services (CFS)]] when she was reported missing to [[Winnipeg Police Service]] on July 31, 2014.<ref name="Timeline 1">{{cite news|last1=Dawkins|first1=Glen|title=Party-house acquaintance, 53, arrested in murder of Tina Fontaine|url=http://www.winnipegsun.com/2015/12/11/arrest-in-tina-fontaine-homicide|accessdate=September 8, 2016|date=December 11, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Timeline 2">{{cite news|title=Some events leading up to the arrest of a man in the death of Tina Fontaine|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/canada/some-events-leading-up-to-the-arrest-of-a-man-in-the-death-of-tina-fontaine--361603241.html|accessdate=September 8, 2016|work=The Canadian Press|date=December 11, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151213212547/http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/canada/some-events-leading-up-to-the-arrest-of-a-man-in-the-death-of-tina-fontaine--361603241.html|archivedate=December 13, 2015}}</ref> Her aunt, Lana, later said that Fontaine had stayed with her during the [[Public holidays in Canada|August long weekend]] (August 1–3).<ref name="Timeline 1"/> On August 5, Fontaine telephoned her CFS worker and was subsequently picked up by members of CFS and Winnipeg Police Service.<ref name="Timeline 1"/> What happened to Fontaine between August 5 and August 8 is unclear, but she remained a missing youth.<ref name="Timeline 1"/> At 3 a.m. on August 8, police Constables Brock Jansen and Craig Houle encountered her in a truck with an allegedly drunk driver, but did not take her into custody, even though she was known to be missing.<ref name="Timeline 1"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Tina Fontaine died because police, CFS failed her, family says|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/tina-fontaine-died-because-police-cfs-failed-her-family-says-1.2777606|accessdate=September 8, 2016|work=cbc.ca|date=September 25, 2014}}</ref>
At 4 a.m., she was found passed out in an alleyway near Ellice Avenue and was escorted to hospital and treated before being checked into the Best Western Charterhouse hotel, which she soon left.<ref name="Timeline 1" /> She was reported missing again on August 9.<ref name="CBC1">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/tina-fontaine-homicide-arrest-winnipeg-1.3361103|title=Raymond Cormier, 53, charged with murder in Tina Fontaine death|date=11 December 2015|publisher=CBC}}</ref>
At around 1:30 p.m. on August 17, a body was found wrapped in plastic and a duvet cover and weighed down with rocks in the [[Red River of the North|Red River]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4043492/tina-fontaine-march-mmiwg-inquiry/|publisher=Global|title=How the tragic death of Tina Fontaine helped spark the MMIWG inquiry|author=Katie Dangerfield|date=23 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="CBC1" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/tina-fontaine-15-found-in-bag-in-red-river-1.2739141|title=Tina Fontaine, 15, found in bag in Red River|date=August 17, 2014|work=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="STAR">{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2015/12/11/winnipeg-police-make-arrest-in-case-of-tina-fontaine.html|title=Winnipeg police make arrest in case of Tina Fontaine|date=11 December 2015|work=Toronto Star}}</ref> The body was identified as that of Fontaine the following day.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/body-of-15-year-old-girl-found-in-winnipeg-s-red-river-1.1964990|title=Body of 15-year-old girl found in Winnipeg's Red River|last=Puxley|first=Chinta|date=August 18, 2014|work=ctvnews.ca|last2=Lambert|first2=Steve|access-date=August 22, 2016|via=}}</ref> Police believe she had died on or around August 10.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/accused-in-tina-fontaine-killing-to-fight-charges-lawyer-says/article27750526/|title=Accused in Tina Fontaine killing had violent history, documents reveal|last=|first=|date=December 14, 2015|work=theglobeandmail.com|access-date=September 8, 2016|via=}}</ref>
A young woman who claimed to have been with Fontaine shortly before she disappeared told [[CBC News]] of events that happened in the hours leading up to her disappearance. Identified by CBC News as "Katrina", she said that after she met Fontaine between 10 and 11 p.m. on August 7, they went to eat at the Macdonald Youth Services emergency shelter at around 2:30 a.m.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/tina-fontaine-last-seen-leaving-with-man-in-west-end-says-friend-1.2778160|title=Tina Fontaine last seen leaving with man in West End, says friend|last=|first=|date=September 25, 2014|work=cbc.ca|access-date=September 8, 2016|via=}}</ref> Believing Fontaine was drunk, Katrina requested the shelter staff keep her overnight, but Fontaine refused to stay, and refused to give her name.<ref name=":0" /> After seeing her get into the truck and the encounter with the police, Katrina lost contact with Fontaine until around 8 p.m., after Fontaine left the hotel where she was staying.<ref name=":0" /> At around 3 a.m. the following morning, the two young women were approached on Ellice Avenue by a man who offered Fontaine money to perform a sex act.<ref name=":0" /> She accepted and left with the man. Katrina followed them but lost sight of the two in the dark.<ref name=":0" />
==Aftermath==
In response to Fontaine's death, the [[Canadian Human Rights Commission]] requested a full inquiry into the number of [[missing and murdered Indigenous women]] in Canada. The RCMP already had such a study underway, which was completed in 2014. Acting chief commissioner David Langtry wrote, "Once again our hearts are filled with grief and sadness as we mourn the brutal and senseless murder of an Aboriginal girl. Tina must not disappear into the oblivion of statistics."<ref name="APTN1">{{cite web |url= http://aptn.ca/news/2014/08/19/tina-fontaines-murder-renews-call-inquiry-missing-murdered-indigenous-women/ |title= Tina Fontaine’s murder renews call for inquiry into missing, murdered Indigenous women |publisher=APTN |date= 19 August 2014}}</ref>
In response to the death, a volunteer group known as Drag the Red was formed. They have begun to regularly drag portions of the [[Red River of the North|Red River]], in order to find bodies or evidence.<ref name="Vice1">{{cite web |url= https://www.vice.com/video/drag-the-red |title= Drag the Red |publisher= Vice Media |date=2016}}</ref> Additionally, a local Inuit woman, Holly Jarrett, has started social media campaigns: the [[AmINext|#AmINext]] hashtag and a [[Change.org]] petition in response to Fontaine's death. The hashtag campaign called for a national inquiry and allowed Indigenous women to express their feelings about the issue of [[missing and murdered Indigenous women]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Burman|first=Jenny|date=2016-04-28|title=Multicultural Feeling, Feminist Rage, Indigenous Refusal|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1532708616638693|journal=Cultural Studies ↔ Critical Methodologies|language=en|volume=16|issue=4|pages=361–372|doi=10.1177/1532708616638693}}</ref>
Fontaine was buried on [[Sagkeeng First Nation]] next to her father. A memorial was placed at the site on the first anniversary of the discovery of her body at the Red River.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/memorial-for-tina-fontaine-unveiled-one-year-after-teen-s-body-pulled-from-red-river-1.2520010|title=Memorial for Tina Fontaine unveiled one year after teen's body pulled from Red River|date=August 17, 2015|work=CTV Winnipeg|last1=Miljure|first1=Ben|accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref>
Raymond Joseph Cormier was charged with Fontaine's murder in December 2015.<ref name="CBC1" /><ref name="CTV">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/murder-charge-laid-in-death-of-tina-fontaine-1.2696774|title=Murder charge laid in death of Tina Fontaine|date=11 December 2015|publisher=CTV}}</ref>
With the change in government, in December 2016 Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced that a national inquiry titled "Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls" would be undertaken. Five independent commissioners were appointed, and commissioners and staff began to consult with families, activist organizations, and others about how to structure the inquiry.
Constables Jansen and Houle were suspended for their actions and left the police force.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/security-video-of-tina-fontaine-captured-days-before-she-was-killed-shown-in-court/article37872202/|title=Security video of Tina Fontaine captured days before she was killed shown in court|access-date=2018-02-07}}</ref>
On February 28, 2018, the [[Justice for our Stolen Children Camp]] was set up on Wascana Park in Regina in response to the death of Tina Fontaine and [[Death of Colten Boushie|Colten Boushie]].<ref name=ReginaPost15June2018>{{cite web|url=http://leaderpost.com/news/local-news/after-108-days-justice-for-our-stolen-children-camp-comes-down|title=After 108 days, Justice For Our Stolen Children camp comes down|publisher=Regina Leader-Post|date=15 June 2018|access-date=23 June 2018}}</ref>
In March 2018, political activist Indygo Arscott held a rally outside [[Toronto City Hall]] to voice outrage in memory of Fontaine due to Cormier being found not guilty of the crime.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thevarsity.ca/2018/03/05/justice-for-tina-fontaine-rally-held-at-nathan-phillips-square/|title="Justice for Tina Fontaine" rally held at Nathan Phillips Square|last=Banares |first=Ilya |date=March 5, 2018 |access-date=July 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/indigenous/thousands-gather-in-memory-of-tina-fontaine-in-toronto-1.4561309|title=Thousands gather in memory of Tina Fontaine in Toronto|last=Johnson |first=Rhiannon |date=March 3, 2018 |access-date=July 27, 2018}}</ref>
== Trial == The trial began January 29, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3993129/trial-begins-for-tina-fontaines-accused-killer/|title=Trial begins for Tina Fontaine’s accused killer|work=Global News|access-date=2018-02-01}}</ref> Raymond Cormier pled not guilty to second degree murder charges.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/tina-fontaine-s-cause-of-death-remains-undetermined-pathologist-tells-cormier-trial-1.3783542|title=Tina Fontaine's cause of death remains undetermined: pathologist tells Cormier trial|date=2018-01-31|work=Winnipeg|access-date=2018-02-01}}</ref> The government did not introduce any forensic evidence or eyewitnesses directly linking Cormier to Tina's death.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/raymond-cormier-tina-fontaine-trial-1.4511959|title=No DNA evidence linking Raymond Cormier to Tina Fontaine, court hears|work=CBC News Manitoba|access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref> At the time of the trial, the cause of death remained undetermined. Cormier's lawyers argued that without a determination on the cause of death, it cannot be known for certain that Tina died as a result of an unlawful act, and Cormier should be acquitted "on that [argument] alone."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/raymond-cormier-trial-verdict-tina-fontaine-1.4542319|title=Jury finds Raymond Cormier not guilty in death of Tina Fontaine|work=CBC News Manitoba|access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref> He was found not guilty on February 22, 2018.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/raymond-cormier-trial-verdict-tina-fontaine-1.4542319|title=Jury finds Raymond Cormier not guilty in death of Tina Fontaine|date=2018-02-22|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02n93d9 BBC Assignment: Canada’s Red River Murders]

revision.text:
{{for|the rugby league footballer of the 1920s and 1930s for Cumberland, and Oldham|Fred Ashworth}} {{Infobox military person |name = Frederick Lincoln Ashworth |birth_date = {{birth date|df=y|1912|1|24}} |death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|2005|12|3|1912|1|24}} |birth_place = [[Beverly, Massachusetts]] |death_place = [[Phoenix, Arizona]] |image = Frederick L. Ashworth.JPG |image_size = 250 |caption = |nickname = "Dick" |allegiance={{flag|United States of America}} |branch = [[Image:United States Department of the Navy Seal.svg|25px]] [[United States Navy]] |serviceyears = 1933-1968 |servicenumber = 0-72354 |rank = [[File:US-O9 insignia.svg|40px]] [[Vice admiral (United States)|Vice Admiral]] |commands= [[United States Sixth Fleet|Sixth Fleet]] |battles = [[World War II]]: * [[Battle of New Georgia]] * [[Gilbert and Marshall Islands campaign]] * [[Bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] * [[Operation Crossroads]] |awards = [[Navy Distinguished Service Medal|Distinguished Service Medal]] (2)
[[Silver Star]]
[[Legion of Merit]] (2)
[[Bronze Star Medal]] }} '''Frederick Lincoln '''"'''Dick'''"''' Ashworth''' (24 January 1912 – 3 December 2005) was a [[United States Navy]] officer who served as the weaponeer on the [[B-29]] ''[[Bockscar]]'' that dropped a [[Fat Man]] [[atomic bomb]] on [[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki, Japan]] on 9 August 1945 during [[World War II]]. A 1933 graduate of the [[United States Naval Academy]] at [[Annapolis, Maryland]], Ashworth commanded [[VFA-115|Torpedo Squadron Eleven (VT-11)]], a [[Grumman TBF Avenger]] unit based on [[Guadalcanal]] that flew patrol, search, spotting, strike, and night mine-laying missions in support of the [[New Georgia Campaign]] in the [[Solomon Islands]]. He was awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] for heroism while carrying out these missions. He then participated in the [[Gilbert and Marshall Islands campaign]] as aviation officer on the staff of [[Vice Admiral (United States)|Vice Admiral]] [[Richmond K. Turner]]'s V Amphibious Force. Rotated back to the United States in June 1944, Ashworth became senior naval aviator at the [[Naval Surface Warfare Center Dahlgren Division|Naval Proving Ground]] in [[Dahlgren, Virginia]]. In November 1944 he was assigned to the [[Manhattan Project]], and supervised the testing of [[atomic bomb]] components at [[Wendover Air Force Base|Wendover]]. In February 1945, he travelled to [[Guam]], where he met [[Fleet admiral (United States)|Fleet Admiral]] [[Chester Nimitz]], and selected [[Tinian]] as a base of operations for the [[509th Composite Group]]. After the war he selected [[Bikini Atoll]] as the site for [[Operation Crossroads]]. Remaining in the navy after the war, Ashworth rose to the rank of vice admiral in May 1966. He was [[Commandant of Midshipmen]] at the United States Naval Academy in 1958, and served as commander of the [[United States Sixth Fleet]] from September 1966 to April 1967. He retired from the navy in 1968, and died in 2005. ==Early life== Frederick Lincoln "Dick" Ashworth was born in [[Beverly, Massachusetts]] on 24 January 1912, the third child of Fred Ashworth, who worked as a draughtsman and tool designer for the United Shoe Machinery Corporation, and his wife Minnie. He had two older brothers, Phil and Bentley. Phil graduated from the [[United States Naval Academy]] at [[Annapolis, Maryland]], in 1931, but died in a 1938 seaplane crash off [[Pearl Harbor]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lanl.gov/news/index.php?fuseaction=home.story&story_id=7619 |title=Naval aviator Ashworth dies in Santa Fe |author=Steve Sandoval |date=7 December 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605233450/http://www.lanl.gov/news/index.php?fuseaction=home.story&story_id=7619 |archivedate=5 June 2011 |publisher=[[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] }}{{cite web |url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/beverly/news/opinions/x21534932 |title=From Beverly to Nagasaki: The "Dick" Ashworth story |author=Stephen P. Hall |date=12 December 2005 |publisher= |accessdate=14 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216173517/http://www.wickedlocal.com/beverly/news/opinions/x21534932 |archivedate=16 December 2013 |df= }} The family moved to a farmhouse in [[Wenham, Massachusetts]], in 1918. Ashworth attended Center School in Wenham, and then, as Wenham had no high school of its own, [[Beverly High School]], where he was president of the Student Council. Too young and small for football, he participated in track and cross country running. He graduated in 1928, and then entered [[Dartmouth College]].{{cite web |url=http://www.salemnews.com/local/x2064744057/Beverly-natives-role-in-atomic-bomb-overlooked |title=Beverly native's role in atomic bomb overlooked |author=Paul Leighton |date=9 August 2010 }} Ashworth decided that he wanted to go to Annapolis like his brother. He sat and passed the examinations for an appointment from his local Congressman, but did not secure one of the Congressman's two appointments. However, in August 1929, he was informed that one of the Congressman's appointments had been rejected for defective teeth. Ashworth then entered Annapolis. He graduated 134th in the class of 1933, and was commissioned as an [[Ensign (rank)|ensign]]. ==Naval career== ===Solomon Islands=== [[File:TBF-1 VT-11 Guadalcanal May1943.jpg|thumb|right|Ashworth (right) with VT-11 in the Solomon Islands]] Ashworth's first posting was to the [[battleship]] {{USS|West Virginia|BB-48|6}}. He married Nathalie Louise (Nan) Bliss from [[Peabody, Massachusetts]] in June 1935. They had three sons: Frederick Jr., David and Stephen. In 1936, he was accepted for aviator training, and reported to the [[Pensacola Naval Air Station]]. He then held various positions including air photography officer for the [[United States Pacific Fleet]]. In 1939, he volunteered for postgraduate study at Annapolis as an aviation ordinance engineer. By the time Ashworth graduated in June 1942, the United States had entered [[World War II]]. He became commander of [[VFA-115|Torpedo Squadron Eleven (VT-11)]], a [[Grumman TBF Avenger]] unit based on [[Guadalcanal]]. VT-11 pilots flew patrol, search, spotting, strike, and night mine-laying missions in support of the [[New Georgia Campaign]] in the [[Solomon Islands]]. Ashworth was awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] and the [[Bronze Star Medal]].{{cite web |url=http://skyraider.org/skyassn/skysqdhist/va115.pdf |accessdate=14 December 2013 |title=Dictionary of American naval aviation squadrons |first=Roy A. |last=Grossnick |publisher=Naval Historical Center |location=Washington, D.C.|year=1995 |pp=181–183 |isbn= 9780160452963 |oclc=31242871 }} His Distinguished Flying Cross citation read: {{quote|The President of the United States of America takes pleasure in presenting the Distinguished Flying Cross to Lieutenant Commander Frederick Lincoln Ashworth (NSN: 0-72354), United States Navy, for heroism and extraordinary achievement while participating in aerial flight in aerial attacks as the commanding officer of a Torpedo Bomber Squadron against Japanese shore installations and shipping in the Solomon Islands area during the period from 26 April to 12 July 1943. During the nights of 18, 20 and 23 May, Lieutenant Commander Ashworth led his squadron in mine laying missions in the Kahili-Shortland area, South Bougainville. It was necessary that level flight at one thousand feet, constant speed and steady course be maintained for periods of time up to one and one-half minutes duration approximately one thousand yards from heavily-fortified Japanese positions. His plane made the longest run on each mission and despite illumination by a concentration of enemy searchlights and heavy enemy anti-aircraft fire these extremely hazardous missions were carried out effectively. He led two night anti-shipping missions in the same area on the nights of 15 and 28 May 1943. On the night of 15 May, he personally by aggressive, daring, and exceptionally well planned attack scored a confirmed hit on an enemy cargo ship. Lieutenant Commander Ashworth also participated in a daylight shipping raid in the same area which was pressed home despite considerable enemy aircraft opposition. He led his squadron in seven successful and highly effective bombing raids against Munda, two against Rekata Bay, and one against Vila, all of which were strongly defended enemy positions. His conduct was in keeping with the highest traditions of the United States Naval Service.{{cite web |publisher=Military Times |title=Valor awards for Frederick Lincoln Ashworth |accessdate=14 December 2013 |url=http://projects.militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=55199 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214121313/http://projects.militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=55199 |archivedate=14 December 2013 |df= }}}} In September 1943, Ashworth was posted to the staff of [[Vice Admiral (United States)|Vice Admiral]] [[Richmond K. Turner]]'s V Amphibious Force as aviation officer. In this capacity he served in the [[Gilbert and Marshall Islands campaign]].{{cite book |title=Amphibians Came to Conquer: the Story of Admiral Richmond Kelly Turner |first=George C. |last=Dyer |location=Washington, DC |publisher=U.S. Dept. of the Navy |year=1972 |oclc=476880 |pp=606, 863}} ===Project Alberta=== In June 1944, Ashworth was rotated back to the United States, where he became senior naval aviator at the [[Naval Surface Warfare Center Dahlgren Division|Naval Proving Ground]] in [[Dahlgren, Virginia]]. In November he was assigned to the [[Manhattan Project]]. He later recalled that {{quote|My job at [[Los Alamos laboratory|Los Alamos]] was to supervise and coordinate the work of engineers in the testing at [[Wendover Air Force Base|Wendover]] of bomb components then being developed at Los Alamos. I don't know who though that the Los Alamos people needed supervising and coordinating by a young commander, US Navy. But I was able to run interference for them with the base commander, Colonel Heflin, and I think in useful ways. That wasn't difficult either because Colonel Heflin was one fine Air Force officer.{{cite book | last = Krauss | first=Robert | last2 = Krauss | first2 = Amelia | title=The 509th Remembered: A History of the 509th Composite Group as Told by the Veterans Themselves | publisher=509th Press | location = Buchanan, Michigan | isbn= 0-923568-66-2 | oclc = 59148135 | year=2005 |pp=15–20 }}}} Holding the rank of commander, he became Director of Operations for [[Project Alberta]], the portion of the [[Manhattan Project]] tasked with dropping of the weapons on [[Empire of Japan|Japan]]. In February 1945, Ashworth was sent to [[Guam]] to deliver a letter to [[Fleet admiral (United States)|Fleet Admiral]] [[Chester Nimitz]] from Fleet Admiral [[Ernest King]] ordering him to provide whatever support the Manhattan Project required. Ashworth's first task was to select a suitable base area for the [[509th Composite Group]]. After looking at Guam and [[Saipan]], he decided that [[Tinian]] would be more suitable, as it was closer to Japan than Guam, and had better facilities than Saipan. At the suggestion of island commander, [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[Frederick V. H. Kimble]], Ashworth selected an area at the northern end of the island. The Director of the Manhattan Project, [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] [[Leslie R. Groves, Jr.]], wanted each nuclear strike mission to be commanded by a "weaponeer", a [[Project Alberta]] service academy graduate who would fly on the bomb-carrying aircraft and make such tactical decisions as were required. Only two officers met this requirement: Ashworth and his commanding officer, [[Captain (United States O-6)|Captain]] [[William S. Parsons]]. The two therefore agreed that they would flying alternating missions. Parsons therefore commanded the [[Bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|Hiroshima]] mission, while Ashworth commanded the Nagasaki mission. For this mission, Ashworth was awarded the [[Silver Star Medal]]. His citation read:{{quote|The President of the United States of America, authorized by Act of Congress July 9, 1918, takes pleasure in presenting the Silver Star (Army Award) to Commander Frederick Lincoln Ashworth (NSN: 0-72354), United States Navy, for gallantry in action while engaged in aerial flight against the Japanese Empire on 9 August 1945, from a base in the Marianas Islands. Commander Ashworth was Senior Military Technical Observer on a B-29 aircraft carrying the second atomic bomb to be employed in the history of warfare. After the Superfort was well away from its island base, Commander Ashworth personally entered the bomb bay to fuze the atomic bomb. Following a circuitous course to the Japanese Empire in order to avoid heavy weather, they arrived over the primary target with low reserves of gasoline. Despite this and the possibility of damage from anti-aircraft fire or enemy fighters, he advised that an effort be made to bomb the primary target and the big plane remained over the city for nearly one hour, making three attempts to drop the new bomb, all failing because smoke obscured the target. Little more than enough fuel remained for Superfort to reach the nearest emergency landing field but they set a course directly across the Empire, disregarding the dangers of flak and enemy fighter attacks, and under Commander Ashworth's direction released the bomb on the secondary target, the important industrial city of Nagasaki. The tremendous blast which followed destroyed a square mile of the city and played an important part in bringing forth an offer of surrender from the Japanese within 24 hours. Although the B-29 was shaken by the detonation, they proceeded to the emergency field and landed with fuel tanks virtually empty. Commander Ashworth distinguished himself by his high degree of skill in directing work with the atomic bomb, the great personal risk he took in placing the powder charge in the bomb during flight and attack despite unfavorable conditions. His actions reflect great credit on himself and the United States Naval Service.}} He was also awarded the [[Legion of Merit]]. His citation read: {{quote|The President of the United States of America takes pleasure in presenting the Legion of Merit to Commander Frederick Lincoln Ashworth (NSN: 0-72354), United States Navy, for exceptionally meritorious conduct in the performance of outstanding services to the Government of the United States in connection with the development of the greatest military weapon of all time, the atomic bomb. Joining the Atomic Bomb Project in November 1944, Commander Ashworth was assigned the duties of supervising and coordinating field tests in which facsimiles of the weapon were dropped from B-29 aircraft. Thoroughly understanding the principles and functions of intricate and complicated mechanisms, he was able to make sure that no time was wasted and the maximum information gained, both as to the components and as to the technique of delivery. Serving with intelligence, resourcefulness and devotion to duty, Commander Ashworth inspired the full confidence of all of the organizations and individuals concerned in the tests and insured the complete cooperation which was essential to achieve results in the time available. As a result of his successful fulfillment of this exacting and important assignment, he acted as representative of General Groves in the historic deliver of the second atomic bomb on Nagasaki, 9 August 1945. Commander Ashworth's leadership, professional skill and distinctive performance of duty throughout the test and development of this project were in keeping with the highest traditions of the United States Naval Service.}} Ashworth was awarded a second [[Legion of Merit]] for [[Operation Crossroads]] in 1946. His citation read: {{quote|The President of the United States of America takes pleasure in presenting a Gold Star in lieu of a Second Award of the Legion of Merit to Captain Frederick Lincoln Ashworth (NSN: 0-72354), United States Navy, for exceptionally meritorious conduct in the performance of outstanding services to the Government of the United States as Chief of Staff to Commander Task Group 1.1, Joint Task Force ONE, during the period 7 February 1946 to 31 October 1946. With outstanding initiative, vision and professional ability, Captain Ashworth participated in the organization of both the military and technical staff of Joint Task Force ONE from its inception. He also made major contributions to the basic planning of the operation including the selection of Bikini Atoll as the site of the tests. As the operations proceeded Captain Ashworth's knowledge, background, initiative and good judgment enabled him to make major contributions to the effective coordination of the work of diverse military and civilian groups, particularly those involved in the preparation and air and underwater deliver of the atomic bombs. His outstanding service and performance of duty were at all times in keeping with the highest traditions of the United States Naval Service.}} ===Post-war career=== Ashworth remained in the navy after the war. He served on the staff of the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]]'s Division of Military Applications from 1952 to 1954. He was [[Commandant of Midshipmen]] at the United States Naval Academy in 1958, and headed the Atomic Energy Division for the [[Chief of Naval Operations]] from 1958 to 1960. Promoted to [[Vice admiral (United States)|vice admiral]] in May 1966, Ashworth served as commander of the [[United States Sixth Fleet]] from September 1966 to April 1967, for which he was awarded a [[Navy Distinguished Service Medal]]. From April 1967 to September 1968, he was Deputy Commander in Chief, U.S. Atlantic Fleet, and as chief of staff to the Commander in Chief Atlantic, Commander in Chief U.S. Atlantic Fleet and Commander in Chief Western Atlantic Area, for which he was awarded a second [[Navy Distinguished Service Medal]]. He retired in September 1968 with the rank of vice admiral. ==Retirement== Frederick L. Ashworth lived for over three decades in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]]. He divorced his first wife in 1990, and remarried. He died on 3 December 2005 at Arizona Heart Hospital in [[Phoenix, Arizona]], while undergoing heart surgery, and was buried in the [[Santa Fe National Cemetery]]. He was survived by his second wife, Ercie Bell Ashworth, and his sons Frederick Jr., David and Stephen.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/12/06/AR2005120601834.html |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |title=Frederick Ashworth; Helped Drop Atom Bomb |date=7 December 2005 }} ==Decorations==

ribbon.svg|width=106}} |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=award-star|ribbon=Silver Star ribbon.svg|width=106}} |{{ribbon devices|number=1|type=award-star|ribbon=Legion of Merit ribbon.svg|width=106}} revision.comment: Replacing GDP_Real_Growth.svg with [[File:GDP_Real_Growth_in_2009.svg]] (by [[commons:User:CommonsDelinker|CommonsDelinker]] because: [[:c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: More specific).
revision.text:
[[File:GDP Real Growth in 2009.svg|270px|thumb|Countries by real [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] growth rate (2009).]] [[File:Countries by Real GDP Growth Rate (2014).svg|270px|thumb|Countries by real GDP growth rate (2014).]] [[File:BankingCrises.svg|thumb|Number of countries having a banking crisis in each year since 1800. This is based on [http://www.reinhartandrogoff.com This time is different: Eight centuries of financial folly], which covers only 70 countries. The general upward trend might be attributed to many factors. One of these is a gradual increase in the percent of people who receive money for their labor. The dramatic feature of this graph is the virtual absence of banking crises during the period of the [[Bretton Woods agreement]], 1945 to 1971. This analysis is similar to Figure 10.1 in Reinhart and Rogoff (2009). For more details see the help file for "bankingCrises" in the Ecdat package available from the [[R (programming language)|Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN).]] ]]
A '''global recession''' is [[recession]] that affects many countries around the world—that is, a period of global economic slowdown or declining economic output.
== Definitions == The [[International Monetary Fund]] defines a global recession as "a decline in annual per{{nbhyph}}capita real World GDP ([[purchasing power parity]] weighted), backed up by a decline or worsening for one or more of the seven other global macroeconomic indicators: Industrial production, trade, capital flows, oil consumption, unemployment rate, per{{nbhyph}}capita investment, and per{{nbhyph}}capita consumption".<ref name="New IMF Global Recession definition">{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2009/04/22/whats-a-global-recession/|title=What’s a Global Recession?|publisher=The Walstreet Journal|date=22 April 2009|accessdate=17 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="IMF WEO 2009">{{cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2009/01/pdf/text.pdf|title=World Economic Outlook - April 2009: Crisis and Recovery|format=PDF|work=Box 1.1 (page 11-14)|publisher=IMF|date=24 April 2009|accessdate=17 September 2013}}</ref>
According to this definition, since [[World War II]] there were only four global recessions (in 1975, 1982, 1991 and 2009), all of them only lasting a year (although the 1991 recession would have lasted until 1993 if the IMF had used normal exchange rate weighted per{{nbhyph}}capita real World GDP rather than the [[purchasing power parity]] weighted per{{nbhyph}}capita real World GDP).<ref name="New IMF Global Recession definition" /><ref name="IMF WEO 2009" /> The 2009 global recession, also known as the [[Great Recession]], was by far the worst of the four postwar recessions, both in terms of the number of countries affected and the decline in real World GDP per capita.<ref name="New IMF Global Recession definition" /><ref name="IMF WEO 2009" />
Before April 2009, the IMF argued that a global annual [[real GDP]] growth rate of 3.0 percent or less was "equivalent to a global recession".<ref name="economist-12381879">{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/finance/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12381879 |title=The world economy Bad, or worse |publisher=Economist.com |date=2008-10-09 |accessdate=2009-04-15}}</ref><ref>Lall, Subir. "IMF Predicts Slower World Growth Amid Serious Market Crisis," International Monetary Fund, April 9, 2008. [http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/survey/so/2008/RES040908A.htm]</ref> By this measure, there were six global recessions since 1970: 1974–75,<ref name="IMF0901">http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2009/update/01/index.htm IMF Jan 2009 update</ref> 1980–83,<ref name="IMF0901" /> 1990–93,<ref name="b1" /> 1998,<ref name="b1" /> 2001–02,<ref name="b1" /> and 2008–09.<ref name="IMF1301">{{cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2013/01/pdf/tables.pdf|title=World Economic Outlook (WEO) April 2013: Statistical appendix - Table A1 - Summary of World Output|format=PDF|publisher=IMF|date=16 April 2013|accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref>
== Overview == Informally, a national [[recession]] is a period of declining economic output. In a 1974 ''[[New York Times]]'' article, [[Julius Shiskin]] suggested several [[rules of thumb]] to identify a recession, which included two successive quarterly declines in [[gross domestic product]] (GDP), a measure of the nation's output.<ref>{{cite news|last=Achuthan |first=Lakshman |url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/05/05/news/economy/recession/index.htm |title=The risk of redefining recession, Lakshman Achuthan and Anirvan Banerji, Economic Cycle Research Institute, May 7, 2008 |publisher=Money.cnn.com |date= 2008-05-06|accessdate=2009-04-15}}</ref> This two-quarter metric is now a commonly held definition of a recession. In the United States, the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] (NBER) is regarded as the authority which identifies a recession and which takes into account several measures in addition to GDP growth before making an assessment. In many developed nations (but not the United States), the two-quarter rule is also used for identifying a recession.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aUUg6ckAsM5U&refer=hom Japan's Economy Shrinks 0.4%, Confirming Recession] By Jason Clenfield</ref>
Whereas a national recession is identified by two quarters of decline, defining a '''global recession''' is more difficult, because a [[Developing country]] is expected to have a higher GDP growth than a [[Developed country]].<ref name="imf-weo-2008-03">{{cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2008/update/03/index.htm |title=IMF World Economic Outlook (WEO) Update - Rapidly Weakening Prospects Call for New Policy Stimulus - November 2008 |publisher=Imf.org |date=2008-11-06 |accessdate=2009-04-15}}</ref> According to the IMF, the real GDP growth of the emerging and developing countries is on an uptrend and that of advanced economies is on a downtrend since late 1980s. The world growth is projected to slow from 5% in 2007 to 3.75% in 2008 and to just over 2% in 2009. Downward revisions in GDP growth vary across regions. Among the most affected are commodity exporters, and countries with acute external financing and [[Liquidity risk|liquidity problems]]. Countries in [[East Asia]] (including [[China]]) have suffered smaller declines because their financial situations are more robust. They have benefited from falling commodity prices and they have initiated a shift toward macroeconomic policy easing.<ref name="imf-weo-2008-03" />
The IMF estimates that global recessions occur over a cycle lasting between eight and ten years. During what the IMF terms the past three global recessions of the last three decades, global per capita output growth was zero or negative.<ref name="b1">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=arlKrFbn3pfY&refer=home|title=Global Recession Risk Grows as U.S. `Damage' Spreads. Jan 2008 |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=2008-01-28 |accessdate=2009-04-15}}</ref>
==See also== *[[2000s energy crisis]] *[[2007–08 world food price crisis]] *[[Financial crisis of 2007–08]] *[[Great Recession]] *[[Great Depression]]
==References==
{{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.imf.org/external/np/res/seminars/2004/mussa/pdf/aliber.pdf The Thirty-Five Most Tumultuous Years in Monetary History]: Shocks and Financial Trauma, by Robert Aliber. Presented at the IMF *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080925210636/http://www.nber.org/cycles.html Business Cycle Expansions and Contractions] The National Bureau Of Economic Research *[http://www.aier.org/research/ Independent Analysis of Business Cycle Conditions] - American Institute for Economic Research (AIER)
