page.title: List of World War II evacuations

revision.text:
{{NR|date=December 2016}} Several instances of [[wikt:evacuations|evacuations]] (including both [[emergency evacuation]]s and [[forced migration]]s) occurred during and after [[World War II]]. {{inc-transport|date=August 2008}}
==Forced Migrations== * [[World War II evacuation and expulsion]], an overview of the major forced migrations ** Forced migration of Poles, [[Ukrainians]], [[Belorussians]], and [[Russians]] to Germany as forced labour ** Forced migration of [[Jews]] to Nazi [[concentration camp]]s in German occupied lands ** [[Expulsion of Germans after World War II]] from areas occupied by the Soviet Army ** [[Evacuation of East Prussia]] ** [[Japanese American internment]] ** [[NKVD prisoner massacres]]
==Civilian emergency evacuations== * [[Evacuations of civilians in Britain during World War II]], the emergency evacuation of children from British urban areas during the Battle of Britain * [[Evacuation in the Soviet Union|Evacuation of population in the Western USSR]] in the wake of [[Operation Barbarossa]] * [[Evacuation of Finnish Karelia]] * [[Finnish war children]] * [[Evacuations of civilians in Japan during World War II]]
==Military evacuations== * [[Operation Dynamo]], British evacuation of Dunkirk, France, 1940 * [[Operation Ariel]], British evacuation of Western France, 1940 * [[Operation Cycle]], British evacuation of Le Havre, France, 1940 * [[Operation Alphabet]], British evacuation of Norway, 1940 * Evacuation for Odessa during the [[Siege of Odessa]] * Evacuation from Crimea during the [[Crimea Campaign]] * Evacuations during the [[Siege of Leningrad]] * [[Operation Hannibal]], German evacuation of East Prussia in advance of the Soviet Army, 1945 * [[Evacuation of Tallinn]] * [[Allied invasion of Sicily]], Axis evacuation order over the Strait of Messina to Italy, 1943
==Industrial evacuations== * Evacuation of industries from western USSR to the [[Urals]] * Evacuation of industries from western USSR to [[Central Asia]] * Evacuation of industries from western USSR to [[Kazakhstan]] * Evacuation of industries from western USSR to the [[Caucasus]]
[[Category:World War II|Evacuations]] [[Category:Evacuations|World War II]]

page.title: List of assassinated people from Turkey

revision.text:
The following is an incomplete, chronological list of people from [[Turkey]] murdered by [[Assassination|assassin]]s mainly on political and religious grounds. Many were critical public servants and intellectuals assassinated by [[Far-right politics|far-right]] proponents of an army-controlled Turkish Republic.<ref>Bawer Çakir, [http://bianet.org/english/freedom-of-expression/119920-families-of-murdered-intellectuals-follow-up-dink-murder-case Families of Murdered Intellectuals Follow up Dink Murder Case], [[Bia News]], 8 February 2010</ref> Many of the victims have historically been [[intellectual]] proponents of [[laicism]] and the strict [[Secularism in Turkey|separation of religion and state in Turkey]], as defined in the [[Constitution of Turkey|constitution]], and [[:Category:Assassinated Turkish diplomats|diplomats who were victims of militant attacks outside of Turkey]].<ref>[http://www.atmg.org/ArmenianTerrorism.html Armenian Terrorism against Turkish diplomatic and non-diplomatic institutions - A Chronological List, 1973 - 1986]</ref>
== [[Mustafa Suphi]] == * 28 January 1921: Mustafa Suphi was the founder of the [[Communist Party of Turkey (historical)|Communist Party of Turkey]]. Suphi and his 14 comrades were assassinated while they were being sent to Erzurum for trial.<ref>Shaw, Stanford J., ''History of the Ottoman Empire and Modern Turkey'', Vol. 2. (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), 354.</ref>
== [[Sabahattin Ali]] == * 2 April 1948: Sabahattin Ali was a writer and critical intellectual who was assassinated at the Bulgarian border while fleeing from Turkey. He had been imprisoned by Republic of Turkey.
==1970s== {{See also|Political violence in Turkey, 1970s}}
=== [[Mehmet Baydar]] and [[Bahadır Demir]] === * 27 January 1973: Mehmet Baydar was Turkey's [[consul general]] in Los Angeles, and Bahadır Demir his deputy, in 1973. Shot down by [[Kourken Yanigian]] in a [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]] hotel who had invited them there on the pretext of a donating a painting to the Turkish government. Yanigian, sentenced to life imprisonment, was amnestied in 1984 and died shortly afterwards.
The event is considered to be the first in a decade-long chain of organized attacks against Turkish diplomats by [[Armenian people|Armenian]] [[Terrorist|militant]] groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.armenians.com/asala/index1.html |accessdate=2008-08-27 |title=Events |work=ASALA Online |date=2001-10-06 }}</ref>
=== [[Daniş Tunalıgil]] === *22 October 1975: Turkey’s Vienna Ambassador Daniş Tunalıgil was murdered by three [[Armenian people|Armenian]] gunmen raiding the Embassy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Terrorist.html|title=Terrorist Organizations|publisher=|accessdate=20 December 2014}}</ref>
=== [[Ismail Erez]] === * 24 October 1975: Turkey’s Paris Ambassador İsmail Erez and his driver Talip Yener were murdered by [[Armenian people|Armenian]] militants in the vicinity of the Embassy by car bomb.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1975/10/25/archives/news-summary-and-index-the-major-events-of-the-day-international.html |accessdate=2008-08-27 |title=News Summary and Index; The Major Events of the Day International National Metropolitan |work=[[New York Times]] |date=1975-10-25 |quote=Ismail Erez, Turkey's Ambassador to France, was fatally shot in Paris by assassins who also killed his chauffeur. }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913623,00.html |accessdate=2008-08-27 |title=Adding Up to an Epidemic |work=TIME |date=1975-11-03 |quote=Two days after the Vienna murder, gunmen in Paris opened fire on a car belonging to the Turkish ambassador to France, Ismail Erez, 56, who died along with his chauffeur.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/archives.php?id=7316 |accessdate = 2008-08-27 |title = Turkey commemorates martyr diplomats |work = [[Turkish Daily News]] |date = 1998-05-28 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
=== [[Taha Carim]] === * 9 June 1977: Turkey’s Vatican Ambassador [[Taha Carim]] was killed by the cross fire of two [[Armenian people|Armenian]] gunmen in front of the Embassy’s residency in [[Rome]].{{citation needed|date=September 2012}}
=== [[Bedrettin Cömert]] === *11 March 1978: Art historian, scholar, literary critic and translator. He was serving on a committee investigating right-wing terror squads at his university.<ref>Ahmad, Feroz. ''The Making of Modern Turkey'', (London: Routledge, 1993), 171.</ref> Shot dead in his car with his wife severely wounded by Rıfat Yıldırım, Üzeyir Bayraklı and by another man nicknamed "Ahmet" who were ultra-nationalists and directly funded by the Turkish state. Ankara 5. Tribunal Correctionnel decided that [[Abdullah Çatlı]] was the responsible. But nobody was punished as a result.
=== [[Doğan Öz]] === *24 March 1978: Public prosecutor who wrote a report for Prime Minister [[Bülent Ecevit]] accusing clandestine groups (later named as [[Ergenekon]]) of creating chaos in order to lay the ground for a military takeover.<ref>Hüseyin Gülerce, [https://web.archive.org/web/20121014134625/http://www.todayszaman.com/columnists-198596-spirits-of-dogan-oz-and-ugur-mumcu-ask-about-baykal.html Spirits of Doğan Öz and Uğur Mumcu ask about Baykal] , [[Today's Zaman]], 15 January 2010</ref> [[Haluk Kırcı]], a [[Grey Wolves (organization)|Grey Wolves]] activist, was implicated in his assassination.
===[[Bedri Karafakıoğlu]]=== *20 October 1978:Former [[rector (academia)|rector]] of [[İstanbul Technical University]]
=== [[Abdi İpekçi]] === *1 February 1979: Editor of the major national newspaper ''[[Milliyet]]''.<ref>[http://www.globaljournalist.org/archive/Magazine/Ipekci-20002q.html Brief biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070227154629/http://www.globaljournalist.org/archive/Magazine/Ipekci-20002q.html |date=2007-02-27 }}</ref> Killed in his car in the street, where he lived, by [[Mehmet Ali Ağca]], a member of the ultra-[[nationalist]] [[Grey Wolves (organization)|Grey Wolves]], who would later try to assassinate the Pope, John Paul II in 1981.
=== [[Metin Yüksel]] === *23 March 1979: Turkish Islamist political and social activist. Shot to death outside of Istanbul's [[Fatih Mosque]] by nationalist gunmen while leaving Friday prayers.
=== [[Cevat Yurdakul]] === 28 September 1979: Turkish prosecutor.
=== [[Cavit Orhan Tütengil]] === * 7 December 1979: Professor of Sociology at [[Istanbul University]], columnist of the newspaper ''[[Cumhuriyet]]''. Shot dead at a city bus stop in [[Istanbul]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/1999/01/24/haber/hab00.html|title=Başlarken... |work=[[Milliyet]]|date=1999-01-24|accessdate=2008-08-27|language=Turkish}}</ref>
==1980s==
=== [[Ümit Kaftancıoğlu]] === * 11 April 1980: TV producer, writer and columnist of the newspaper ''[[Cumhuriyet]]''. Gunned down in front of his home in Istanbul as he was about to get in his car.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.radikal.com.tr/ek_haber.php?ek=ktp&haberno=5412 |accessdate = 2008-08-27 |title = Bir 'Garip' Kaftancıoğlu |section = Kitap |work = [[Radikal]] |date = 2006-07-14 |quote = 11 Nisan 1980'de Mecidiyeköy'de, küçücük çocuğunu okula götürürken, gün ortasında, kızının gözleri önünde katledilen bu değerli aydınımız |first = Kadir |last = Aydemir |language = Turkish |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080608053054/http://www.radikal.com.tr/ek_haber.php?ek=ktp&haberno=5412 |archive-date = 2008-06-08 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
=== [[Gün Sazak]] === * 27 May 1980: customs and tobacco minister of Turkey for a short time, right wing politician. Murdered in front of his car while putting out baggage. Radical leftist Turkish militant group [[Dev Sol]] (Revolutionary Left) claimed responsibility for the attack.
=== [[Nihat Erim]] === * 19 July 1980: [[List of Prime Ministers of Turkey|Prime Minister]] of Turkey in 1971-1972, for almost 14 months. Shot to death by two gunmen in [[İstanbul]]. Radical leftist Turkish militant group [[Dev Sol]] (Revolutionary Left) claimed responsibility for the attack.
=== [[Kemal Türkler]] === * 22 July 1980: Socialist [[trade union]] leader and left-wing politician. Murdered in front of his home by ultra-right militants.
===[[Şarık Arıyak]]=== *17 December 1980: Turkish chief concul in Sydney (together with his bodyguard Engin Sever).[[Justice Commandos of the Armenian Genocide]] claimed the responsibility.
===[[Kemal Arıkan]]=== *28 January 1982:Turkish diplomat Kemal Arıkan shot dur death by two [[Armenian people|Armenian]] origin gun men in Los Angeles, United States.
=== [[Atilla Altıkat]] === * 23 August 1982: Turkish military attaché in Canada. Assassinated in his car while driving in [[Ottawa]], Ontario, Canada by [[Justice Commandos Against Armenian Genocide]].
==1990s==
=== [[Muammer Aksoy]] === * 31 January 1990: Professor of law at [[Ankara University]], Faculty of [[Political science]]; author of books on [[Kemalism]]; elected head of the Ankara Bar Association 1969, columnist of the newspaper ''[[Cumhuriyet]]''. Shot in the back of his head in front of his house.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/2000/05/22/english/cur03.html |accessdate=2008-08-27 |title=Suspects told the murders |work=[[Milliyet]] |date=2000-05-22 |author=Gokcer Tahincioglu, Ersan Atar }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/article.php?webcat=domestic&enewsid=4885 |accessdate = 2008-08-27 |title = Murdered journalist Aksoy commemorated |work = [[Turkish Daily News]] |date = 2005-02-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930155158/http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/article.php?webcat=domestic&enewsid=4885 |archivedate = 2007-09-30 |df = }}</ref>
=== [[Çetin Emeç]] === * 7 March 1990: Journalist, editor-in-chief and chief columnist of the liberal rightist daily ''[[Hürriyet]]''. Shot to death in front of his house. Case remains unresolved.
=== [[Turan Dursun]] === * 4 September 1990: Former member of clergy, descended from Islam and wrote to criticize Islam and promote atheism. Shot to death in front of his house. Case remains unresolved.
=== [[Bahriye Üçok]] === * 6 October 1990: Female academic, pro-secular theologist, columnist of the newspaper ''[[Cumhuriyet]]''. Killed by a [[mail bomb|parcel bomb]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Turkish Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit has accused Iran of failing to respond to evidence of Iranian involvement in the murders of Turkish pro-secular writers and academics |url=http://www.fas.org/news/iran/2000/000517-iran2.htm |work=[[Voice of America]] |publisher=[[Federation of American Scientists]] |date=2000-05-17 |accessdate=2008-08-25 |first=Amberin |last=Zaman}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iranfocus.com/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4950 |accessdate=2008-08-27 |title=Iran accused of aiding Islamist violence in Turkey: report |work=[[Agence France Presse]] |publisher=[[Iran Focus]] |date=2005-12-18 }}</ref>
===[[Memduh Ünlütürk]]=== * 7 April 1991: Retired General. Shot dead at his house.
=== [[Kemal Kayacan]] === * 29 July 1992: Admiral (retired), former commander of the Turkish Navy. Shot dead in his house.
=== [[Musa Anter]] === *1992: Kurdish writer, assassinated in Diyarbakir. [[European Court of Human Rights]] fined Turkey for this assassination, allegedly committed by [[JITEM]] illegal gendarmerie unit.
=== [[Zübeyir Akkoç]] ===
* 13 January 1993: Union member of [[Kurds in Turkey|Kurdish]] origin. His murder led to the [[European Court of Human Rights]] case ''[[Akkoç v. Turkey]]'' (2000).
=== [[Uğur Mumcu]] === * 24 January 1993: Research journalist, columnist of the major newspaper ''[[Cumhuriyet]]''. Killed in front of his home in [[Ankara]] by a bomb installed in his car.<ref>[http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/archives.php?id=1971 Public outrage over Mumcu's murder unabated four years later; Foundation carries on Ugur Mumcu's work] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930155101/http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/archives.php?id=1971 |date=2007-09-30 }}</ref>
===[[Cem Ersever]]=== * 4 November 1993: ex-[[JITEM]] commander who had begun speaking to the press.
=== [[Onat Kutlar]] === * 11 January 1995: A prominent Turkish art critic, writer, poet, columnist for the daily ''[[Cumhuriyet]]'' and one of the founders of the [[Istanbul International Film Festival]], died of injuries he suffered during a bomb attack at a hotel in [[İstanbul]].<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.birgun.net/sunday_index.php?news_code=1199551197&year=2008&month=01&day=05 |accessdate = 2008-08-27 |title = Yazar Onat KUTLAR, 11 Ocak 1995 de Yaşamını Yitirdi |work = BirGün |date = 2008-01-06 |language = Turkish |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110526143637/http://www.birgun.net/sunday_index.php?news_code=1199551197&year=2008&month=01&day=05 |archivedate = 2011-05-26 |df = }}</ref>
=== [[Metin Göktepe]] === * 8 January 1996: {{DOClink|[http://www.b-info.com/places/Bulgaria/news/98-03/mar16c.rfe Metin Goktepe]}}, a left wing journalist of [[Evrensel]] was beaten to death by Turkish police while covering civil unrest in the Gazi district of Istanbul. The first case in Turkey where the police were convicted of murder.
=== [[Özdemir Sabancı]] === * 9 January 1996: Businessman and a member of the [[Sabancı family]] in the second generation. Gunned down in his office in Sabancı Towers, [[Levent]], İstanbul, by assassins hired by the leftist armed group [[DHKP-C]]. The general manager of ToyotaSA and a secretary was also killed. They had been given access to the building by [[Fehriye Erdal]], a female member of DHKP-C, who was an employee at that time.
=== [[Ahmet Taner Kışlalı]] === * 21 October 1999: Academic, writer. politician, former Minister of Culture and columnist of the newspaper ''[[Cumhuriyet]]''. Killed in [[Ankara]] by a bomb placed on the windshield of his car.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/archives.php?id=14602 |accessdate = 2008-08-27 |title = A tragic loss for the nation |work = [[Turkish Daily News]] |date = 1999-09-22 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930155642/http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/archives.php?id=14602 |archivedate = 2007-09-30 |df = }}</ref><ref>Hocaoglu, Selcan. [http://www.atmg.org/Kislali.html Prominent secularist academic and writer slain in Ankara] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060208210936/http://www.atmg.org/Kislali.html |date=2006-02-08 }}, ''[[Associated Press]]'', 23 October 1999.</ref>
==2000s==
=== [[Gaffar Okkan]] === * 24 January 2001: [[Diyarbakır]] Police Chief, his driver and four policemen escorting him were shot dead in an attack after they left Diyarbakır Police Department building. Radical Islamic group known as [[Turkish Hezbollah]] was suspected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1136302.stm|title=BBC News - EUROPE - Crowds mourn slain Turkish officers|publisher=|accessdate=20 December 2014}}</ref>
=== [[Üzeyir Garih]] === * 25 August 2001: A prominent [[Jews in Turkey|Turkish Jewish]] businessman and a founding partner of the Alarko group of companies. He was stabbed to death in the cemetery of the historic [[İstanbul]] quarter of [[Eyüp]].
=== [[Necip Hablemitoğlu]] === * 18 December 2002: A Kemalist historian from ''[[Ankara University]]'' who was killed in an armed attack near his home in Ankara.
=== [[Andrea Santoro]] === * 5 February 2006: Father Andrea Santoro was a Roman Catholic priest in Trabzon, murdered in the Santa Maria Church in Trabzon where he served as a member of the Catholic Church's [[Fidei donum]] missionary program. On 5 September 2006 he was shot dead from behind while kneeling in prayer in the church. A witness heard the perpetrator shouting "Allahu Akbar".[1][2] A 16-year-old high school student was arrested two days after the shooting carrying a 9mm pistol. An investigation by the Air Force Office of Special Investigations on stolen weaponry in Iraq revealed that the gun was of the same type used in the supposedly Islamist attack on the Turkish Council of State in 2006.
=== [[Mustafa Yücel Özbilgin]] === * 17 May 2006: Council of State member judge. Murdered during a session in the high court in [[Ankara]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4989034.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Europe - Judge dies in Turkey court attack|publisher=|accessdate=20 December 2014}}</ref>
=== [[Hrant Dink]] === {{Main|Assassination of Hrant Dink}} * 19 January 2007: [[Armenians in Turkey|Armenian-Turkish]] journalist and editor-in-chief of the weekly Armenian and Turkish language newspaper ''[[Agos]]'' in [[Istanbul]]. Shot dead in front of his newspaper's office.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL19386144|accessdate=2008-08-27|title=Turkish-Armenian editor shot dead in Istanbul |work=[[Reuters]]|date=2007-01-19|author=Paul de Bendern and Thomas Grove}}</ref>
<!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[File:Ogunsamastflag.jpg|thumbnail|Shortly after [[Hrant Dink]] was murdered, the assassin was honored as a hero while in police custody, posing with a Turkish flag with policemen.<ref>{{cite news|title=Samast'a jandarma karakolunda kahraman muamelesi |url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/haber.php?haberno=211902 |newspaper=Radikal |date=2 February 2007 |language=Turkish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205085530/http://www.radikal.com.tr/haber.php?haberno=211902 |archivedate=5 February 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Watson|first1=Ivan|title=Turkey remembers murdered journalist|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/01/19/world/meast/turkey-journalist-anniversary/|agency=CNN|date=12 January 2012}}</ref>]] -->
=== [[Bible publishing firm murders in Malatya, Turkey|Necati Aydın, Uğur Yüksel and Tilman Geske]] === *18 April 2007. Three Christian leaders assassinated, two Turkish Pastors and a German missionary.
=== [[İhya Balak]] === *16 November 2007. Director of ''[[Milli Piyango]]'', the Turkish National Lottery, was assassinated in his office by an ex-inspector of his directorate.
=== [[Ahmet Yıldız (honor killing)|Ahmet Yıldız]] === *July 2008: "the victim of what sociologists say is the first gay [[honor killing]] in Turkey to surface publicly"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/was-ahmet-yildiz-the-victim-of-turkeys-first-gay-honour-killing-871822.html|title=Was Ahmet Yildiz the victim of Turkey's first gay honour killing?|last=Birch|first=Nicholas|date=19 July 2008|work=The Independent|accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/26/world/europe/26turkey.html|title=Soul-Searching in Turkey After a Gay Man Is Killed|last=Bilefsky|first=Dan|date=November 25, 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://bianet.org/english/gender/116934-ahmet-yildiz-murder-case-started-fugitive-defendant-yildizs-father|title=Ahmet Yıldız Murder Case Started. Fugitive Defendant: Yıldız's Father|last=Gençkal|first=Elif|date=September 9, 2009|work=Bianet.org|accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuerkeiforum.net/enw/index.php/The_killing_of_Ahmet_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1z_%282008%29|title=The killing of Ahmet Yıldız (2008)|publisher=|accessdate=20 December 2014}}</ref>
=== [[Cihan Hayırsevener]] === *19 December 2009: founder and editor of the daily ''Güney Marmara’da Yaşam'', was shot in a street of [[Bandırma]], [[Balıkesir Province]] and died later that day at a hospital in [[Bursa]]. He had reported on corruption charges involving the owners of ''İlkhaber'', another daily in the town.<ref>[http://cpj.org/killed/2009/cihan-hayirsevener.php Cihan Hayırsevener], [[Committee to Protect Journalists]]</ref><ref>[http://cpj.org/2009/12/editor-killed-by-unknown-gunmen-in-turkey.php Editor killed by unknown gunmen in Turkey], [[Committee to Protect Journalists]], December 21, 2009</ref>
== See also == *[[List of assassinated people]] *[[List of journalists killed in Turkey]] *[[:Category:Massacres in Turkey|Massacres in Turkey]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Assassinated people from Turkey}} [[Category:Lists of Turkish people]] [[Category:Assassinated Turkish people| ]] [[Category:Turkey-related lists]] [[Category:Assassinations in Turkey| ]] [[Category:Lists of assassinations|Turkey]] [[Category:Turkey crime-related lists|Assassinated people]]

page.title: List of live performances by Shawn Mendes

revision.text: {{Infobox|above=[[Shawn Mendes]] live performances|abovestyle={{{abovestyle|{{{Abovestyle|}}}}}}|headerstyle=background:#DADCED;|labelstyle=background:#DADCED;|datastyle=background:#E6E8FA; text-align:center;|image={{#invoke:InfoboxImage|InfoboxImage|image=File:QueenbdayRAH210418-28 (26886325387) (cropped).jpg |alt=}}|caption=Mendes performing at Queen Elisabeth's 92nd birthday in March 2018.|label1=Concert tours|data1=4|label2=Live performances|data2=78}} Canadian singer and songwriter [[Shawn Mendes]] has released three [[studio albums]], an [[extended play]] and two [[live albums]] since his debut in 2013. This has resulted in four concert tours (all of them worldwide), and numerous TV and [[Award show|award shows]] performances. He first released an extended play named ''[[The Shawn Mendes EP]]'' in July 2014. The EP got promoted through 2014, through performances at several award ceremonies and television shows, including the [[Jingle Ball Tour 2014|Jingle Ball]] and [[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]. Mendes has served as an opening act for [[Austin Mahone]] on the [[North America|North American]] leg of [[Austin Mahone: Live on Tour|his 2014 tour]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.fuse.tv/videos/2014/08/austin-mahone-tour-fifth-harmony-vamps-shawn-mendes-interview|title=Austin Mahone Details Touring Life with Fifth Harmony, Shawn Mendes & The Vamps - Fuse|website=www.fuse.tv|access-date=2018-09-02}} He also has served as the opening act for [[Taylor Swift|Taylor Swift's]] [[The 1989 World Tour|1989 World Tour]] on selected dates of the tour's North American leg.{{Cite news|url=https://mashable.com/2014/11/03/taylor-swift-1989-tour-openers-shawn-mendes-vance-joy/?europe=true|title=Taylor Swift reveals tour openers: Meet Shawn Mendes and Vance Joy|last=Hernandez|first=Brian Anthony|work=Mashable|access-date=2018-09-02|language=en}} In 2014 he embarked on his debut concert tour, [[ShawnsFirstHeadlines|#ShawnsFirstHeadlines]], which only visited [[North America]] and [[Europe]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1940658/shawn-mendes-tour-dates/|title=EXCLUSIVE: Shawn Mendes Announces His First Headlining Shows: Get The Tour Dates!|work=MTV News|access-date=2018-09-02|language=en}} and grossed over a million dollars.{{cn|date=November 2018}} He embarked on his second world tour [[Shawn Mendes World Tour]] in 2016 to promote his first studio album ''[[Handwritten (Shawn Mendes album)|Handwritten]]'' (2015).{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/shawn-mendes-announces-second-headlining-world-tour-66683/|title=Shawn Mendes Announces Second Headlining World Tour|last=Spanos|first=Brittany|date=2016-01-28|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2018-09-02|language=en-US}} The tour visited North America, Europe, [[Oceania]] and the [[Philippines]]. After completion, the tour grossed over $3.8 million and over 95,000 people had gone to one of the tour's stops.{{cn|date=November 2018}} The [[Madison Square Garden]] show in September 2016 was filmed for a live album that got released three months later.{{Cite news|url=https://www.axs.com/shawn-mendes-to-release-live-at-madison-square-garden-album-111922|title=Shawn Mendes to release 'Live At Madison Square Garden' Album|work=AXS|access-date=2018-09-02|language=en-US}} Mendes' next tour was named [[Illuminate World Tour]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.musictimes.com/articles/73147/20160908/shawn-mendes-2017-illuminate-world-tour-dates.htm|title=Shawn Mendes Announces 2017 Illuminate World Tour Dates|last=Times|first=Music|date=2016-09-08|work=Music Times|access-date=2018-09-02|language=en}} It began in April 2017 and ended in December 2017 visiting North America, Europe, [[Asia]], Oceania and [[Brazil]].{{Cite news|url=https://g1.globo.com/musica/rock-in-rio/2017/noticia/shawn-mendes-vai-cantar-no-rock-in-rio.ghtml|title=Shawn Mendes vai cantar no Rock in Rio|work=G1|access-date=2018-09-02|language=pt-BR}} It was reported that the tour had grossed over $37 million becoming his highest grossing tour to date. The tour supported the release of his second studio album, ''[[Illuminate (Shawn Mendes album)|Illuminate]]'' which was released in September 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7430909/shawn-mendes-new-album-illuminate|title=Shawn Mendes Announces New Album 'Illuminate'|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-09-02}} The only show in [[Mexico]] was cancelled due to the [[2017 Central Mexico earthquake]].{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/music/news/shawn-mendes-ricky-martin-mexico-city-earthquake-1202564747/|title=Shawn Mendes, Ricky Martin Cancel Concerts Following Mexico City Earthquake|last=Rubin|first=Rebecca|date=2017-09-20|work=Variety|access-date=2018-09-02|language=en-US}} In November 2017, Mendes released his [[MTV Unplugged (Shawn Mendes album)|MTV Unplugged]] live album which was filmed at the [[Ace Hotel Los Angeles|Ace Hotel]] in [[Los Angeles]] in early September.{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8006549/shawn-mendes-mtv-unplugged-album|title=Shawn Mendes Releasing 'MTV Unplugged' Album on Nov. 3|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-09-02}} In May 2018 Mendes announced his fourth world tour called [[Shawn Mendes: The Tour]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8455111/shawn-mendes-tour-dates-2019|title=Shawn Mendes Announces Self-Titled International Arena Tour|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-09-02}} The tour will start in [[Amsterdam]] in March 2019 and will visit Europe, North America and Oceania.{{Cite news|url=https://www.eonline.com/news/933410/shawn-mendes-announces-2019-global-tour-dates|title=Shawn Mendes Announces 2019 Global Tour Dates|last=|first=|date=May 8, 2018|work=E! Online|access-date=September 2, 2018|language=en-US}} Before going on that 2019 tour, he had embarked on a big [[festival]] tour in 2018 to support his [[Shawn Mendes (album)|self-titled album]] which was released in May 2018. == Concert tours == {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" width="100%" ! scope="col" |Title ! scope="col" width="14%" |Dates ! scope="col" page.title: List of people who disappeared mysteriously: pre-1970

revision.comment: Reverting 2 edits by Bravo-November7. Notability of the disappearance not established. Write an article on it before resubmitting
revision.text:
{{For|other lists of disappeared persons|Lists of people who disappeared}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} This is a '''list of people who disappeared mysteriously: pre-1970''' and of people whose current whereabouts are unknown or whose deaths are not substantiated. Many people who disappear are eventually [[declared death in absentia|declared dead ''in absentia'']]. Some of these people were possibly subjected to [[forced disappearance]], but there is insufficient information on their subsequent fates.
<!--By consensus, entries must be those of people or disappearances that are notable because an article about them already exists. Do not add an entry if you cannot link to such an article. Also, fugitives from justice including most wanted criminals or those who disappear that are suspects of a crime, and whose disappearance is related to that particular crime, should not be included unless there are special circumstances regarding the case.--> {{horizontal TOC|nonum=yes}}
==Before 1800==
{| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="-53-01-01"|53 BC |[[Ambiorix]] |rowspan="2"| |rowspan="2"|Ambiorix was, together with Catuvolcus, prince of the [[Eburones]], leader of a [[Belgae|Belgic tribe]] of northeastern [[Gaul]] ([[Gallia Belgica]]), where modern [[Belgium]] is located. According to the writer [[Florus]] (iii.10.8), Ambiorix and his men managed to cross the [[Rhine]] and disappeared without a trace.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.livius.org/articles/person/ambiorix/|title=Ambiorix – Livius|website=www.livius.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-07}}</ref> |- |[[Catuvolcus]] |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="-30-01-01"|30 BC |[[Alexander Helios]] |[[circa]] 10 |rowspan="2"|Alexander Helios and Ptolemy Philadelphus, sons of [[Cleopatra]] and [[Mark Antony]] and the younger half-brothers of [[Caesarion]], left [[Egypt]] for [[Rome]], after which their fates are unknown.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ancient-origins.net/history-famous-people/unraveling-history-final-fates-children-cleopatra-vii-005230|title=Unraveling History: The Final Fates of the Children of Cleopatra VII?|last=Klimczak|first=Natalia|work=Ancient Origins|access-date=2017-06-09|language=en}}</ref> |- |[[Ptolemy Philadelphus (son of Cleopatra)|Ptolemy Philadelphus]] | 6 |- |data-sort-value="108-01-01"|108–164 |[[Legio IX Hispana]] (Ninth Spanish Legion) | |The Roman legion stationed in [[Roman Britain]], following the [[Roman conquest of Britain]] in AD 43, disappears from surviving records without explanation in the second century. There are multiple conjectures regarding what happened to it and why no record of its fate has been found. Many references to the legion have been made in subsequent works of fiction.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-12752497 | work=BBC News | title=The Roman Ninth Legion's mysterious loss | date=16 March 2011}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="834-01-01"|{{circa|834}} |[[Muhammad ibn Qasim (al-Alawi)]] | |The [[Alawite]] imam who led a rebellion against the [[Abbasid Caliphate]]. He was eventually defeated and detained but was able to escape. After fleeing he was never heard from again.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=h9yluZH7dGIC&pg=PT12&lpg=PT12#v=onepage&q=Muhammad%20ibn%20Qasim%20was%20never%20heard%20from%20again|title=Raptor Force: Holy Fire|last=Yenne|first=Bill|date=2007-02-06|publisher=Penguin|isbn=9781440622809|language=en}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1021-01-01"|1021 |[[Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah]] |36 |The sixth [[Fatimid Caliphate|Fatimid]] caliph and 16th [[Ismaili]] [[imam]] rode his donkey to the [[Mokattam]] hills, outside [[Cairo]], for one of his regular nocturnal meditation outings and failed to return. A search found only the donkey and his bloodstained garments.<ref>[http://www.iis.ac.uk/view_article.asp?ContentID=104798 al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah], Institute of Ismaili Studies, Dr Farhad Daftary.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1071-01-01"|1071 |[[Hereward the Wake]] |36–37 |A formerly exiled Anglo-Danish minor noble rebel, Hereward the Wake led a huge revolt in the marshy region of [[Ely, Cambridgeshire|Ely]] in England against the rule of [[William the Conqueror]]. He was eventually betrayed by fearful local monks who led the [[Normans|Norman]] troops through secret trackways. Many rebels were mutilated or executed but Hereward escaped, never to be heard of again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mygen.com/users/outlaw/Hereward_the_Wake_Utlag.htm|title=Hereward the Wake – Outlawe|website=www.mygen.com|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref><ref>Rex, Peter (2005) Hereward: the last Englishman Chalford: Tempus, Chapter 10, {{ISBN|0-7524-3318-0}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1291-01-01"|{{circa|1291}} |[[Vandino and Ugolino Vivaldi]] | |[[Republic of Genoa|Genoese]] sailors and explorers were lost while attempting the first oceanic journey from Europe to Asia. Their two galleys sailed out of the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and into the [[Atlantic Ocean]] but were never heard from again.<ref>{{cite EB1911|wstitle=Vivaldo, Ugolino and Sorleone de |volume=28 |page=152 |url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri28chisrich#page/152/mode/1up}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1398-01-01"| 1398 |[[Gerald FitzGerald, 3rd Earl of Desmond|Gearóid Iarla]] | 63 |Gerald FitzMaurice FitzGerald, also known by the Irish Gaelic Gearóid Iarla (Earl Gerald), was the 3rd Earl of Desmond, lord of Munster, and Norman-Gaelic poet, disappeared in 1398.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=uFgoDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT29#v=onepage&q=%22gearoid+iarla%22+%22lough+gur%22|title=Sacred Plant Initiations: Communicating with Plants for Healing and Higher Consciousness|first=Carole|last=Guyett|date=16 March 2015|publisher=Simon and Schuster|via=Google Books}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1412-01-01"|1412 |[[Owain Glyndŵr]] | 56 |The last native [[Welsh person]] to hold the title [[Prince of Wales]], Owain instigated the [[Glyndŵr Rising|Welsh Revolt]] against the rule of [[Henry IV of England]] in 1400. Although initially successful, the uprising was eventually defeated but Glyndŵr disappeared and no one knows what became of him after that.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ramblingman.org.uk/walks/glyndwrs-way/the_story_of_owain_glyndwr|title=The Last Prince: the story of Owain Glyndŵr – Glyndŵr's Way – Rambling Man|website=ramblingman.org.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1453-01-01"|1453 |[[Constantine XI Palaiologos]] | 48 |The last [[List of Byzantine emperors|Byzantine emperor]] during the final hours of the [[Fall of Constantinople|Siege of Constantinople]]. Constantine XI Palaiologos disappeared during the fighting and was never seen after that.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://neoskosmos.com/news/en/A-throwback-to-the-last-Byzantine-Emperor|title=A throwback to the last Byzantine Emperor {{!}} Neos Kosmos|date=2015-08-10|website=neoskosmos.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="1483-01-01"|1483 |[[Edward V of England]] |12 |rowspan="2"|The [[Princes in the Tower]], Edward V of England and Richard of Shrewsbury, sons of King [[Edward IV of England]] and [[Elizabeth Woodville]], were placed in the [[Tower of London]] (which at that time served as a fortress and a royal palace as well as a prison) by their uncle [[Richard III of England]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldreviewer.com/travel-guides/castle/tower-of-london/10969/|title=''World Reviewer'', accessed March 21, 2011|work=World Reviewer|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> Neither was ever seen in public again and their fate remains unknown. The remains of four children which have been found could be the princes, but they have not been subjected to DNA analysis to positively identify them.<ref name=Guardian2013>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/feb/05/princes-in-tower-staying-under|title=Why the princes in the tower are staying six feet under|first1=Alan|last1=Travis|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=5 February 2013}}</ref> |- |[[Richard of Shrewsbury, 1st Duke of York]] | 9 |- |data-sort-value="1487-01-01"|1487 |[[Francis Lovell, Viscount Lovell|Lord Lovell]] | 31 |Lord Lovell, a rebel [[House of York|Yorkist]] knight, was last seen alive fleeing from the [[Battle of Stoke Field]] after defeat by the [[House of Lancaster|Lancastrians]]. In 1488 he was granted safe conduct in Scotland by [[King James IV]] but there is no evidence he was ever in the country. (A skeleton found at one of his mansions at [[Minster Lovell]], [[Oxfordshire]], in 1708 was believed without evidence to be his.)<ref>Joanna M. Williams, "The Political Career of Francis Viscount Lovell (1456-?)"</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1499-01-01"|1499 |[[John Cabot]] | [[circa]] 49 |John Cabot, an Italian explorer, disappeared along with his five ships during an expedition to find a [[Northwest Passage|western route]] from Europe to Asia.<ref>{{cite DCB | url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/cabot_john_1E.html |title=Cabot, John |volume=1 |first=R. A. |last=Skelton}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1501-01-01"|1501 |{{nowrap|[[Gaspar Corte-Real]]}} | 51 |[[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] explorer Gaspar Corte-Real disappeared on an expedition to discover the [[Northwest Passage]] from Europe to Asia. Two of his ships returned to [[Lisbon]] but the third, with Gaspar on board, was lost and never heard from again.<ref>{{cite DCB |url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/corte_real_gaspar_1E.html |title=Corte-Real, Gaspar |first=L.-A. |last=Vigneras |volume=1}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1502-01-01"|1502 |[[Miguel Corte-Real]] | [[circa]] 54 |Miguel Corte-Real, a Portuguese explorer, disappeared while searching for his brother [[Gaspar Corte-Real|Gaspar]]. Like his brother he took three ships and, just like his brother, the ship with Miguel on board was lost and never heard from again.<ref>{{cite DCB |url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/corte_real_miguel_1E.html |title=Corte-Real, Miguel |first=L.-A. |last=Vigneras |volume=1}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1526-01-01"|1526 |[[Francisco de Hoces]] | |Francisco de Hoces was the commander of the ''San Lesmes'' which was one of the seven ships of the [[Loaísa expedition]] under [[García Jofre de Loaísa]]. It has been speculated that the ''San Lesmes'', last seen in the [[Pacific Ocean]] in late May, may have reached [[Easter Island]], the [[Polynesia|Polynesian archipelagos]] or even [[New Zealand]].<ref>Langdon, Robert. ''The lost caravel re-explored''. Canberra: Brolga Press {{ISBN|0-9588309-1-6}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1579-01-01"|1579 |[[Ikegusuku Antō]] | <ref group="Note">Has to be cleared</ref> |A bureaucrat of [[Ryukyu Kingdom]], Ikegusuku Antō was sent by ship to [[China]] to ask for postponement, but his ship was caught in a storm and disappeared at sea in 1579 and was never seen again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://manwe.lib.u-ryukyu.ac.jp/d-archive/s/viewer?cd=00030240|title=中山王府相卿伝職年譜 向祐等著写本{{!}} 琉球・沖縄関係貴重資料 デジタルアーカイブ|last=琉球大学附属図書館|website=manwe.lib.u-ryukyu.ac.jp|language=ja|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1590-01-01"|{{circa|1590}} |[[list of colonists at Roanoke|Roanoke colonists]] | |The Roanoke colonists, including [[Virginia Dare]] age 2 or 3, the first [[English people|English child]] born in a [[New World]] [[English overseas possessions|English overseas possession]], disappeared becoming known as the [[Roanoke Colony|Lost Colony]]. On 18 August 1590, their settlement was found abandoned. The settlement was located on [[Roanoke Island]], currently part of [[Dare County, North Carolina]].<ref>[http://www.coastalguide.com/packet/lostcolony-croatan.shtml The Lost Colony: Roanoke Island, NC] Eric Hause.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1611-01-01"|1611 |[[Henry Hudson]] | |Hudson went on multiple expeditions of present-day [[Canada]] and parts of the [[northeastern United States]], searching for the [[Northwest Passage]]. In 1611, after [[overwintering|wintering]] on the shore of [[James Bay]], Hudson wanted to press on to the west, but most of his crew [[mutiny|mutinied]]. The mutineers cast Hudson, his teenage son, and seven others [[marooning|adrift]]; the Hudsons and their companions were never seen again.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Aftermath of Hudson's Voyages and Related Notes|url=http://www.ianchadwick.com/hudson/hudson_05.htm|publisher=Ian Chadwick|date=19 January 2007|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1628-01-01"|1628 |[[David Thompson (New Hampshire settler)|David Thompson]] | |The founder of the [[New Hampshire]] colony in 1623, Thompson moved his family to an island in [[Boston Harbor]] (today called [[Thompson Island (Massachusetts)|Thompson Island]] in his honor) in 1626 becoming the first European settlers of [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]]. He disappeared in 1628 and was never heard from again. Some historians theorize he was the victim of foul play while others suggest he accidentally drowned in Boston Harbor.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Robert Charles |last=Anderson |title=The Great Migration Begins: Immigrants to New England, 1620–1633 |volume=3 |location=[[Boston]], MA |publisher=New England Historic Genealogical Society |year=1995 |isbn= |pages=}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1638-01-01"|1638 |[[Urasoe Chōri]] | |A member of [[Sanshikan]], Urasoe Chōri went on a boat trip to [[Satsuma Domain|Satsuma]] but his ship was caught in a storm and disappeared in the sea. He is believed to have drowned.<ref>''[[Chūzan Seifu]]'', appendix vol.1</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1661-01-01"|1661 |[[René Menard]] | 56 |A French [[Jesuit]] missionary, Fr. René Menard disappeared while traveling by canoe with a Native guide from the area of present-day [[L'Anse, Michigan]], on [[Lake Superior]], to minister to a [[Huron, Wisconsin|Huron]] village deep in the [[Wisconsin]] interior. After encountering a series of rapids Menard and his guide agreed that he would walk downstream on shore while his more skilled companion brought the boat through. The latter passed the rapids successfully but Menard was never seen again. Years later, his cassock and breviary were discovered in a [[Dakota people|Dakota]] village far from the scene.<ref>Schmirler, A. A. A., [http://content.wisconsinhistory.org/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/wmh&CISOPTR=22009&CISOSHOW=21949&REC=1 "Wisconsin's Lost Missionary: The Mystery of Father Rene Menard"], ''The Wisconsin Magazine of History'', Volume 45, number 2, winter, 1961–1962.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1671-01-01"|1671 |[[Roche Braziliano]] | 40–41 |A [[Dutch people|Dutch]] [[Piracy|pirate]] born in the town of [[Groningen]], Roche Braziliano, whose career lasted from 1654 until 1671, when he disappeared during that year, and was never seen again.<ref>Pyle, Howard. ''Howard Pyle's Book of Pirates''. {{ISBN|1-60303-278-9}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1696-01-01"|1696 |[[Henry Every]] (sometimes spelled 'Avery') | 37 |Henry Every, an [[England|English]] pirate, vanished after perpetrating one of the most profitable pirate raids in history. Despite a worldwide manhunt and an enormous bounty on his head Every was never heard from again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/henry-avery-pirate-who-kept-loot-2136226|title=Henry Avery: The Pirate Who Kept His Loot|work=ThoughtCo|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> In March, Every had led his ship, the ''[[Fancy (ship)|Fancy]]'', to the island of [[New Providence]]. He and his crew spent months living there and soon lost their ship. By June, Every and his crew were forced to flee the island. The crew then split up, with Every possibly setting sail toward [[Ireland]]. A manhunt for Every lasted for at least a decade. There were several unconfirmed sightings of him and contradictory reports of his death during the 18th century. Most of them are considered unreliable, however, and his actual fate is unknown.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.goldenageofpiracy.org/infamous-pirates/henry-every.php|title=Infamous Pirates {{!}} Henry Every, the 'King of Pirates'|last=Humanity|first=History of|website=www.goldenageofpiracy.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1704-01-01"|1704 |[[Laurens de Graaf]] | 51 |[[Laurens de Graaf]] was last known to be near [[Louisiana (New France)|Louisiana]] where he was to help set up a [[French colonial empires|French colony]] near present-day [[Biloxi, Mississippi]]. Some sources claim he died there while others claim he died at different locations in [[Alabama]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=KRJ3CQAAQBAJ&pg=PT109&lpg=PT109#v=onepage&q=Laurens%20de%20Graff|title=Alabama Scoundrels: Outlaws, Pirates, Bandits & Bushwhackers|last=Kazek|first=Kelly|last2=Elrick|first2=Wil|date=2014-06-17|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=9781625850676|language=en}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1758-01-01"|1758 |[[Khe Pandjang]] | |[[Khe Pandjang]] was a leader of Chinese rebels fighting against the [[Dutch East India Company]] during the [[Java War (1741–1743)|Java War]]. He escaped capture after the defeat of the rebellion, and was last seen in [[Bali]] in 1758.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Mary|first=Somers Heidhues,|date=2009|title=Daradjadi, Perang Sepanjang 1740-1743 : Tionghoa-Jawa Lawan VOC.|url=https://www.persee.fr/doc/arch_0044-8613_2009_num_77_1_4134_t14_0201_0000_3|journal=Archipel|language=fr-FR|volume=77|issue=1}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1769-01-01" rowspan="3"|1769/70 |[[Henry Vansittart]] |37 |rowspan="3"|Henry Vansittart, MP and director of the East India Company, Luke Scrafton and Francis Forde formed a delegation to investigate corruption and reform the British government in [[India]] and were last seen embarking at [[Cape Town]] en route to India on 27 December 1769. Their ship disappeared with all hands, apparently in a storm, the captain having decided to sail the [[Mozambique Channel]] despite adverse weather.<ref name=odnb>{{cite book|title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Volume 20|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=350|isbn=0-19-861370-9}}Article by H M Stephens, revised by D J Prior.</ref> |- |[[Luke Scrafton]] | |- |[[Francis Forde (army officer)|Francis Forde]] |51 |- |data-sort-value="1788-01-01"|1788 ||[[Jean-François de Galaup, comte de Lapérouse]] and his expedition | |The French expedition of Jean-François de Galaup, Comte de Lapérouse disappeared after their [[Jean-François de Galaup, comte de Lapérouse#Australia|last stop]] at [[Botany Bay]] (now [[Sydney]]) after meeting ships of Britain's [[First Fleet]] bringing convicts to establish the new settlement that became [[Australia]]. The wrecks of the expedition's two ships, the [[French ship Boussole (1781)|Boussole]] and [[French ship Astrolabe (1781)|Astrolabe]]), were subsequently discovered at [[Vanikoro]], an island in the [[Santa Cruz Islands|Santa Cruz group]] (part of the [[Solomon Islands]]) where the survivors may have set up camp.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Robert J |last=King |title=What brought Lapérouse to Botany Bay? |journal=Journal of the Royal Australian Historical Society |volume=85, pt.2 |date=December 1999|pages=140–147 |url=http://search.informit.com.au/search;res=APAFT}}</ref><ref>They Made History edited by Claud Golding; p.53 (1998 edition); published and distributed by [[Siena]]; {{ISBN|978-0-75252-828-1}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1792-01-01"|1792 |[[James Harrod]] |46 |An early explorer of the areas west of the [[Appalachian Mountains]] prior to their settlement by European-Americans, James Harrod never returned from a trip to western [[Kentucky]] from [[Harrodsburg, Kentucky|Harrodsburg]]. Theories about his fate range from murder at the hands of his companions or [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] in the area, to accidental death or a desire to abandon his wife and family.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://genealogytrails.com/ken/mercer/bio_harrod_james.html|title=James Harrod Mercer County, KY|website=genealogytrails.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> |}
==1800 to 1899== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- |data-sort-value="1802-01-01"|1802 |[[James Derham]] |44–45 |The [[List of African-American firsts|first African American]] to formally practice medicine in the United States disappeared after 1802.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://americacomesalive.com/2012/05/03/james-derham-ca-1762-1802-physician/|title=James Derham (ca. 1762–1802?), Physician|last=says|first=Susan Nelson Hopkins|date=2012-05-03|website=America Comes Alive|access-date=2017-06-26}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1803-01-01"|1803 |[[George Bass]] |32 |The British explorer of [[Australia]] set sail from [[Sydney]] for South America and was never heard from again.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/55411/George-Bass George Bass] ''Encyclopædia Britannica''.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1809-01-01"|1809 | [[Benjamin Bathurst (diplomat)|Benjamin Bathurst]] | 25 | British diplomat, disappeared from an inn in [[Perleberg]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.historicmysteries.com/benjamin-bathurst/|title=Benjamin Bathurst {{!}} Historic Mysteries|date=2011-10-14|work=Historic Mysteries|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1812-01-01"|1812 |[[Theodosia Burr Alston]] |29 |The daughter of U.S. Vice President [[Aaron Burr]], and sometimes called the most educated American woman of her day, sailed from [[Georgetown, South Carolina]], aboard the ''Patriot'', which was never seen again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/local/article187025283.html|title=Aaron Burr's daughter went missing 204 years ago. But a clue turned up in Nags Head.|work=Charlotte Observer|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1821-01-01"|1821 |[[Essex (whaleship)#Separation|Obed Hendricks, William Bond and Joseph West]] | |Sailors on the [[whaler]] ''[[Essex (whaleship)|Essex]]'', which sank in the Pacific on 20 November 1820 after being struck by a [[sperm whale]]. Their whaleboat was separated on the open sea from their fellow crewmen on 28 January 1821, it was never seen again. Years later, a boat with three skeletons inside was discovered washed up on [[Ducie Island]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Philbrick|first1=Nathaniel|title=In the Heart of the Sea: The Tragedy of the Whaleship Essex|date=2001|publisher=Penguin|location=New York|isbn=978-0-14-100182-1|edition=[Nachdr.]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/the-true-life-horror-that-inspired-moby-dick-17576/|title=The True-Life Horror That Inspired Moby-Dick|last=King|first=Gilbert|website=Smithsonian Magazine|access-date=2017-10-14}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1826-01-01"|1826 |[[William Morgan (anti-Mason)|William Morgan]] |52 |The resident of [[Batavia (city), New York|Batavia, New York]], disappeared just before his book critical of [[Freemasonry]] was published. A year after he had disappeared a badly decomposed body was found that was thought to be his but it was proven not to be.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.awarenessofnothing.com/capt-william-morgan.html|title=Capt. William Morgan|website=Awareness of Nothing|language=en|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1829-01-01"|1829 |[[John Lansing, Jr.]] |75 |American politician and chief justice of the [[New York State Supreme Court]] Lansing left his [[Manhattan]] hotel to mail a letter at a [[New York City]] dock and was never seen again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs|title=America's Founding Documents|date=2015-10-30|work=National Archives|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1837-01-01"|1837 |[[Joseph Gellibrand]] |48–49 |The first [[Attorney-General]] of [[Van Diemen's Land]] disappeared while attempting to ride inland from [[Geelong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], to [[Melbourne, Victoria]] in 1837.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://poi-australia.com.au/joseph-tice-gellibrand/|title=Joseph Tice Gellibrand – (b. c 1792 – d. c 1837) » POI Australia|date=1792-01-01|work=POI Australia|access-date=2017-07-08|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1839-01-01"|1839 |[[Charles Sturt#Return to Australia and disappearance and likely death of Henry Bryan|Henry Bryan]] |18 |Bryan, who accompanied explorer [[Charles Sturt]], [[Governor of South Australia|Governor]] [[George Gawler]], and others on an expedition from the [[Murray River]] to the [[Burra, South Australia|Burra]] area of [[South Australia]], disappeared and is believed to have died in 1839 during a dust storm on the return trip.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sahistorians.org.au/175/chronology/november/26-november-1839-disappearance-of-henry-bryan.shtml|title=26 November 1839 Disappearance of Henry Bryan (Celebrating South Australia)|last=Painter|first=Alison|website=www.sahistorians.org.au|language=en|access-date=2017-03-26}}</ref> Searchers later found his saddle and some tracks which stopped abruptly. His body was never found, however his horse returned to [[Adelaide]] after several months.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.murrayriver.com.au/morgan/mt-bryan-expedition/|title=Disappearance of Henry Bryan Trail 1839 from Morgan|website=www.murrayriver.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-05-12}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1842-01-01"|1842 |[[Charles Christian Dutton]] | |Charles Christian Dutton and four other men disappeared without trace while droving cattle from [[Port Lincoln, South Australia|Port Lincoln]], [[South Australia]] to [[Adelaide]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article96724741|title=Early Days of Eyre Peninsula 1 |newspaper=[[Port Lincoln Times|Port Lincoln Times (SA : 1927–1954)]]|location=SA |date=31 January 1936|accessdate=22 November 2015|page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1842-01-01"|1843 |[[Sequoyah]] |''circa'' 73 |The creator of [[Cherokee syllabary]], Sequoyah disappeared during a trip to Mexico to locate isolated tribes of Cherokees who had moved there during the time of [[Indian Removal]] in the U.S. His body has never been found, although at least three different burial sites have been reported.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.u-s-history.com/pages/h3934.html|title=Sequoyah|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1845-01-01"|1845 |[[Franklin's lost expedition]] | |The expedition, with 129 seamen, made last contact with a whaling ship before entering [[Victoria Strait]] in search of the [[Northwest Passage]]. The remains of some individuals, written messages and the wrecks of the ships [[HMS Erebus (1826)|HMS ''Erebus'']] (in 2014) and [[HMS Terror (1813)|HMS ''Terror'']] (in 2016) were later discovered. However, the majority of the crew, including Franklin himself, were never found with the crew having probably died from a combination of lead poisoning, starvation, and exposure.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neatby|first1=Leslie H. |last2=Mercer|first2=Keith|last-author-amp=yes|title=Sir John Franklin|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/sir-john-franklin/|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|publisher=Historica Canada|date=|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1848-01-01"|1848 |[[Khachatur Abovian]] |38 |The Armenian writer and national public figure of the early 19th century, credited as creator of modern [[Armenian literature]], left his house early one morning and was never heard from again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.australiangeographic.com.au/topics/history-culture/2010/08/cold-case-leichhardts-disappearance/|title=Cold case: Leichhardt's disappearance|work=Australian Geographic|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1848-01-01"|1848 |[[Ludwig Leichhardt]] |34 |A [[Prussia]]n explorer and naturalist, Ludwig disappeared during his third major expedition to explore parts of northern and central Australia. He was last seen on 3 April at McPherson's Station on the [[Darling Downs]], en route from the [[Condamine River]] to the [[Swan River (Western Australia)|Swan River]] in [[Western Australia]]. Although investigated by many, his fate after leaving the settled areas remains a mystery. |- |data-sort-value="1849-01-01"|1849 |[[Sándor Petőfi]] |26 |Sándor Petőfi, [[Hungarian people|Hungarian]] poet and [[Classical liberalism|liberal]] [[revolutionary]], was one of the key figures of the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1848]]. Petőfi was last seen in [[Transylvania]] during the [[Battle of Segesvár]]. He is thought to have been killed in battle, but since his body was never found, his true fate remains unknown.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Sandor-Petofi|title=Sándor Petőfi {{!}} Hungarian poet|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1856-06-29"|1856 |[[Matias Perez]] | |Perez, a Cuban balloonist of Portuguese descent, disappeared with his balloon "Ville de Paris" during a flight in Cuba on 29 June.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.check-six.com/lib/Famous_Missing/Perez-1856.htm|title=Matías Pérez|website=www.check-six.com|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1857-01-01"|1857 |[[Solomon Northup]] |48–49 | Solomon Northup, an American author, who was most notable for his book ''[[Twelve Years a Slave]]'' in which he details his kidnapping and subsequent sale into slavery. Northup did not return to his family from his book-promoting tour.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/lifestyle/death-of-solomon-northup-author-of-12-years-a-slave-still-a-mystery-1.277249|title=Death of Solomon Northup, author of 12 Years A Slave, still a mystery|work=The National|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref> No contemporary evidence documents Northup after 1857. |- |data-sort-value="1857-01-01"|1857 |[[Nana Sahib]] |33 |An Indian aristocrat and a leader of the [[Indian Rebellion of 1857]] Nana Sahib disappeared after the [[East India Company]]'s forces retook his city of [[Kanpur]]. Rumors that he had died of an illness or fled to exile in [[Nepal]] or another part of [[India]] were never proven.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/sunday-times/deep-focus/Indias-very-own-treasure-mystery/articleshow/2291584.cmshttps://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/sunday-times/deep-focus/Indias-very-own-treasure-mystery/articleshow/2291584.cms|title=India's very own treasure mystery |work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1865-01-01"|1865 |Captain [[James William Boyd]] |43 |Boyd, a [[Confederate States of America]] military officer, vanished after his release as a prisoner of war in February 1865 after he failed to show up for a rendezvous with his son to go to Mexico at the end of the [[American Civil War]]. Boyd's disappearance is the subject of a conspiracy theory that he was killed after being mistaken for [[John Wilkes Booth]], the assassin of President [[Abraham Lincoln]].<ref name="Guttridge">{{cite news |author=Leonard Guttridge |title=In Defense of Dark Union |publisher=History News Network |date=8 March 2004 |url=http://hnn.us/articles/3873.html |accessdate=23 April 2009}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1869-01-01"|1869 |{{nowrap|[[Agoston Haraszthy]]}} |56 |Haraszthy, who was a founder of Californian wine industry, disappeared in a river while organizing a liquor business in Nicaragua.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://library.sonoma.edu/research/guides/regional/notablepeople/haraszthy|title=Agoston Haraszthy, 1812–1869 {{!}} University Library|website=library.sonoma.edu|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1872-01-01"|1872 |Captain [[Benjamin Briggs]] |37 |Captain Briggs, his wife Sarah Elizabeth (31), their daughter Sophia Matilda (2) and all seven crew members were missing when the ''[[Mary Celeste]]'' was found adrift in choppy seas some {{convert|400|mi}} east of the [[Azores]]. Their unexplained disappearances are at the core of "one of the most durable mysteries in nautical history".<ref>[http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history-archaeology/abandoned-200711.html Abandoned Ship] ''Smithsonian Magazine'' 2007–11, Jess Blumberg.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1874-01-01"|1874 |[[Charley Ross]] |4 |Ross, a resident of [[Philadelphia]], was enticed along with his brother Walter into a horse-drawn carriage while playing in their front yard on 1 July. Walter got out at a fireworks shop, and the carriage drove on without him. The family received ransom notes and worked with police, but all to no avail.<ref>Carrie Hagen, ''we is got him: The Kidnapping That Changed America''. Overlook, 2011.</ref><ref>Waldon R. Porterfield, "[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19741002&id=u68oAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AikEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7464,403935 Little Charlie and the Crime that Shocked a Nation]{{dead link|date=March 2017}}." ''Milwaukee Journal'', 2 October 1974.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1880-01-01"|1880s |[[William Cantelo]] | |Cantelo, inventor of an early machine gun, never returned to his [[Southampton]] home after one of his frequent and lengthy sales trips. His sons speculated years later that he may have re-emerged as [[Hiram Maxim]], another machine-gun pioneer, who he strongly resembled.<ref name="William Cantelo">{{cite news|title=The mystery of the vanishing gun inventor|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23709471|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=24 August 2013}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1880-01-01"| 1880 |[[Lamont Young]] |28–29 |Lamont Young, government geologist inspecting new gold fields on behalf of the New South Wales Mines Department, together with his assistant Max Schneider, boat owner Thomas Towers and two other men disappeared after leaving [[Bermagui, New South Wales]], Australia in a small boat. The nearby location where the abandoned wreck of their boat was discovered was subsequently named [[Mystery Bay, New South Wales|Mystery Bay]].<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/news/New-South-Wales/Bermagui/2005/02/17/1108500192720.html Bermagui] ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' 16 December 2008.</ref><ref>{{NSW GNR|id=ujKqlMKmKW|title=Mystery Bay|accessdate=}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1882-01-01"|1882 |[[Jesse Evans]] | |An American outlaw, gunman of the [[Old West]], leader of the [[Jesse Evans Gang]], and veteran of the [[Lincoln County War]] disappeared from the record shortly after his release from prison. He was never seen or heard from again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.texasescapes.com/CFEckhardt/What-Happened-To-Jesse-Evans.htm|title=What Happened To Jesse Evans.|website=www.texasescapes.com|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> Despite an unsubstantiated claimant in 1948 (who also claimed that other Lincoln County veterans, including the renowned [[Billy the Kid]], were still alive), Evans's fate remains unknown. |- |data-sort-value="1884-01-01"|1884 |''[[Resolven (ship)|Resolven]]'' | |The merchant ship ''Resolven'' was found abandoned off the coast of [[Labrador]] on 29 August. A lifeboat was missing and it was assumed that all 11 on board had evacuated in the face of nearby icebergs but neither they nor the lifeboat were ever found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/lifestyle/nostalgia/welsh-marie-celeste-mystery-8916016|title=Could the 131-year-old mystery of the Welsh Marie Celeste about to be solved?|last=Bevan|first=Nathan|date=2015-03-25|work=walesonline|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1888-01-01"|1888 |[[Boston Corbett]] |56 |Boston Corbett, the [[Union Army]] soldier who fatally shot [[John Wilkes Booth]], later went insane and was incarcerated in a mental asylum in 1887. He escaped from the facility a year later and was never seen again, though some historians suspect he may have perished in the [[Great Hinckley Fire]] of 1 September 1894.<ref name=Herald>''Lincoln Herald, Volume 86'', Lincoln Memorial University Press., 1984, pp. 152–155.</ref><ref name=Kubicek>Kubicek, Earl C, "The Case of the Mad Hatter", ''Lincoln herald, Volume 83'', Lincoln Memorial University Press, 1981, pp. 708–719.</ref> |- |data-sort-value-"1888-10-30"|1888 |[[Henry Boynton Clitz]] |64 |Clitz, a career U.S. Army officer who had served with distinction in the [[Mexican–American War|Mexican]] and [[American Civil War|Civil]] wars before being named superintendent of the [[United States Military Academy]], was last seen in [[Niagara Falls, New York]], on 30 October. Family members said his mental state had been deteriorating over the previous months; he was presumed to have drowned although no body was ever found.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1888/10/30/archives/gen-hb-clitz-missing-he-disappeared-from-his-home-in-detroit.html "Gen. H. B. Clitz Missing: He Disappeared from His Home in Detroit Last Tuesday."] ''[[The New York Times]]'', 30 October 1888. Retrieved 27 April 2018.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1890-01-01"|1890 |[[Louis Le Prince]] |48 | Le Prince, a motion picture pioneer, disappeared after boarding a Paris-bound train at [[Dijon|Dijon, France]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://fstoppers.com/originals/mysterious-disappearance-louis-le-prince-father-cinematography-156151|title=The Mysterious Disappearance of Louis Le Prince, Father of Cinematography|date=2016-12-08|work=Fstoppers|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1892-01-01"|1892 |[[Hermann Fol]] |46 |Hermann Fol, a Swiss zoologist regarded as the father of modern cell biology, disappeared with several crew members of his yacht shortly after leaving [[Bénodet|Bénodet, France]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/science/biology#ref498812|title=biology {{!}} Definition, History, Concepts, Branches, & Facts|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1896-01-01"|1896 |[[Albert Jennings Fountain]] |57 |Former [[Texas State Senate|Texas state senator]] and [[Lieutenant governor (United States)|lieutenant governor]] Albert Jennings Fountain disappeared near [[Las Cruces, New Mexico]], United States, along with his son Henry (8) on 1 February 1896. Evidence found along their route strongly suggests they were murdered but no bodies were ever found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truewestmagazine.com/who-killed-col-fountain/|title=Who Killed Col. Fountain?|date=2007-08-01|work=True West Magazine|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US}}</ref> |}
==1900s== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- |rowspan="3" data-sort-value="1900-12-26"|1900 |Thomas Marshall |24 |rowspan="3"|Lighthouse keepers at the [[Flannan Isles Lighthouse]] who mysteriously vanished from their posts during a fierce storm on 26 December 1900 and were never seen again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unexplainedpodcast.com/episode-8-when-the-light-fades/|title=S01 Episode 8: When The Light Fades|website=Unexplained|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref> |- |James Ducat |48 |- |Donald MacArthur | |- |data-sort-value="1902-01-01"|1902 |[[Yda Hillis Addis]] |45 |A translator of ancient Mexican narratives, Addis escaped from an insane asylum in [[California]] where her husband had her confined during their divorce and was not seen again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sites.tufts.edu/excollege/|title=University's Experimental Colleges volumes|last=|first=|date=|website=sites.tufts.edu|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://my.wn.com/search/from_ancient_times?p=21900&t=details |title=World News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161120085421/http://my.wn.com/search/from_ancient_times?p=21900&t=details |archivedate=20 November 2016 |df= }}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1902-10-26"|1902 |[[Eduard Toll]] |44 |A group of Russian explorers led by Baron [[Eduard Toll]] left their camp on [[Bennett Island]] and disappeared without trace.<ref>Wikipage titled "[[Russian polar expedition of 1900-02]]"</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1908-04-28"|1908 |[[Belle Gunness]] |48 |The Norwegian-American serial killer vanished on 28 April 1908 after a house fire (suspected arson) and withdrawing huge amounts of money from her bank accounts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://swordandscale.com/did-belle-get-away-with-murder/ |title=Did Belle Get Away with Murder? |publisher=[[Sword and Scale]] |date=2013-12-30 |accessdate=2017-10-02}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1908-01-01"|1908 |[[Eduardo Newbery]] |30 |The Argentine aviator disappeared while attempting to break the night flight record on the aerostat ''Pampero'' in Buenos Aires, Argentina.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.ca/translate?sl=es&u=http://www.lanueva.com/sociedad-impresa/504872/eduardo-newbery.html|title=Google Translate|website=translate.google.ca|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="1908-11-7"|1908 |[[Butch Cassidy|Robert Leroy Parker]] <br>([[Pseudonym|aka]] Butch Cassidy) |42 |rowspan="2"| The outlaws were supposedly killed in a shootout with the Bolivian police around 7–8 November, although the authorities were unable to positively identify the bodies. |- |{{nowrap|[[The Sundance Kid|Harry Alonzo Longabaugh]]}} (aka The Sundance Kid) |40 or 41 |- |data-sort-value="1909-01-01"|1908 |[[Joseph Kelly (crimper)|Joseph "Bunko" Kelly]] | |The English hotelier, [[Crimp (recruitment)|crimper]] and convicted murderer vanished while traveling to [[San Diego]], [[California]] after finishing a 13 year prison sentence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/jterencefisher/bunkokelly,continued |title= The Legend of Bunko Kelly |accessdate=2018-11-05}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1909-01-01"|1909 |[[Joshua Slocum]] |65 |Slocum, a Canadian-American sailor and first man to [[Single-handed sailing|sail single-handedly]] around the world (1895–1898), disappeared after setting sail from Vineyard Haven on [[Martha's Vineyard]] alone, bound for [[South America]], aboard the same {{convert|36|ft|9|in|abbr=on}} [[sloop]] ''[[Spray (sailing vessel)|Spray]]'' he had used for his circumnavigation.<ref>[http://www.joshuaslocumsocietyintl.org/jshistory.htm Joshua Slocum and His Travels] Joshua Slocum Society International Inc.</ref> |}
==1910s== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- |data-sort-value="1910-01-01"|1910 |[[Disappearance of Dorothy Arnold|Dorothy Arnold]] |24 | [[Manhattan]] [[socialite]] and [[perfume]] heiress Dorothy Arnold vanished after buying a book in [[New York City]]. She intended to walk through [[Central Park]] and was never seen again.<ref>[http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1960/5/1960_5_24.shtml "The Girl Who Never Came Back", ''American Heritage'', May 1960] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630110556/http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1960/5/1960_5_24.shtml |date=30 June 2007 }}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1912-01-01"|1912 |[[Alexander Kuchin]] | |[[Russia]]n [[oceanographer]] and Arctic explorer Alexander Kuchin disappeared in 1912 and was never heard from again.<ref>Barr, William (1985/01). "Aleksandr Stepanovich Kuchin: the Russian who went south with Amundsen". Polar Record. 22 (139): 401–412. {{ISSN|1475-3057}}.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1912-01-01"|1912 |[[Disappearance of Bobby Dunbar|Bobby Dunbar]] |4 |Bobby disappeared during a fishing trip in [[St. Landry Parish, Louisiana]]. A child found in the custody of William Cantwell Walters of [[Mississippi]] eight months later was ruled to be Bobby Dunbar by a court-appointed arbiter, and Walters was found guilty of kidnapping. The child grew up as Bobby Dunbar, had four children of his own, and died in 1966. In 2004, DNA tests proved that the child found was not related to Bobby Dunbar's brother, Alonzo.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2004-05-05-1914-dna_x.htm DNA clears man of 1914 kidnapping conviction] ''USA Today'' 2004-05-05, Allen G. Breed (Associated Press).</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1912-01-01"|1912 | [[Sebastiano DiGaetano]] |50 |DiGaetano, a ''[[capo di tutti capi]]'' of the [[Bonanno crime family]], disappeared from [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York]], shortly after being forced out of that position. It is believed he and his wife returned to [[Italy]] but it is not known for certain.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Warner|first=Richard|last2=Santino|first2=Angelo|last3=Van't Reit|first3=Lennert|date=May 2014|title=Early New York Mafia: An Alternative Theory|url=http://www.magcloud.com/browse/issue/739915|journal=Informer: The History of American Crime and Law Enforcement|doi=|pmid=|ref=harv|access-date=20 July 2017}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1914-01-01"|1914 |[[František Gellner]] |33 | The [[Czech people|Czech]] poet, short story writer, artist and [[Anarchism|anarchist]] disappeared in September 1914; on 13 September he was claimed missing and was never found.<ref>Lexikon české literatury, vol.I, Academia, Praha 2000, pp.795–797, {{ISBN|80-200-0797-0}} and Slovník českých spisovatelů, Československý spisovatel, Praha 1964, p.112.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1914-01-01"|1914 |[[Ambrose Bierce]] |71 |American writer known for "[[An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge]]" and ''[[The Devil's Dictionary]]'' was last heard from in a letter of December 1913 bearing a [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua|Chihuahua]] postmark to his secretary and companion, Carrie Christiansen. Although alternative theories are plentiful, he may have perished in war-torn Mexico, possibly at the Battle of [[Ojinaga]] on 10 February or perhaps was executed as a spy in the municipal cemetery of [[Sierra Mojada]], [[Coahuila]], where a gravestone bearing his name was erected in 2004.<ref>[http://www.biercephile.com/death.cfm The Death of Bierce] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617070319/http://www.biercephile.com/death.cfm |date=17 June 2009 }} ''Ambrose Bierce Appreciation Society''.</ref><ref>[http://ojinaga.com/bierce/ Ambrose Bierce, "the Old Gringo": Fact, Fiction and Fantasy] Glenn Willeford.</ref><ref>[http://donswaim.com/bierce-lienert.html Retired priest erects Bierce gravestone in Sierra Mojada, Mexico] ''The Ambrose Bierce Site'' James Lienert, Don Swaim.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1914-01-01"|1914 |[[F. Lewis Clark]] |52 |Clark, a businessman from the U.S. state of [[Idaho]] disappeared while visiting [[Santa Barbara, California]], and after getting on a train he was never seen again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://clarkhouse.com/clarkhouse-history/|title=Clarkhouse History ‹ The Clark house|website=clarkhouse.com|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1914-01-01"|1914 |{{nowrap|[[Alejandro Bello Silva]]}} |27 |A lieutenant in the [[Chilean Army]], Silva disappeared during a qualifying examination flight over central [[Chile]] which was to be his final flight. At some point during the flight, Bello became lost in the clouds and he was never seen again. Although search efforts commenced within hours, no trace of him or his aircraft was ever found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deicinginnovations.com/?p=4556|title=Lieutenant Bello Goes Missing in Chile|date=2015-03-09|newspaper=deicing innovations|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1915-01-01"|1915 |[[Frederick Mors]] |24 |The Austrian-American serial killer Frederick Mors (born as Carl Menarik) murdered at least eight people in an [[Independent Order of Odd Fellows|Odd Fellows]]' home, where he was employed as a porter. Mors was declared to be [[criminally insane]] and was committed to an insane asylum. In May 1915 he escaped from the asylum grounds and was never seen again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/dr-jack-kevorkian-young-orderly-yonkers-old-folks-home-caused-sensation-article-1.144018|title=Before Dr. Jack Kevorkian young orderly from a Yonkers old folks home caused a sensation|last=Bovsun|first=Mara|date=2011-05-15|website=NY Daily News|access-date=2018-04-09}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1916-01-01"|1916 |[[Béla Kiss]] |39 |Kiss was a Hungarian serial killer and murderer of 24 young women prior to his enrollment in the Austro-Hungarian Army in the [[World War I|First World War]]. Upon the discovery of his crimes he was traced to a Serbian military hospital but escaped a few days before investigators arrived. Although there were several reported sightings of the killer (notably in [[New York City|New York]] in 1932), his true fate remains a mystery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oddlyhistorical.com/2015/02/14/bela-kiss/|title=Bela Kiss–The Monster of Cinkota|last=|first=|date=2015-02-14|website=Oddly Historical|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161029111944/http://www.oddlyhistorical.com/2015/02/14/bela-kiss/|archivedate=29 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1918-01-01"|1918 |[[Knud Andersen (mammalogist)|Knud Andersen]] |51 |Danish mammalogist Knud Andersen mysteriously disappeared in 1918. His colleague [[Oldfield Thomas]] submitted his final manuscript on his behalf, stating that Andersen expected "to be absent from his scientific work for some time."<ref name="Flannery 2012">{{cite book| last=Flannery| first= T.| year=2012| title= Among the islands: adventures in the Pacific| publisher= Grove/Atlantic, Inc.|isbn=9780802194046}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1919-01-01"|1919 |[[Mansell Richard James]] |25 |Canadian [[flying ace]] Mansell Richard James was last seen in western [[Massachusetts]] on 2 June just days after a record-setting flight between [[Atlantic City]] and [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite news|work=Saskatoon Star-Phoenix|date=2 October 1930|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lxBlAAAAIBAJ&pg=1221,3596411&dq=mansell-james|title=Death of Aviator May Clear UP Old Mystery|accessdate=10 April 2011|page=11}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1919-01-01"|1919 |[[Ambrose Small]] |56 |The Canadian millionaire disappeared from his office. He was last seen at 5:30 pm on 2 December 1919 at the [[Grand Opera House (Toronto)|Grand Opera House]] in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?BioId=41831 |title=Dictionary of Canadian Biography, "Small, Ambrose Joseph" |publisher=Biographi.ca |date=18 October 2007 |accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref> |- |}
