==1920s== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- |data-sort-value="1920-01-01"|1920 |[[Little Lord Fauntleroy (murder victim)#Homer Lemay|Homer Lemay]] |6 |Homer disappeared in 1920, and on 8 March 1921 the body of an unidentified boy was found murdered in [[Waukesha, Wisconsin]], and nicknamed [[Little Lord Fauntleroy (murder victim)|Little Lord Fauntleroy]]. Many years later authorities said that the body might have been that of Lemay.<ref>{{cite news|title=In Memoriam|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=pv&GRid=5481656&PIpi=33460872|accessdate=2 August 2014|agency=Waukesha Freeman|date=17 March 1921}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1920-01-01"|1920 |[[Clayton Kratz]] |21–22 |The [[Mennonite]] [[relief worker]] from the [[U.S. state]] of [[Pennsylvania]] left the U.S. on 1 September 1920 to travel to [[Russia]]. He did not return from the trip and was never heard from again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mbhistory.org/profiles/kratz.en.html|title=MBHC: Profiles: Clayton Kratz|website=www.mbhistory.org|language=en|access-date=2017-07-20}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1920-01-01"|1920 |[[Victor Grayson]] |39 |The British former Member of parliament was not seen again after 28 September 1920 after telling friends he was going to the Queen's Hotel in [[Leicester Square]], London, and would be back, but did not return. He was also seen the same day by an artist who knew him entering a house in [[Thames Ditton]] belonging to [[Maundy Gregory]], corrupt honours dealer, who is alleged to have murdered Grayson who had been investigating his activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://justcriminals.info/2017/02/14/victor-grayson-1920/|title=Victor Grayson – 1920 {{!}} Criminal Encyclopedia|last=admin|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1921-01-01"|1921 |''[[Carroll A. Deering]]'' | |The captain and ten crewmen of the schooner ''Carroll A. Deering'' were missing after the schooner was found run aground off [[Cape Hatteras|Cape Hatteras, North Carolina]], on 31 January 1921. A mutiny is suspected but without any idea of the crew's later whereabouts nothing can be proven.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bermuda-attractions.com/bermuda2_00018e.htm|title=The Ghost Ship – Carroll A. Deering|last=Admin|website=www.bermuda-attractions.com|access-date=2017-05-28}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1921-01-01"|1921 |[[Charles White Whittlesey|Charles Whittlesey]] |37 |The American [[soldier]] and [[Medal of Honor]] recipient who led the "[[Lost Battalion (World War I)|Lost Battalion]]" in [[World War I]] was last seen on the evening of 26 November 1921 on a passenger ship bound from [[New York City]] to [[Havana]]. It is presumed he committed suicide by jumping overboard. |- |data-sort-value="1922-01-01"| 1922 |[[Edward F. Sands]] |27 |Sands was a suspect in the murder of [[Hollywood]] director [[William Desmond Taylor]] on 1 February 1922, disappeared shortly after that, and was never seen again.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Badly Wanted |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,751984,00.html |quote=Edward F. Sands, 34, 5 ft 5 in., for the murder of William Desmond Taylor, cinema director, whose butler he was. Questioned in this case were Cinemactresses Mabel Normand, last to see Taylor alive, and Mary Miles Minter whose lingerie and love letters were found in the Taylor apartment. |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=26 August 1929|accessdate=2007-07-21}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1922-01-01"|1922 |[[Alejandro Carrascosa]] |21 |Carrascosa, an [[Argentines|Argentine]] [[poet]], [[writer]] and [[student]], disappeared on 22 September and left hints that he was not going to be seen again,<ref>Febrero, Enero, Alejandro Carrascosa (1923) Seven Nights, Editorial Atlántida p. 33.</ref> and indeed was not. |- |data-sort-value="1924-01-01"|1924 |[[Andrew Irvine (mountaineer)|Andrew Irvine]] |22 |The English mountaineer, who took part in the [[1924 British Mount Everest expedition]], was last seen high on the mountain's northeast ridge on 8 June 1924 and his body has not been found.<ref name="mountainzone.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mountainzone.com/everest/99/history.html|title=George Mallory and Andrew Irvine: Can they be found?|website=www.mountainzone.com|access-date=2017-05-28}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1924-01-01"|1924 |{{nowrap|[[Artur de Sacadura Cabral]]}} |43 |[[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] [[aviation]] pioneer, Artur de Sacadura Cabral, disappeared flying over the [[English Channel]] on 24 November and is believed to have died, since parts of the plane were found, although he was not.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vidaslusofonas.pt/sacadura_cabral2.htm|title=Sacadura Cabral (English version)|date=2012-08-15|access-date=2017-07-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815031249/http://www.vidaslusofonas.pt/sacadura_cabral2.htm|archivedate=15 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1924-01-01"|1924 |[[Liu Menggeng]] | |Menggeng, a politician and physician of the [[Taiwan|Republic of China]] and [[Manchukuo]], left office in 1924 and was never seen again.<ref>Xu main (2007), page 2508.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1925-01-01"|1925 |[[Sidney Reilly]] |47–48 |British spy Sidney Reilly set off for the [[Soviet Union]] in an attempt to overthrow the Bolshevik regime and was said to have been captured and shot on 5 November 1925 but it is not known for sure since no location of his body is known. The photo of him seen dead was said to be alleged and it was even speculated that he might have still been alive since there were later sightings of him.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://warfarehistorynetwork.com/daily/military-history/the-mysterious-sidney-reilly/|title=The Mysterious Sidney Reilly|website=warfarehistorynetwork.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-04}}</ref><ref>Adventures of a British Master Spy: The Memoirs of Sidney Reilly, (first published in 1932)</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1925-01-01"|1925 |[[Percy Fawcett]] |58 |Fawcett, a British [[Archaeology|archaeologist]] and [[List of explorers|explorer]], together with his eldest son Jack and friend Raleigh Rimell, was last seen traveling into the jungle of [[Mato Grosso]] in [[Brazil]] to search for a hidden city called the [[Lost City of Z]]. Several unconfirmed sightings and many conflicting reports and theories explaining their disappearance followed, but despite more than a dozen follow-up expeditions and the recovery of some of Fawcett's belongings, their fate remains a mystery.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/mar/21/research.brazil Veil lifts on jungle mystery of the colonel who vanished] ''guardian.co.uk – The Observer'' 2004-03-21, Vanessa Thorpe.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1925-01-01"|1925 |[[Frederick McDonald]] |53–54 |An Australian politician, McDonald set off from [[Martin Place, Sydney]], for a meeting with [[Jack Lang (Australian politician)|Jack Lang]] two blocks away but failed to arrive. He was possibly murdered by his political rival [[Thomas Ley]]. In 1947, Ley was convicted at the [[Old Bailey]] of the "Chalkpit Murder", that of a barman in England, and sentenced to hang but was then declared insane and sent to [[Broadmoor Hospital|Broadmoor]] high-security [[psychiatric hospital]], where he died of a [[cerebral hemorrhage]] two months later.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2004/s1095204.htm Lateline History Challenge: Minister for Murder] Australian Broadcasting Corporation, 2004-04-26, [[Margot O'Neill]] & Brett Evans.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1925-01-01"|1925 |[[Disappearance of Alice Corbett|Alice Corbett]] |19 |An American college student, Corbett was last seen leaving her residence on the campus of [[Smith College]] in [[Northampton, Massachusetts]] on the morning of November 13. Extensive searches of urban and wilderness areas across Western [[Massachusetts]] failed to yield any evidence of her fate. Her case received wide publicity though regional newspapers and national wire services. Her disappearance has the distinction of being the oldest active missing person case in the United States.<ref>{{cite news |title=Smith College Student Vanishes Strangely |agency=United Press |publisher=Binghamton Press |date=14 November 1925}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1926-01-01"|1926 |[[Disappearance of Marvin Clark|Marvin Clark]] |75 |A retired American sheriff, Clark disappeared in [[Portland, Oregon]], en route to visit his daughter by [[stagecoach]] during the [[Halloween]] weekend.<ref name=laine>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/crime/oldest-active-missing-persons-case-in-us-may-soon-be-solved/article/382517|work=Digital Journal|title=Oldest active missing persons case in U.S. may soon be solved|author=Laine, Martin|date=30 April 2014|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="1927-01-01"|1927 |[[Charles Nungesser]] |35 |rowspan="2"|Both French aviators disappeared with their aircraft ''[[L'Oiseau Blanc]]'' on 8 May 1927 while attempting a [[transatlantic flight]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/13/130509-charles-lindbergh-transatlantic-flight-white-bird-bernard-decre-safran-aviation/|title=Was Charles Lindbergh Second to Fly Across Atlantic?|date=2017-05-09|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref> |- |[[François Coli]] |44 |- |data-sort-value="1927-01-01"|1927 |[[Włodzimierz Zagórski (general)|Włodzimierz Zagórski]] |45 |An [[Austro-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] military intelligence officer, [[Poland|Polish]] brigadier general, staff officer and aviator disappeared on 6 August 1927 never to be seen again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&rurl=translate.google.ca&sl=pl&sp=nmt4&u=http://nowahistoria.interia.pl/kartka-z-kalendarza/news-6-sierpnia-1927-r-zaginal-general-wlodzimierz-zagorski,nId,2245480&usg=ALkJrhjelc0Es4G8cOid1hz5ZFIlDr6Jmw#|title=Google Translate|website=translate.googleusercontent.com|access-date=2017-07-22}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1927-01-01"|1927 |[[Paul Redfern]] |25 |An [[Americans|American]] musician and a pilot from [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia]], [[South Carolina]], who became known during the summer of 1927 for attempting to fly from [[Brunswick, Georgia|Brunswick]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] to [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]]. He disappeared after 25 August 1927 and was never seen again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rbscp.lib.rochester.edu/rochester-review/view-issue?y=1929&v=7&i=3&p=71|title=Rochester Reviews: View Issue {{!}} RBSCP|website=rbscp.lib.rochester.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-19}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1928-01-01"|1928 |[[Walter Collins]] |9 |Walter disappeared from his home in [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], in 1928. He was later determined to have been murdered by Gordon Stewart Northcott in what was known as the [[Wineville Chicken Coop Murders]]. His disappearance and the attempt by the Los Angeles police department to convince his mother that a different boy was her son formed the basis of the 2008 film ''[[Changeling (film)|Changeling]]''.<ref>[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/465341642.html?dids=465341642:465341642&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Apr+04%2C+1928pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=New+Kidnaping+Clew+Furnished+in+Hunt+for+Missing+Collins+Boy New Kidnaping Clew Furnished in Hunt for Missing Collins Boy] ''Los Angeles Times'' 4 April 1928.</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Foundas |first=Scott |title=Clint Eastwood: The Set Whisperer – Shooting quietly on the Changeling set |newspaper=[[LA Weekly]] |date=19 December 2007 |url=http://www.laweekly.com/film+tv/film/clint-eastwood-the-set-whisperer/17910/ |access-date=29 December 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223025728/http://www.laweekly.com/film+tv/film/clint-eastwood-the-set-whisperer/17910/ |archive-date=23 December 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=King |first=Susan |author-link=Susan King (journalist) |title=Changeling actor reveres his boss: Clint Eastwood |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=7 September 2008 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/sep/07/entertainment/ca-changeling7 |access-date=5 September 2008}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1928-01-01"|1928 |[[Roald Amundsen]] |55 |Amundsen disappeared with five crew members on 18 June 1928 while flying on a rescue mission in the [[Arctic]]. The search for Amundsen and team was called off in September 1928 by the [[Politics of Norway|Norwegian Government]]. No bodies were ever found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2013/jun/21/roald-amundsen-explorer-lost-arctic|title=From the archive, 21 June 1928: Roald Amundsen lost in the Arctic|date=2013-06-21|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-05-14|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="1928-01-01"|1928 |Glen Hyde |29 |rowspan="2"|The American newlyweds [[Glen and Bessie Hyde]] were last seen 18 November 1928 and disappeared while attempting to raft the [[Colorado River]] rapids of the [[Grand Canyon]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jun/29/news/cl-16386|title=What Really Happened to Bessie and Glen?|date=2001-06-29|work=LA Times|access-date=2017-07-02}}</ref> |- |Bessie Hyde |22 |}
==1930s== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- |data-sort-value="1930-01-01"|1930 |{{nowrap|[[Mary Agnes Moroney]]}} |2 |Mary Agnes went missing after her mother, a struggling 17-year-old mother of two, gave her to a stranger calling herself "Julia Otis" in exchange for $2 on 15 May 1930 on the understanding that the woman would take care of the girl in [[California]] for a short time and then return her to the Moroneys' [[Chicago]] home when things were better. She never did, and the ensuing investigation attracted national media attention. The girl was never located, and the case remains the oldest unsolved missing-persons case of this nature in the files of the Chicago Missing Persons Bureau.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2506&dat=19520904&id=iAJZAAAAIBAJ&pg=6373,692062 |title=Woman identified as kidnap victim in 1930 case |work=[[The Post and Courier|The News and Courier]] |date=4 September 1952 |agency=[[Evening Post Publishing Company|Evening Post Publishing]] |accessdate=15 January 2012 |location=Charleston |page=32}}</ref> A California woman's belief that she was Mary Agnes has subsequently been disproven by DNA testing.<ref name="Mary Agnes Moroney">{{cite web |url=http://charleyproject.org/cases/m/moroney_mary.html |title=Mary Agnes Moroney |publisher=charleyproject.org |work=The Charley Project |date=12 October 2004 |accessdate=22 June 2015 |author=Good, Meaghan |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623072001/http://charleyproject.org/cases/m/moroney_mary.html |archive-date=23 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1930-01-01"|1930 |[[Joseph Force Crater]] |41 |An [[associate justice]] of the [[New York Supreme Court]], Crater was last seen on 6 August after eating a meal at a restaurant. Judge Crater was never seen or heard from again. (His [[mistress (lover)|mistress]], Sally Lou Ritz, 22, was falsely said to have disappeared a few weeks later, but was interviewed by police as late as July 1937.<ref>[http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/r/ritz_sally.html The Charley Project: Sally Lou Ritz] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613070713/http://charleyproject.org/cases/r/ritz_sally.html |date=13 June 2010 }} 3 April 2005.</ref>) Crater's disappearance, which prompted one of the most sensational manhunts of the 20th century,<ref>[http://www.officer.com/article/article.jsp?id=25488&siteSection=1 1930 NYPD Cold Case 'Solved'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531164905/http://www.officer.com/article/article.jsp?id=25488&siteSection=1 |date=31 May 2008 }} ''OFFICER.com'' 2005-08-19, Larry Celona, Lorena Mongelli & Marsha Kranes (courtesy of ''New York Post'').</ref> was the subject of widespread media attention and a [[grand jury]] investigation. Crater was [[declared death in absentia|declared legally dead]] in 1939 and his missing persons file was officially closed in 1979; however, [[Cold case (criminology)|cold case squad]] detectives have investigated new leads as recently as 2005.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/20/nyregion/20crater.html Judge Crater Abruptly Appears, at Least in Public Consciousness] ''New York Times'' 2005-08-20, William K. Rashbaum.</ref> To "pull a Crater" became [[slang]] for a person vanishing. |- |data-sort-value="1932-01-01"|1931 |[[Joseph Ardizzone]] |46 |[[Los Angeles crime family]] boss, vanished while driving from his home to pick up a relative 15 October 1931; declared legally dead 7 years later, no trace of him was ever found. |- |data-sort-value="1932-01-01"|1932 |[[Jack Black (author)|Jack Black]] |c. 61 |Author Jack Black is believed to have committed suicide in 1932 by drowning after as he reportedly told his friends that if life got too grim, he would row out into [[New York Harbor]] and, with weights tied to his feet, drop overboard. |- |data-sort-value="1933-01-01"|1933 |[[Julien Torma]] |30 |A French [[Dadaist]] writer, Julien Torma never returned from a 17 February trip into the Austrian [[Tirol, Austria|Tyrol]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yB43H0u4slwC&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85#v=onepage&q=Julien%20Torma%20disappeared%20in%201933|title=How it was Done in Paris: Russian Émigré Literature and French Modernism|last=Livak|first=Leonid|date=2003|publisher=Univ of Wisconsin Press|isbn=9780299185145|language=en}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1933-01-01"|1933 |[[C. B. Johnston]] |c.38 |Johnston, American college athlete and coach, sent a postcard to his wife from [[Zanesville, Ohio]], saying he was on his way to Chicago to publish a book after being fired as head football coach of what is now [[Appalachian State University]]. No one heard from him after that.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clydejohnston.com/granddad.htm |title=Searching for Grandfather Clement Bernard "Johnnie" Johnston |publisher=Clydejohnston.com |date= |accessdate=21 January 2012}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1934-01-01"|1934 |[[Wallace Fard Muhammad]] |43 |Founder of the [[Nation of Islam]], Muhammad left [[Detroit]] and was never heard from again.<ref>[http://foia.fbi.gov/foiaindex/fard.htm Wallace D. Fard] Federal Bureau of Investigation – Freedom of Information Privacy Act.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1934-01-01"|1934 |[[Everett Ruess]] |20 |Everett Ruess, a young American artist, disappeared while traveling through the deserts of [[Utah]] and was never seen again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kensandersbooks.com/shop/rarebooks/everett-ruess.html|title=Everett Ruess – Ken Sanders Rare Books – A full service antiquarian bookshop in downtown Salt Lake City, Utah.|website=www.kensandersbooks.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-14|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415170705/http://www.kensandersbooks.com/shop/rarebooks/everett-ruess.html|archivedate=15 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="NPR">{{cite web|title=Mystery Endures: Remains Found Not Those Of Artist|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/storystory.php?storyId=114123077|website=Weekend Edition Saturday|publisher=NPR.org|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1934-11-22"|1934 |[[The Disappearance of Etta Riel|Etta Riel]] |20 |Riel was an American woman who vanished from [[Worcester, Massachusetts]] on the day of a scheduled paternity hearing against her former boyfriend. The case was complicated by anonymous telephone calls placed to a local train station the night of her disappearance and a telegram sent to her attorney weeks later from an unknown individual impersonating her. Extensive police searches across Central Massachusetts failed to locate her and the case was never solved.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Donn |first1=Jeff |title=Daughter Still Haunted by Mother's Disappearance Nearly 60 Years Ago |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-03-07/news/mn-8239_1_state-paternity-law |accessdate=12 August 2018 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=7 March 1993}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="1935-01-01"|1935 |[[Charles Kingsford Smith]] |38 |rowspan="2"|Australian pioneer aviator Charles Kingsford Smith and co-pilot Tommy Pethybridge disappeared during an overnight flight from [[Allahabad]], India, to [[Singapore]] while attempting to break the England–Australia speed record. Eighteen months later, Burmese fishermen found an undercarriage leg and wheel (with its tire still inflated) on the shoreline of Aye Island in the [[Andaman Sea]], {{convert|3|km|0|abbr=on}} off the southeast coastline of Burma, which [[Lockheed Corporation|Lockheed]] confirmed to be from their [[Lockheed Altair]], the ''[[Lady Southern Cross]]''. Botanists who examined the weeds clinging to it estimated that the aircraft itself lies not far from the island at a depth of approximately {{convert|15|fathom|0|abbr=on}}.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,771071,00.html By Aye] ''TIME'' 6 June 1938.</ref> A filmmaker claimed to have located ''Lady Southern Cross'' on the seabed in February 2009.<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/story/0,27574,25218600-421,00.html "Sir Charles Kingsford Smith's final resting place found, says film crew"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090323040728/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C27574%2C25218600-421%2C00.html |date=23 March 2009 }} ''The Daily Telegraph'' 2009-03-21, Justin Vallejo.</ref> |- |Tommy Pethybridge | |- |data-sort-value="1935-01-01"|1935 |[[Li Yuan (mayor)|Li Yuan]] | |Li Yuan was a politician of the [[Taiwan|Republic of China]] (and later [[Manchukuo]]) who disappeared in 1935. The circumstances of his later life and death are unknown.<ref>{{Cite book|author=Xu Youchun (main ed.)|title=Unabridged Biographical Dictionary of the Republic, Revised and Enlarged Version|year=2007|publisher=[[Hebei]] People's Press (Hebei Renmin Chubanshe; |isbn=978-7-202-03014-1}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1936-01-01"|1936 |[[Jean Mermoz]] |35 |French air pilot Jean Mermoz went missing on 7 December 1936 while flying his [[Latécoère 300]] ''Croix-du-Sud'' near [[Aubenton|Aubenton, Aisne]]. It is assumed that the plane crashed in the sea, but it is unconfirmed since his body was never recovered.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://books.google.cl/books?id=Wxl-CwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA184|title=Radio and the Politics of Sound in Interwar France, 1921–1939|last=Scales|first=Rebecca|access-date=2017-11-20|page=184|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1937-01-01"|1937 |[[Juliet Stuart Poyntz]] |50 |An American [[Communism|communist]] and intelligence agent for the [[Soviet Union]] Juliet Poyntz disappeared on 3 June 1937. A police investigation turned up no clues to her fate, and her belongings, all of her clothing and hand luggage in her room appeared to be untouched.<ref>Kern, Gary, A Death in Washington, p. 163.</ref><ref name="Gitlow, Benjamin 1948">Gitlow, Benjamin, ''The Whole of Their Lives; Communism in America—a Personal History and Intimate Portrayal of its Leaders'', New York: Charles Scribner's Sons (1948)</ref> |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="1937-01-01"|1937 |[[Amelia Earhart]] |39 |rowspan="2"|The famous American [[aviator]] Amelia Earhart was the first woman to try a [[circumnavigation]]al flight of the globe. During the attempt she and her [[navigator]], Fred Noonan, disappeared over the central Pacific in the vicinity of [[Howland Island]] on 2 July 1937.<ref name="HisV">{{cite web|title=What Happened to Amelia Earhart?|url=http://www.history.com/topics/what-happened-to-amelia-earhart|website=History Valut|publisher=History.com|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> |- |[[Fred Noonan]] |44 |- |data-sort-value="1937-01-01"|1937 |[[Sigizmund Levanevsky]] |35 |Sigizmund Levanevsky, a famous [[USSR|Soviet]] aviator, with his crew of five and their [[Bolkhovitinov DB-A]] aircraft disappeared in the vicinity of the [[North Pole]]. They had reported a loss of power from one of their four [[Mikulin AM-34]] engines while attempting to prove a trans[[polar route]] between [[Asia]] and [[North America]] commercially viable.<ref>[http://www.check-six.com/lib/Famous_Missing/Levanevsky.htm Sigismund Levanevsky] ''Check-Six.com''.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1938-01-01"|1938 |[[Ettore Majorana]] |32 |An Italian physicist, Majorana disappeared in unknown circumstances during a boat trip from [[Palermo]] to [[Naples]] on 25 March 1938. There is some evidence that he was alive in South America in 1959 and that his disappearance was voluntary.<ref name="science20">{{cite web|title=Ettore Majorana: The Mystery Might Be Solved |url=http://www.science20.com/quantum_diaries_survivor/ettore_majorana_mystery_might_be_solved-79823|website=science 2.0|accessdate=18 April 2017}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1938-01-01"|1938 |[[Willie McLean (soccer, born 1904)|Willie McLean]] |34 |A [[Scottish people|Scottish]]-born [[United States|American]] [[soccer]] player, Willie McLean disappeared without a trace in the summer of 1938,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.exploringlifesmysteries.com/mysterious-disappearances/#willie-mclean|title=Many Disappearances Worldwide Remain Unsolved {{!}} Exploring Lifes Mysteries|date=2012-01-21|work=Exploring Lifes Mysteries|access-date=2017-07-23|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |1938 |[[Disappearance of Alfred Beilhartz|Alfred Beilhartz]] |4 |American child who while on vacation with his family at [[Rocky Mountain National Park]] in [[Colorado]]. vanished on 2 July, and has not been seen since. |- |data-sort-value="1939-01-01"|1939 |[[Barbara Newhall Follett]] |25 |Barbara Follett was an American child prodigy novelist. Her first novel, ''The House Without Windows'', was drafted when she was eight and completed and published in 1927 when she was twelve years old. Her next novel, ''The Voyage of the Norman D.'', received critical acclaim when she was fourteen. She continued to write as an adult including travelogues and a romance called ''Lost Island''. In 1939 at aged 25, and despondent over her husband's unfaithfulness, she walked out of her apartment with thirty dollars ($528 in 2017) and was never seen again.<ref>[http://www.farksolia.org/ Official Barbara Follett website], run by her nephew Stefan Cooke.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1939-01-01"|1939 |[[Lloyd L. Gaines]] |28 |Lloyd L. Gaines was a central figure in the legal case ''[[Missouri ex rel. Gaines v. Canada]]'', which was an early success for the [[African-American Civil Rights Movement (1896–1954)|U.S. civil rights movement]]. One evening, he left his [[Alpha Phi Alpha]] fraternity house in [[Chicago]], having told the housekeeper he was going to buy some stamps, and was never seen or heard from again. Some accounts suggest he was living in New York or Mexico City in the late 1940s.<ref name="Riverfront Times story">{{cite news|last=Garrison |first=Chad |title=The Mystery of Lloyd Gaines |url=http://www.riverfronttimes.com/content/printVersion/220398/ |newspaper=[[The Riverfront Times]] |publisher=[[Village Voice Media]] |location=[[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis, MO]] |date=4 April 2007 |accessdate=5 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305102655/http://www.riverfronttimes.com/content/printVersion/220398/ |archivedate=5 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1939-01-01"|1939 |[[Richard Halliburton]] |39 |Halliburton vanished on 20 March, while attempting to sail the ''Sea Dragon'', a Chinese junk, across the Pacific Ocean. In 1945 wreckage identified as a rudder, and believed to belong to the ''Sea Dragon'', washed ashore in [[San Diego]]. |- |data-sort-value="1939-01-01"|1939 |[[William Snodgrass (politician)|William Snodgrass]] |68-69 |Snodgrass, a New Zealand politician, disappeared from the interisland ferry ''[[Arahura (twin screw ship)|Arahura]]'' while travelling overnight from Wellington to Nelson on 20 March 1939.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19390322.2.110?end_date=31-12-1939&page=2&query=Snodgrass&start_date=01-01-1939|accessdate=20 November 2018|title=Lost Overboard|date=22 March 1939|publisher=''The New Zealand Herald'' - archived at PapersPast - paperspast.co.nz}}</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1939-01-01"|1939 |[[Rita Gorgonowa]] |38 | Rita Gorgonowa, a [[governess]] who was convicted of murdering a child in her care, disappeared after being released from [[prison]] on 3 September 1939 and was not seen again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.ca/translate?sl=pl&u=http://www.nowastrategia.org.pl/rita-gorgonowa-i-najglosniejszy-proces-sadowy-ii-rzeczypospolitej/|title=Google Translate|website=translate.google.ca|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref> |- |}
==1940s== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- | data-sort-value="1940-01-01"|1940 |[[Elroy Guckert]] |40 |An [[American football]] and [[basketball]] coach who is said to have died in 1940 when he disappeared from ship but his body was never recovered and he was never seen, so his fate remains unknown.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Michigan Alumnus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H_rhAAAAMAAJ(Den-+ison+University)+'22.+A.M.+(Columbia+University)+'27,+Instructor+in+Sociology+1928-1930,+disappeared+from+ship+September+3.+1940;+aged+42.******%22|year=1941|publisher=UM Libraries|page=385|id=UOM:39015071120904}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1941-01-01"|1941 |[[Thomas C. Latimore]] |51 |American naval officer Thomas C. Latimore, who was captain of the {{USS|Dobbin}} and the 24th (22nd unique) [[Governor of American Samoa]], disappeared in [[Hawaii]] believed to be in July 1941<ref>{{cite web|url=http://flattopshistorywarpolitics.yuku.com/topic/509/The-Captain-Vanishes|title=The Captain Vanishes in Annapolis Forum|website=Yuku|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1941-01-01"|1941 |[[Jaan Tõnisson]] |72 |As one of the foremost [[Estonia]]n political leaders, Tõnisson was arrested during the [[Soviet occupation of the Baltic states|Soviet occupation]] and was thought to have been shot but his exact whereabouts after that remains unknown.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pUawCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA465&lpg=PA465#v=onepage&q=jaan%20t%C3%B5nisson%20fate%20is%20unknown|title=Historical Dictionary of Estonia|last=Miljan|first=Toivo|date=2015-05-21|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780810875135|language=en}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1941-01-01"|1941 |[[Alexandru Robot|Alter Rotmann]] |25–26 |Rotmann, a [[Romania]]n, [[Moldova]]n and [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] poet, was last seen in August 1941 in [[Odessa|Odessa, Ukrainian SSR]] and is believed to have died after that.<ref>Colesnic, p.72.</ref> |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="1942-01-01"|1942 |Lt. Ernest Cody | |rowspan="2"|On 16 August, U.S. Navy blimp ''[[L-class blimp|L-8]]'' drifted inland from its route doing antisubmarine patrol off the coast of [[California]] near [[San Francisco]] several hours after its crew, Lt. Ernest Cody and Ens. Charles Adams, radioed in that they were going to take a closer look at an oil slick. When the ship eventually crashed in [[Daly City, California|Daly City]], neither man was aboard. A massive search failed to find any trace of them; they were both declared dead a year later.<ref name="CheckSixL-8">{{cite web |url=http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/L-8_crash_site.htm|title=The Crash of Navy Blimp L-8|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=Check Six|date=May 2008}}</ref> |- |Ens. Charles Adams | |- | data-sort-value="1942-01-01"|1942 |[[James Litterick]] |41 |Litterick was the first member of the [[Communist Party of Canada]] (CPC) elected to the [[Manitoba]] provincial parliament. By the time that the CPC was banned in 1940 and Litterick formally expelled from the legislature he had already gone into hiding and become the subject of a [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] manhunt.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qSunRNFcAZ8C&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105#v=onepage&q=James%20Litterick%20was%20never%20found|title=Joe Zuken, Citizen and Socialist|last=Smith|first=Doug|date=1990-01-01|publisher=James Lorimer & Company|isbn=9781550283037|language=en}}</ref><ref name="golden">{{cite news |url=http://manitobia.ca/content/en/newspapers/WPT/1943/03/22/articles/140.xml/iarchives |title=Under the Golden Boy – Manitoba's M.L.A.'s |newspaper=Winnipeg Evening Tribune |date=22 March 1943 |page=11 |accessdate=2013-04-12}}</ref> Litterick surrendered to the RCMP during 1942 and was held at the [[Don Jail]] in [[Toronto]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://manitobia.ca/content/en/newspapers/WPT/1942/09/25/articles/13.xml/iarchives |title=Tim Buck, Jim Litterick Give Selves Up |newspaper=Winnipeg Evening Tribune |date=25 September 1942 |page=11 |accessdate=2013-04-12}}</ref> The following year he was reported to be working at a garment factory in Toronto but nothing further appears to be known about him.<ref name="golden"/> |- | data-sort-value="1943-01-01"|1943 |[[Dan Billany]] |30 |An [[English people|English]] [[novelist]], Billany was last heard from in 1943. He was last seen 20 November 1943 in [[Capistrello|Capistrello, Italy]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.danbillany.com/books-by-dan-billany/the-cage|title=The Cage|website=Dan Billany – Hull's Lost Hero|language=en|access-date=2017-07-24}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1943-01-01"|1943 |[[Abraham Gancwajch]] |41–42 |Abraham Gancwajch, a prominent [[Nazi collaborator]] in the [[Warsaw Ghetto]] during the [[occupation of Poland]] in World War II and a [[Jewish]] "kingpin" of the ghetto underworld, was last seen in 1943 and is rumored to have been killed.<ref name="Baron">{{cite book |author=Lawrence Baron |title=Projecting the Holocaust into the Present: The Changing Focus of Contemporary Holocaust Cinema |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |year=2005 |ISBN=0-7425-4333-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U9b7r0QFCagC&pg=PA83 |via=Google Print |page=83}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://loveforlife.com.au/content/08/10/03/abraham-gancwajch-13-nazi-collaborators-warsaw-ghetto-holocaust-education-archive-r|title=Abraham Gancwajch – The "13" – Nazi Collaborators In The Warsaw Ghetto by The Holocaust Education & Archive Research Team {{!}} Love for Life|website=loveforlife.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-07-15}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1943-01-01"|1943 |[[Endre Rudnyánszky]] |57–58 |A [[Hungary|Hungarian]] [[lawyer]], military officer, and [[communism|communist]] Rudnyánszky was last seen in Russia in 1943. It is believed that he may have died that year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.marxists.org/archive/broue/1997/xx/5yearson.htm#n58|title=Pierre Broué: Five Years On (1997)|last=Broue|first=Pierre|website=www.marxists.org|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1943-01-01"|1943 |[[Moriz Seeler]] | |Moriz Seeler, a [[Germans|German]] [[poet]], [[writer]] and [[film producer]], disappeared in 1943 when he was said to have been deported by the Nazis to Latvia. He went missing from the capital city of [[Riga]] and is believed to have been murdered.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.poemhunter.com/moriz-seeler/biography/|title=Moriz Seeler – Moriz Seeler Biography – Poem Hunter|website=www.poemhunter.com|access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Herschel Grynszpan]] |22 |Herschel Grynszpan was the Jewish exile from Germany whose 1938 assassination of diplomat [[Ernst vom Rath]] in [[Paris|Paris, France]] was the trigger for [[Kristallnacht]] in Germany. For various reasons, largely legal delays, a planned trial was never held in either France or (after 1940) Germany during which Grynszpan was held in various prisons and concentration camps. [[Adolf Eichmann]] testified at his 1961 trial in Jerusalem that he had interrogated Grynszpan in [[Magdeburg]] in either late 1943 or early 1944 but after that there is no record of his whereabouts or ultimate fate. The West German government had him declared legally dead in 1960.<ref name="Herschel Grynszpan">{{cite news|last=Davidson|first=Lyn|title=Jewish teen who dared to retaliate given his due|url=http://www.jweekly.com/includes/print/70005/article/jewish-teen-who-dared-to-retaliate-given-his-due/|newspaper=[[Jweekly]]|date=31 October 2013|accessdate=7 November 2013}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Rocco Perri]] |56 |An [[organized crime]] figure in [[Ontario]], Perri was last seen alive in [[Hamilton, Ontario]] on 23 April 1944. His body has never been found and there was speculation that he was murdered by being thrown into [[Hamilton Harbour]] after he was fitted with [[cement shoes]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thespec.com/community-story/6870542-april-23-1944-hamilton-mobster-rocco-perri-disappears/|title=April 23, 1944: Hamilton mobster Rocco Perri disappears|publisher=thespec.com|date=23 September 2016|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[USS Robalo|USS ''Robalo'' crewmen]] | |Although the U.S. Navy claimed the submarine USS ''Robalo'' was lost with all hands after failing to report while on a July 1944 patrol in [[the Philippines]], Lt. Cmdr. [[Manning Kimmel]] (31) and three other crewmen are known to have survived. A note recovered by an Army [[prisoner of war]] claimed the four had been arrested as spies after reaching [[Palawan Island]] following the ''Robalo''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s 26 July collision with a Japanese mine just offshore. Another witness account says they were [[Palawan massacre|massacred following an air raid]] later that year but Japanese records do not indicate they were being held at the camp in question at that time. It is believed that they were killed in captivity but officially their fate is still unknown.<ref name="Manning Kimmel">{{cite book|last1=Blair|first1=Clay Jr.|title=Silent Victory: The U.S. Submarine War Against Japan|date=1975|publisher=[[Naval Institute Press]]|isbn=9781557502179|page=688|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KGjfqe6DcrEC}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |{{nowrap|[[Antoine de Saint-Exupéry]]}} |44 |French author Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, who disappeared over the [[Mediterranean]] on a reconnaissance mission during July 1944, is believed to have died at that time.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.biography.com/news/the-little-prince-antoine-de-saint-exupery-facts|title=The Mysterious 'Little Prince': 5 Facts About Author Antoine de Saint-Exupéry|work=Biography.com|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en-us}}</ref> In August, an unidentifiable body, wearing French uniform, was found in the sea near [[Carqueiranne]] and was buried there. In 2000, the wreckage of the aircraft flown by Saint-Exupéry was found on the seabed near [[Marseille]]. |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Disappearance of Sheila Fox|Sheila Fox]] |6 |Sheila Fox disappeared in [[Farnworth]], [[Bolton]], [[Lancashire]], England on 18 August 1944. Witnesses claim they saw Sheila riding on the handlebars of a bike being pedalled by a 25–30-year-old man. In 2001 a witness came forward claiming he saw a local resident digging a hole in the area where Sheila disappeared on his property. The property owner was revealed to have been convicted of rape and child molestation but Sheila's remains weren't found.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dig for wartime girl's body resumed|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1370907.stm|accessdate=13 May 2017|work=BBC News|date=6 June 2001}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Ina Benita]] |32 |Ina Benita, a [[Poland|Polish]] actress of the [[interwar period]], was last seen during the [[Warsaw Uprising]] in August 1944. She allegedly went down into a sewage canal and drowned but this is not known for sure since her body was never recovered.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://filmpolski.pl/fp/index.php?osoba=1180369|title=FilmPolski.pl|work=FilmPolski|access-date=2017-08-17|language=pl}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Johan Pitka]] |72 |Johan Pitka, a famous [[Estonia]]n military commander from the [[Estonian War of Independence]] until [[World War II]], disappeared in September 1944, and is believed to have been killed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nauticapedia.ca/Gallery/Admiral_Pitka.php|title=Johan Pitka|website=www.nauticapedia.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Gertrude Tompkins Silver]] |33 |Gertrude Tompkins Silver is the only [[Women Airforce Service Pilots]] member to go missing during World War II.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Slater|first1=Stefan|title=The Lost Wasp – Southbay|url=https://southbay.goldenstate.is/the-lost-wasp/|accessdate=28 January 2018|work=Southbay|date=16 September 2014}}</ref> She departed from Mines Field ([[Los Angeles International Airport]]) for Palm Springs, on 26 October 1944, flying a [[North American P-51 Mustang|P-51D Mustang]] destined for New Jersey. She never arrived at Palm Springs and due to reporting errors, a search for her was not started until three days later. Despite an extensive ground and water search no trace of Gertrude or the aircraft were found.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Merl|first1=Jean|title=Mystery in the Sky|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/sep/14/local/me-32250|accessdate=28 January 2018|work=Los Angeles Times|date=14 September 1997}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Glenn Miller]] |40 |An American big band leader and recording artist, Miller disappeared on the night of 15 December 1944 in a US Army [[Noorduyn Norseman|UC-64 Norseman]] aircraft that vanished over the English Channel while en route from UK to Paris, France. Miller was on the flight to make arrangements for his band to entertain Allied servicemen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/Explore/Notable-Graves/Other-Prominent-Figures/Glenn-Miller|title=Glenn Miller|website=arlingtoncemetery.mil|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-berkshire-16517128|title=Glenn Miller clue found in Reading plane-spotter's log|last=Serck|first=Linda|date=2012-01-11|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Erna Petermann]] |31–32 |Erna Petermann was a high-ranking female overseer at two [[Nazi concentration camp]]s during the closing of [[World War II]]. She was last seen in 1944 and was never heard from again.<ref>Daniel Patrick Brown, ''The Camp Women: The Female Auxiliaries Who Assisted the SS in Running the Nazi Concentration Camp System,'' [[Schiffer Publishing]], 2002, {{ISBN|0-7643-1444-0}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Mieczysław Kosmowski]] | |Mieczysław Kosmowski was a Polish postmaster turned [[Gestapo]] agent during the occupation of Poland by Nazi Germany in World War II. Operating under the code name "Gienek", he was responsible for a number of German massacres against former Polish soldiers and Jews. Kosmowski was last seen in late 1944 when the German army evacuated [[Bydgoszcz]]. The Polish government searched for Kosmowski between 1957 and 2009, without success.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pch24.pl/niemcy-organizowali-pogrom-w-jedwabnem--przypadek-agenta-kosmowskiego-vel-krause,53876,i.html|title=Niemcy organizowali pogrom w Jedwabnem. Przypadek agenta Kosmowskiego vel Krause|website=Pch24.pl|accessdate=21 October 2018}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1944-01-01"|1944 |[[Karla Mayer]] |35–36 |Karla Mayer was a [[Germans|German]] [[prison guard|guard]] at three [[Nazism|Nazi]] [[death camp]]s during the World War II. She disappeared in 1944 and her fate remains a mystery.<ref>Brown, Daniel Patrick (2002). The Camp Women: The Female Auxiliaries Who Assisted the SS in Running the Nazi Concentration Camp System. Schiffer Publishing. {{ISBN|0-7643-1444-0}}.</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Szilveszter Matuska]] |52–53 |A [[Hungarians|Hungarian]] mass murderer and mechanical engineer who reportedly escaped from jail in [[Vác]] in 1944.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://loanpride.com/elusive-criminals-escaped-law/|title=Elusive Criminals Who Escaped The Law – Loan Pride|date=2017-06-26|work=Loan Pride|access-date=2017-07-16|language=en-US}}</ref> In 1945, according to some reports, he served as an explosives expert during the latter stages of [[World War II]] but he was never recaptured and his fate is unknown. |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Heinrich Müller (Gestapo)|Heinrich Müller]] |45 | Müller, a [[Nazism|Nazi]] [[Gestapo]] chief, was last seen in the [[Führerbunker]] on the evening of 1 May 1945. While there he had stated that his intention was to avoid being taken into custody by the Soviet forces advancing on Berlin. His [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] file and related documents state that while the record is "...inconclusive on Müller's ultimate fate... [he] most likely died in Berlin in early May 1945."<ref>[https://www.archives.gov/iwg/declassified-records/rg-263-cia-records/rg-263-mueller.html Analysis of the Name File of Heinrich Mueller], [[National Archives and Records Administration]] – [[Timothy Naftali]], [[Miller Center of Public Affairs]], [[University of Virginia]]; [[Norman J.W. Goda]], [[Ohio University]]; [[Richard Breitman]], [[American University]]; [[Robert Wolfe]], National Archives (ret.).</ref> Other theories have suggested that he either escaped to South America like many other fugitive Nazis and lived out his life there (the Israelis continued to investigate his whereabouts into the 1960s) or was protected by U.S. or Soviet intelligence under a new identity. He is the most senior Nazi official whose fate is unknown. |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Constanze Manziarly]] |25 |A cook and dietitian for [[Adolf Hitler]], Constanze Manziarly disappeared on 2 May 1945 while escaping [[Berlin]] following the [[Battle of Berlin|Soviet invasion]] and fall of [[Nazi Germany]]. She was believed to have been raped and shot by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] soldiers in an [[Berlin U-Bahn|U-Bahn subway]] tunnel.<ref>{{cite book|last=Junge|first=Traudl| authorlink=Traudl Junge|title=Until the Final Hour, Hitler's Last Secretary|year=2004|page= 219|isbn=1-55970-728-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ie1FsnzQkfUC&pg=PA219}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Hildegard Neumann]] |26 |Neumann, a chief overseer at several [[Nazi concentration camps]], transition camps and detention camps, disappeared in May 1945 after she left the [[Ravensbrück concentration camp]]. It is claimed that she died in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fold3.com/page/286020537_ravensbrueck|title=Ravensbrueck|publisher=Fold3.com|accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Supriyadi]] |22 |Supriyadi was disappeared after the [[1945 PETA Revolt in Blitar|failed PETA revolt against Japanese occupation]] on 14 February 1945. Later that year, he was named Minister for People's Security in the [[Presidential Cabinet (Indonesia)|first cabinet formed]] by the newly declaring-independence [[Indonesia]]. However, he failed to appear and was replaced on 20 October 1945 by [[ad interim]] minister Muhammad Soeljoadikusuma. To this day his fate remains unknown.<ref name="SUDARMANTO2312">Sudarmanto (1996), pp. 231–232.</ref><ref name="SIMANJUNTAK18">Simanjuntak (2003), p. 18.</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Genrikh Lyushkov]] |45 |Genrikh Lyushkov was high-level [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] defector and former [[Russian Far East|Far East]] [[NKVD]] chief. A participant in the [[Great Purge]] he fled, to avoid what he believed would be arrest and execution, into the [[Japan]]ese [[puppet state]] of [[Manchukuo]]. After his defection he became a military consultant and analyst for the [[Imperial Japanese Army]]. He disappeared during the [[Soviet invasion of Manchuria]] and was reported as being last seen in a crowded train station in Dairen ([[Dalian]]) in August 1945. Several theories exist about his fate, but he is presumed to have died in 1945, killed by either Soviet or Japanese forces.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Coox |first=Alvin D. |authorlink=Alvin Coox |date=January 1968 |title=L'Affaire Lyushkov: Anatomy of a Defector |journal=[[Soviet Studies]] |volume=19 |issue=3 |pages=405–420 |publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] |issn=0038-5859 |jstor=149953|doi=10.1080/09668136808410603}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Alfred Partikel]] |57 |A [[Germans|German]] painter Partikel disappeared while picking mushrooms in the [[Darß|woods near Ahrenshoop]] on 20 October 1945 and was never seen again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://art.famsf.org/alfred-partikel|title=Alfred Partikel|date=2015-05-08|work=FAMSF Explore the Art|access-date=2017-07-25|language=en}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Sodder children disappearance|Sodder children]] | |Five of the nine Sodder children, aged 5 through 14, who lived in their parents' home outside [[Fayetteville, West Virginia]], were presumed to have died in a [[Christmas Eve]] fire that destroyed the house. However, no remains were found in the ashes the morning after the fire and some small bone fragments found during subsequent investigations turned out to have been planted. Later reported sightings of some of the children and suspicions that the fire had been arson rather than an accident led the family to believe that the children were still alive. The family kept a billboard offering a reward for information on their fate up at the house site until the late 1980s.<ref name="Sodder children">{{cite news|last=Abbott|first=Karen|title=The Children Who Went Up In Smoke|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/the-children-who-went-up-in-smoke-172429802/|newspaper=[[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian]]|date=25 December 2012|accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1945-01-01"|1945 |[[Johnny Jebsen]] |28 |Johnny Jebsen was an anti-Nazi German intelligence officer and British double agent (code name Artist) during the Second World War. Jebsen recruited Dušan Popov (who became the British agent Tricycle) to the Abwehr and through him later joined the Allied cause. Kidnapped from Lisbon by the Germans shortly before D-Day, Jebsen was tortured in prison and spent time in a concentration camp before disappearing, presumed killed, at the end of the war.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/defying-torture-doomed-to-the-camps-the-german-who-kept-the-allies-biggest-secret-gfkqt8dhj82 |title=Defying torture, doomed to the camps, the German who kept the Allies' biggest secret |publisher=The Times |date=24 March 2012 |accessdate=3 December 2017}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1946-01-01"|1946 |[[Paula Jean Welden]] |18 |The [[Bennington College]] [[Sophomore year|sophomore]] disappeared while walking on the [[Long Trail]] near [[Glastenbury Mountain]], [[Vermont]], US.<ref>[http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/w/welden_paula.html The Charley Project: Paula Jean Welden] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212022421/http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/w/welden_paula.html |date=12 December 2009 }} 18 September 2007.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/1784dfvt.html |title=Paula Jean Welden |publisher=The Doe Network |date=1 December 1946 |accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1947-01-01"|1947 |[[Daniel S. Voorhees]] |33–34 |Voorhees, a transient restaurant [[Porter (carrier)|porter]] who confessed to the murder of [[Elizabeth Short]], checked out of a hotel in [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], on the morning of 16 January 1947 and was never seen again.<ref>Beth Short Slaying Suspect Jailed After Asserting Admission of Crime, 29 January 1947, Pg. 2.</ref> |- |data-sort-value="1947-01-01"|1947 |[[1947 Glazier–Higgins–Woodward tornadoes|Joan Gay Croft]] |4 |In the aftermath of the Glazier–Higgins–Woodward tornadoes on 9 April 1947 4-year-old Joan Gay Croft and her sister Jerri were among refugees taking shelter in a basement hallway of the Woodward hospital. As officials sent the injured to different hospitals in the area, two men took Joan away saying they were taking her to Oklahoma City. She was never seen again and, over the years, several women have come forth saying they suspect they might be Joan. None of their claims have been verified.<ref>Mike Coppock, [http://www.okgazette.com/oklahoma/article-187-sixty-years-after-woodward-tornado-girls-kidnapping-unsolved.html Sixty years after Woodward tornado, girl's kidnapping unsolved.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017101859/http://okgazette.com/oklahoma/article-187-sixty-years-after-woodward-tornado-girls-kidnapping-unsolved.html |date=17 October 2014 }} ''Oklahoma Gazette'', 3 April 2007.</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=348&dat=19940415&id=YUMvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CjMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6966,4253787 Woman may be girl stolen after tornado.] ''Rome News-Tribune'', 15 April 1994.</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1947-01-01"|1947 |[[Raoul Wallenberg]] |32 |A [[Sweden|Swedish]] diplomat credited with saving the lives of at least 20,000 [[Hungarian Jews]] during the [[Holocaust]], Raoul Wallenberg was arrested on espionage charges in Budapest following the arrival of the Soviet army. His fate remains a mystery despite hundreds of purported sightings in Soviet prisons, some as recent as the 1980s. In 2001, after 10 years of research, a Swedish-Russian panel concluded that Wallenberg probably died or was executed in Soviet custody on 17 July 1947 but to date no hard evidence has been found to confirm this.<ref>[http://archives.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/europe/scandinavia/01/12/wallenberg.finding/index.html Wallenberg fate shrouded in mystery] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026081732/http://archives.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/europe/scandinavia/01/12/wallenberg.finding/index.html |date=26 October 2007 }} ''CNN'' 12 January 2001.</ref> In 2010, evidence from Russian archives surfaced suggesting he was alive after the presumed execution date.<ref>{{cite news |author=Arthur Max and Karl Ritter |title=New evidence on WWII mystery of Raoul Wallenberg |url=http://www.salon.com/wires/allwires/2010/04/01/D9EQBH1O0_eu_sweden_wallenberg_mystery/ |work=[[Salon (magazine)|Salon]] |date=1 April 2010 |accessdate=29 May 2010}}{{dead link|date=March 2017}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1947"|1947 |[[Lai Teck]] |45–46 |Lai Teck, a leader of the [[Communist Party of Malaya]] and [[Malayan People's Anti-Japanese Army]], disappeared in 1947 and is believed to have been killed.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cIz9Cfk0T0MC&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32#v=onepage&q=Lai%20Teck%20disappeared%20in%201947|title=Malaya's Secret Police 1945–60: The Role of the Special Branch in the Malayan Emergency|last=Comber|first=Leon|date=2008|publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|isbn=9789812308290|language=en}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1948-01-01"|1948 |[[Arthur Coningham (RAF officer)|Sir Arthur Coningham]] |53 |A retired [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] [[Air Marshal]], Sir Arthur Coningham disappeared when a [[Avro Tudor|Avro Tudor IV]] [[G-AHNP "Star Tiger"|G-AHNP ''Star Tiger'']] went missing over the western Atlantic.<ref>[http://www.rafweb.org/Biographies/Coningham.htm Air Marshal Sir Arthur Coningham] rafweb.org.</ref> He was one of 25 passengers, together with six crewmen, who were lost when the flight from [[Santa Maria Airport (Azores)|Santa Maria Airport]] in the [[Azores]] failed to reach its destination of [[Kindley Air Force Base|Kindley Field]], [[Bermuda]].<ref>[http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19480130-0 Avro 688 Tudor 1 G-AHNP western Atlantic Ocean] ''Aviation Safety Network'' 13 March 2004.</ref> ''Star Tiger'''s sister aircraft [[G-AGRE "Star Ariel"|G-AGRE ''Star Ariel'']] also disappeared over the western Atlantic, with the loss of all seven crewmen and 13 passengers, while flying from Bermuda to [[Norman Manley International Airport|Kingston Airport]], [[Jamaica]], the following year.<ref>[http://1000aircraftphotos.com/Contributions/Coates/1422.htm Avro 688 Tudor Mk.1 (G-AGRE c/n 1253)] 1000aircraftphotos.com.</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1949-01-01"|1949 |[[Disappearance of Dorothy Forstein|Dorothy Forstein]] |40 |American housewife Dorothy Forstein disappeared in [[Pennsylvania]] on 18 October 1949. Her two children reported that they witnessed an unknown man carrying Dorothy over his shoulder downstairs and she was never seen again.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Jay Robert Nash]] |title=Among the Missing: An Anecdotal History of Missing Persons from 1800 to the Present |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]] |year=1978 |isbn=9781590775233 |pages=119–122}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.the-line-up.com/dorothy-forstein/|title=Vanished into the Night: The Unsolved Disappearance of Dorothy Forstein {{!}} The Lineup|date=2016-12-12|work=The Lineup|access-date=2017-03-12|language=en-US}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1949-01-01"|1949 |[[Jean Spangler]] |26 |Aspiring actress Jean Spangler went missing on 7 October 1949 from [[Los Angeles, California]], under mysterious circumstances. Spangler left her home in Los Angeles after telling her sister-in-law that she was going to meet with her ex-husband before going to work as an extra on a film set. She was last seen at a grocery store several blocks from her home at approximately 6:00 p.m. Two days later Spangler's tattered purse was discovered in a remote area of [[Griffith Park]] approximately {{convert|5.5|mi|km}} from her home.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/real-life/true-stories/cryptic-note-what-happened-to-actress-jean-spangler/news-story/ab9ca6835d6739c75912fd3b4feb76c7|title=Cryptic note: What happened to actress Jean Spangler?|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2017-05-10|language=en}}</ref> She left a note addressed to "Kirk". Police ruled out a connection to the actor [[Kirk Douglas]]. Also ruled out was her ex-husband, but other theories included an illegal abortion that resulted in her death and a connection with gangsters.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Cold-Case--Aspiring-Actress-Left-Cryptic-Note-138625954.html|accessdate=2 November 2018|title=Cold Case: Aspiring Actress Left Cryptic Note|date=February 2, 2012|publisher=NBC Los Angeles}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1949-01-01"|1949 |[[Francis Hong Yong-ho]] |43 |Francis Hong Yong-ho, a [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] [[prelate]], was [[prisoner of conscience|imprisoned]] by the [[communist state|communist regime]] of [[Kim Il-sung]] in 1949. He disappeared and was never seen again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.angelusnews.com/articles/north-korea-could-soon-have-its-first-saint-hong-yong-ho|title=North Korea could soon have its first saint: Hong Yong-ho|access-date=2017-08-04}}</ref> |}
==1950s== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- | data-sort-value="1950"|1950 |{{nowrap|[[Richard Colvin Cox]]}} |21 |A second-year military cadet, disappeared from the [[United States Military Academy]] at [[West Point, New York]], after he met an unknown man, known as "George", three times over the course of a week. On the third occasion, Cox and "George" left the grounds of the Academy and were never seen again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.recordonline.com/article/20020917/NEWS/309179996|title=Missing West Point sergeant not first to disappear|last=Herald-Record|first=Wayne A. Hall, Times|newspaper=recordonline.com|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/19389211/|title=News-Journal from Mansfield, Ohio, on January 14, 1951; disappearances, Page 29|last=|first=|date=|work=|newspaper=Newspapers.com|access-date=2016-11-27|via=}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1951-01-01"|1951 |[[Vincent Mangano]] |63 |A mafia [[crime boss]] of the future [[Gambino crime family]], Vincent Mangano disappeared on the same day that his brother [[Philip Mangano]] was found murdered. He is believed to have been killed on the orders of [[Albert Anastasia]] as part of a coup.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://crime.about.com/od/gangsters/ig/Mafia-Mug-Shots/mangano_vincent.htm|title=Vincent Mangano|newspaper=About.com News & Issues|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/family-gambinos-gallery-1.14318?pmSlide=1.14398|title=All in the Family: Inside the Gambinos – slide 5|newspaper=NY Daily News|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1951-01-01"|1951 |[[Disappearance of Beverly Potts|Beverly Potts]] |10 |Beverly Potts, an American schoolgirl from [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], disappeared while walking home from an entertainment event at Halloran Park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/162dfoh.html|title=The Doe Network: Case File 162DFOH|website=doenetwork.org|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref> She is believed by police to have been abducted and murdered, possibly by someone she knew and trusted as she was shy and fearful of strangers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/p/potts_beverly.html|title=The Charley Project: Beverly Rose Potts|last=Good|first=Meaghan Elizabeth|website=charleyproject.org|access-date=2016-11-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205054829/http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/p/potts_beverly.html|archive-date=5 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1952-10-31"|1952 |[[Disappearance of Steven Damman|Steven Damman]] | 2 |Steven Damman, a two-year-old boy, went missing outside a bakery in [[Long Island]], New York, along with his older sister, on 31 October 1955. His sister was found several blocks away unharmed, but Steven's whereabouts remain unknown.<ref>{{cite web|work=The Charley Project|title=Steven Craig Damman|url=http://charleyproject.org/case/steven-craig-damman|archive-url=https://archive.is/20181109214123/http://charleyproject.org/case/steven-craig-damman|archive-date=9 November 2018}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1953-01-01"|1953 |[[Rudolf Mildner]] |51 |Rudolf Mildner was an Austrian-German [[SS]]-[[Standartenführer]] who served as the chief of the [[Gestapo]] at [[Katowice]] and also was the head of the political department at [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]]. After the war Mildner testified at the [[Nuremberg Trials]] and remained in custody until 1949. It is believed he died in 1953 but [[Adolf Eichmann]] claimed to have met Mildner in [[Argentina]] in 1958. However, his claim has not been verified.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rathkolb|first=Oliver|title=Revisiting the National Socialist Legacy: Coming to Terms With Forced Labor, Expropriation, Compensation, and Restitution|year=2002|publisher=Transaction Publishers|location=United States|isbn=9780765805966|pages=480}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" data-sort-value="1953-01-01"|1953 |[[Felix Moncla]] |27 |rowspan="2"|Pilot [[First Lieutenant]] Felix Moncla along with [[Second Lieutenant]] Robert Wilson, radar operator, disappeared when their [[United States Air Force]] [[F-89 Scorpion]] was scrambled from [[Kincheloe Air Force Base]], and subsequently went missing over [[Lake Superior]], while intercepting an unknown aircraft in [[Canadian airspace]] close to the [[Canada–United States border]]. The USAF claimed the second aircraft was [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] [[C-47 Skytrain|C-47 Dakota]] VC-912, crossing Northern Lake Superior from west to east at 7,000 feet en route from [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], to [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]], [[Ontario]].<ref>[http://www.ufobc.ca/kinross/accReportDocs/accRep_Form14.htm Form 14 – Informal Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812183506/http://www.ufobc.ca/kinross/accReportDocs/accRep_Form14.htm |date=12 August 2007 }} ''UFO*BC'' Gord Heath.</ref> The RCAF stated it had no record of such an incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nicap.org/reports/kinlet.htm|title=RCAF Letter on Kinross UFO Case|publisher=}}</ref> |- |Robert Wilson |22 |- | data-sort-value="1953-01-01"|1953 |[[Evelyn Hartley]] |15 |Evelyn, a teenager from [[La Crosse, Wisconsin]], disappeared on 24 October 1953 from a home while babysitting.<ref name="nampn">{{cite web|title=Evelyn Grace Hartley|url=http://www.nampn.org/cases/hartley_evelyn.html|website=North American Missing Persons Network|publisher=Nampn.org|accessdate=4 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/1388dfwi.html|title=The Doe Network: Case File 1388DFWI|website=doenetwork.org|access-date=2016-11-23}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1953-01-01"|1953 |The five crew members of the ''Holchu'' | |The ''Holchu'', a small cargo ship, was sighted adrift in the Indian Ocean on 7 February 1953, around {{convert|200|mi|km}} south of the [[Nicobar Islands]], by ''[[HMT Empire Windrush]]''. She was later boarded by the crew of a British cargo ship, alerted by ''Windrush''{{'}}s radio warning. They found no trace of the crew and the ''Holchu'' was towed to [[Colombo]]. ''Holchu'' was carrying a cargo of rice and was in good condition, aside from a broken mast. Adequate supplies of food, water and fuel were found, and a meal had been prepared in the ship's galley.<ref name=Times52543a>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Ship Found Adrift Without Crew. |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=11 February 1953 |page_number=8 |issue=52543}}</ref> The fate of the ''Holchu''{{'}}s crew remains unknown. |- | data-sort-value="1953-01-01"|1953 |[[Disappearance of Henry Borynski|Henry Borynski]] |42 |Henry Borynski, a Polish Catholic priest and outspoken anti-Communist, disappeared on 13 July 1953 in [[Bradford|Bradford, Yorkshire]] when he left his residence following a phone call.<ref name="BBC2">{{cite news|title=Fresh claims in unsolved Bradford murder|publisher=BBC News Online|date=27 January 2003|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/insideout/yorkslincs/series2/catholic_church_religion_priest.shtml|accessdate=6 June 2013}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1955-01-01"|1955 |[[Stanley Mathenge]] |36 |Stanley Mathenge, a [[Mau Mau Uprising|Mau Mau]] leader who disappeared in 1955, was later reported to be allegedly living in [[Ethiopia]] but has not been seen since.<ref>Carole Cooper, J. R. A. Bailey & Garth Bundeh: [https://books.google.com/books?id=B3eh2Vefs5YC&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74&dq=%22stanley+mathenge%22+ethiopia&ct=result&resnum=10#v=onepage&q=%22stanley%20mathenge%22%20ethiopia Kenya: The National Epic]. Kenway Publications, 1993</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1955-01-01"|1955 |[[Herman Schultheis]] |55 |A [[Walt Disney Studios (Burbank)|Walt Disney Studios]] photographer and technician in the Special Effects Department, Herman Schultheis is best known for his work on [[Fantasia (1940 film)|''Fantasia'']], [[Pinocchio (1940 film)|''Pinocchio'']], ''[[Dumbo]]'' and ''[[Bambi]]'' disappeared on 20 May 1955.<ref>{{cite book |last=Canemaker |first=John |title=The Secrets of Disney's Visual Effects: The Schultheis Notebooks Hardcover |publisher=Walt Disney Family Foundation Press |publication-date=11 March 2014 |pages=256 |isbn=1616286121 }}</ref> He is believed to have perished in a Guatemalan Jungle.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jacobs|first=Horace|title=Schultheis Disappears in Guatemala Mystery|url=http://www.librascopememories.com/Librascope_Memories/1950_-_1959_files/550700%20Librazette.pdf|accessdate=8 February 2012|newspaper=Librazette|date=July 1955}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1955-01-01"|1955 |[[Weldon Kees]] |41 |Weldon Kees was an American poet, painter, literary critic, novelist, playwright, jazz pianist, short story writer, and filmmaker who went missing. On 19 July 1955 a car owned by Weldon Kees was discovered on the [[Marin County]] side of the [[Golden Gate Bridge]]. While Kees had talked about jumping over the railing of the bridge, he stated that he was physically unable to accomplish the task.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lane|first1=Anthony|title=The Disappearing Poet|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/07/04/the-disappearing-poet|website=NewYorker.com|publisher=The New Yorker|accessdate=19 February 2017}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1955-01-01"|1955 |''[[MV Joyita|Joyita]]'' | |On 10 November, the {{convert|69|ft|m|adj=on}} merchant vessel ''Joyita'' was found abandoned, partially submerged and listing heavily to port, north of the Pacific island of [[Vanua Levu]], part of [[Fiji]]. No sign of the 25 passengers and crew who had been aboard when it was last seen on its departure from [[Apia]], Samoa five weeks earlier. Extensive investigation has failed to find any trace of the passengers or crew.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=1292221|accessdate=12 November 2016|title=Author says he's solved MV Joyita mystery, 47 years later|date=29 March 2002|publisher=NZ Herald}}</ref> |- |rowspan="3" data-sort-value="1956-01-01"|1956 |Robert H. Hodgin |31 |rowspan="3"|Three United States Air Force airmen, commander [[1956 B-47 disappearance#Aftermath|Captain Robert H. Hodgin, observer Captain Gordon M. Insley and pilot 2nd Lt. Ronald L. Kurtz]] disappeared when their [[1956 B-47 disappearance|B-47]] failed to make contact with an [[aerial refueling]] tanker at 14,000 ft over the [[Mediterranean Sea]].<ref>[http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/reading_room/635.pdf DoD narrative summaries of accidents involving U.S. nuclear weapons 1950–1980] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071204104233/http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/reading_room/635.pdf |date=4 December 2007 }}</ref> While the unarmed aircraft was transporting two different capsules of [[nuclear weapon]]s material in carrying cases a nuclear detonation was not possible.<ref>[http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/operation_and_plans/NuclearChemicalBiologicalMatters/21.pdf DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE – NARRATIVE the best SUMMARIES OF ACCIDENTS INVOLVING U.S. NUCLEAR WEAPONS 1950–1980] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140113030431/http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/operation_and_plans/NuclearChemicalBiologicalMatters/21.pdf |date=13 January 2014 }}</ref> |- |Gordon M. Insley |32 |- |Ronald L. Kurtz |22 |- | data-sort-value="1956"|1956 |[[Lionel Crabb|Lionel "Buster" Crabb]] |46 |Crabb, retired British [[Royal Navy]] [[frogman]], disappeared 29 April 1956 during an [[MI6]] mission to spy on the Soviet [[Sverdlov class cruiser|''Sverdlov'' class cruiser]] ''Ordzhonikidze'' in [[Portsmouth Harbour]]. The coroner concluded that a body (missing its head and hands) in a frogman suit found floating in [[Chichester Harbour]] the following year was Crabb's but a positive identification was never made nor cause of death determined.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/9/newsid_4741000/4741060.stm 1956: Mystery of missing frogman deepens] BBC "On This Day".</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1957-01-01"|1957 |[[Maud Crawford]] |65 |[[Maud Crawford]] was an American [[Attorney at law (United States)|attorney]] in [[Camden, Arkansas|Camden]], [[Arkansas]], who disappeared without a trace on a Saturday night in the winter of 1957. Crawford was a partner in a law firm investigating [[American Mafia|Mafia]] influence over [[labor union]]s.<ref name="encofar">{{cite web|url=http://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=2405|title=Maud Robinson Crawford (1891–1957)|publisher=encyclopediaofarkansas.net|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1958-01-01"|1958 |[[Martin family disappearance|Martin family]] | |The Martin family disappeared on 7 December 1958 in [[Hood River County, Oregon|Hood River County]], [[Oregon]], while on a drive. Six months later the bodies of the two youngest daughters were recovered on the [[Columbia River]] although the whereabouts of the mother, father and eldest daughter remains unsolved.<ref name="klare">{{cite web|url=https://nwlaborpress.org/klare/082099.html|work=NW Labor Press|title=Let me say this about that|author=Klare, Glen|date=20 August 1999|accessdate=25 October 2016}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1959-01-01"|1959 |[[Camilo Cienfuegos]] |27 |A [[Cuba]]n revolutionary and friend of [[Fidel Castro]], Camilo Cienfuegos disappeared when his [[Cessna 310]] went missing over the ocean during a night flight from [[Camagüey]] to [[Havana]].<ref>[http://www.miaminewtimes.com/news/who-killed-camilo-cienfuegos-6548166 Who Killed Camilo Cienfuegos] Miami New Times</ref> |- |}
==1960s== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- ! data-sort-type="isoDate"|Date ! data-sort-type="text"|Person(s) ! data-sort-type="text"|Age ! class="unsortable"|Circumstances |- | data-sort-value="1960-01-01"|1960 |[[Chen Tien]] | |The head of the Central Propaganda Department of the [[Malayan Communist Party]] (MCP) Chen Tien disappeared four years after taking part in talks with government officials to try to reach a mutually agreeable solution in the [[Malayan Emergency]]. The talks broke down and Tien continued to take part in the insurrection until the Malayan government suppressed the MCP in 1960 and declared the emergency over.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Ramakrishna |first1=K. |title=Content, credibility and context: Propaganda government surrender policy and the Malayan communist terrorist mass surrenders of 1958 |doi=10.1080/02684529908432579 |journal=Intelligence and National Security |volume=14 |issue=4 |pages=242–266 |year=1999}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1960-01-01"| 1960 |[[James Squillante]] |41 |Squillante, a [[caporegime]] in the [[Gambino crime family]], disappeared after being indicted on [[extortion]] charges. He went out on a boat near the coast of Santa Monica and disappeared while shark fishing and is presumed to have drowned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.davidkenyonwebster.com/biography.html|title=David Kenyon Webster, author of "Parachute Infantry – An American Paratrooper's Memoir of D-Day and the Fall of the Third Reich"|website=davidkenyonwebster.com|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1961-01-01"|1961 |[[Masanobu Tsuji]] |59 |The [[Japanese people|Japanese]] army officer and politician disappeared on a trip to [[Laos]] and was never heard from again.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://militaryanalysis.blogspot.ca/2011/01/disappearance.html|title=Disappearance.|website=militaryanalysis.blogspot.ca|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref> |- | data-sort-value="1961-01-01"|1961 |[[Disappearance of Joan Risch|Joan Risch]] |31 |The [[Lincoln, Massachusetts]], homemaker was last seen in her driveway by a neighbor on the afternoon of 24 October 1961 and several unconfirmed sightings were reported on local roads later that day. again|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/justice-story/3-girls-beach-found-article-1.1216303|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=9 December 2012|accessdate=1 December 2016}}</ref> to a hit ordered
